title: COP26: SDG or NDC? Our guide to the language you need to know
text: Letâ€™s start with the name of the event itself, COP26. In laymanâ€™s terms, this is the 26th UN climate change conference, but officially it is the 26th Conference of the Parties (or COP) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Letâ€™s break that down a bitâ€¦The UNFCCC was established following the 1992 UN Conference on Environment and Development in Rio (often referred to as the Earth Summit). The stated aim of the UNFCCC was to reduce greenhouse gases in order to prevent dangerous climate change caused by human activity.Â Conferences of the Parties to the convention, or COPs, are the formal meetings that have taken place every year since 1995, apart from 2020: the COVID-19 pandemic meant that COP26 was delayed by a year.There are 17 inter-linked Sustainable Development Goals, or SDGs, which focus on challenges ranging from clean energy access, to poverty reduction and responsible consumption.Â Together, the SDGs make up the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the UNâ€™s blueprint for peace and prosperity for people and the planet.Climate Change is one of the Goals (SDG 13), butÂ tâ€™s becoming increasingly clear that climate change plays a role in many, if not all of the SDGs, and that achieving the 2030 Agenda will be impossible without making serious inroads into tackling the problem.This stands for Nationally Determined Contribution, the detailed plan that individual countries are required to make, under the Paris Agreement, to show how they will cut the amount of harmful greenhouse gases they emit. All countries are expected to revise their NDC to reflect greater ambition.Â Presently, these plans are not sufficient to keep global warming to 1.5Â° Celsius above pre-industrial levels, so this year, there is increased pressure on countries to sharply increase their level of ambition.Put simply, net zero means cutting emissions to as close to zero as possible, such as by moving toward a green economy and clean renewable energy, with any remaining emissions reabsorbed, including oceans and forests.Practically every country has joined the Paris Agreement on climate change, which calls for keeping the global temperature to 1.5Â°C above pre-industrial era levels.If we continue to pump out the emissions that cause climate change, however, temperatures will continue to rise well beyond 1.5, to levels that threaten the lives and livelihoods of people everywhere.This is why a growing number of countries are making commitments to achieve "net zero" emissions by 2050. Itâ€™s a big task, requiring ambitious actions starting right now.Youâ€™ll be hearing â€œthe goal of 1.5 degrees Celsiusâ€ a lot during COP. In a 2018, an IPCC Â report, reviewed by thousands of scientists and governments, found that limiting global temperature rise to no more than 1.5Â°C above pre-industrial levels (in the mid-18th century), would help us avoid the worst climate impacts and maintain a liveable climate.Â According to the latest data, our world has already warmed between 1.06 to 1.26 above pre-industrial levels, and even if current promises are met, we would still be on a course to reach 2.7Â°C this century. This would mean a â€œclimate catastropheâ€ as highlighted by the UN Secretary-General, with a possible collapse of ecosystems, and life as we know it.The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is the UN body for assessing the science related to climate change.Created in 1988 by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), the objective of the IPCC is to provide governments at all levels with scientific information that they can use to develop climate policies.IPCC reports are also a key input into the international climate change negotiations that will be happening during COP26. A major report released in August showed that unless there are rapid, sustained and large-scale reductions of greenhouse gas emissions, including CO2, methane and others, the goal of limiting global warming to 1.5C will be beyond reach.Small Island Developing States are a distinct group of 58 low-lying island nations that are highly vulnerable and often affected by weather extremes and climate change, including the increased severity of cyclones, storm surges, heavy rains, droughts, sea-level rise and ocean acidification.During the latest high-level week of the General Assembly, SIDS leaders from Fiji, Tuvalu and the Maldives took centre stage saying their nations are facing an existential threat if rich countries fail to make good on their promises to turn the tide on global warming.Broadly speaking, climate finance relates to the money which needs to be spent on a whole range of activities to reduce the emissions that are causing climate change, and to help people adapt to and build resilience for the impacts of climate change that are already occurring. Â It can involve local, national, or transnational financing, which may be drawn from public, private and alternative sources of financing. Climate finance is critical to addressing climate change, because large-scale investments are required to significantly reduce emissions, notably in sectors that emit large quantities of greenhouse gases, and to help adaptation efforts.Â In 2009, during the COP15 in Copenhagen rich nations promised to channel $100 billion a year to less-wealthy nations by 2020, to help them adapt to climate change and mitigate further rises in temperature.The promise still hasnâ€™t been deliveredâ€”climate finance to developing countries presently amounts to about $80 billion--, and therefore climate finance will be one of the biggest issues of discussion during COP26.Â This stands for the UN-backed Science Based Target initiative. Companies which sign up to the initiative set science-based emission reduction targets, which leave them better equipped to tackle climate change, and making them more competitive, in the transition to a net-zero economy.Science-based target setting has become a standard business practice, and corporations are playing a major role in driving down global greenhouse gas emissions and in supporting the implementation of country commitments.Nature-based Solutions are actions to protect, sustainably manage, and restore natural and modified ecosystems that address societal challenges effectively and adaptively, simultaneously providing human well-being and biodiversity benefits.Nature-Based Solutions are an essential part of the overall global effort to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change: they are a vital complement to decarbonisation, reducing climate change risks and establishing climate resilient societies.Examples include massive tree planting programmes, which absorb carbon and provide protection from intense rainfall, and rebuilding mangroves, which provide effective and cheap natural barriers against coastal floods and shoreline erosion.The Group of 20 (G20) is an intergovernmental forum comprising most of the worldâ€™s largest economies: 19 nations and the European Union. Â They work to address major issues related to the global economy, such as international financial stability, climate change mitigation, and sustainable development.Â The UN Secretary-General has made clear that climate action must be led by G20 nations, which collectively account for around 90 per cent of gross world product, 75-80 per cent of international trade and two thirds or the worldâ€™s population.Â Their commitment during COP26 is crucial for curbing greenhouse gases and stop fuelling climate change.Â The African Group of Negotiators on Climate Change (AGN) was established at COP1 in Berlin, Germany in 1995 as an alliance of African member states that represents the interests of the region in the international climate change negotiations, with a common and unified voice.Outside the formal intergovernmental negotiations, countries, cities and regions, businesses and civil society members across the world are already taking action for the climate.The Global Climate Action Agenda (GCAA), initiated under the Lima Paris Action Agenda, was launched to spur rapid climate action, boost cooperation between governments, local authorities, the business community, investors, and civil society, and to support the adoption and the implementation of the Paris Agreement.Â UN News is producing special coverage from COP26 in Glasgow. You can find all our COP-related stories here.

title: General Assembly debate underscores need to deliver on climate action
text: The day-long meeting comes just ahead of the COP26 climate change conference for countries to deliver on the promise of keeping global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, in line with the 2015 Paris Agreement.Â In his opening remarks, Assembly President Abdulla Shahid highlighted the â€œblunt realitiesâ€ of climate impacts such as rising sea levels, which are threatening island nations like his homeland, the Maldives.Â However, as the architect of a â€œPresidency of Hopeâ€, Mr. Shahid stressed that countries can confront these challenges if they work together.Â â€œTodayâ€™s event will not solve climate change, only action will,â€ he said, speaking from the rostrum. â€œTodayâ€™s event is about reminding people of what we are capable of if we act in concert, trust in science, and intelligently mobilize the many resources we have at our disposal.â€Â Scientists are unequivocal about the causes of the climate emergency. Human activities have warmed the atmosphere, ocean and land, driving ice melt and leading to unprecedented and rapid changes, said ValÃ©rie Masson-Delmotte from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the UN body that has published a series of ground-breaking but alarming reports on the issue.Â â€œHuman-caused climate change is already affecting every region on Earth in many ways, strengthening the frequency and intensity of extreme events such as heatwaves, heavy precipitation events, droughts and fire weather,â€ she said, speaking via videolink. â€œThe changes we already experience will increase with further warming.â€Â The UN and its General Assembly, where all 193 Member States are represented, were created so that countries could unite to address common crises such as climate change, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres told the meeting. Â Â COP26 in Glasgow will be a moment of truth, he added, because despite the alarm bells, governmentsâ€™ actions so far â€œsimply do not add up to what is so desperately needed.â€ Â Â The world currently remains on a track for global temperature rise of 2.7 degrees Celsius, far from the 1.5 degree goal, or what Mr. Guterres called â€œthe only liveable future for humanity.â€ Â He said the situation can only be reversed through reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 45 per cent this decade, when compared to 2010 levels, and net-zero emissions by mid-century. Â Leaders must also come to COP26 with bold targets and new concrete policies.Â â€œThe time has passed for diplomatic niceties,â€ the UN chief said. Â â€œIf governments - especially G20 governments - do not stand up and lead this effort, we are headed for terrible human suffering.â€Â And while people expect their governments to lead, Mr. Guterres stressed that everyone has a role in achieving a future where fossil fuels, which create greenhouse gases, are abandoned for cleaner energy sources. Â This includes businesses, investors and average citizens.Â â€œIndividuals in every society need to make better, more responsible choices - in what they eat, how they travel, and what they purchase as consumers,â€ said Mr. Guterres. Â â€œAnd young people - and climate activists - need to keep doing what theyâ€™re doing: demanding action from their leaders.â€Â The Secretary-General also underlined the need for solidarity, urging richer countries to meet their commitment of at least $100 billion in annual climate finance for developing nations.Â He also called for donors and development banks to devote at least 50 per cent of their climate support towards adaptation and resilience in the developing world.Â Climate action and sustainable development must go hand-in-hand, said the President of the UN Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), Collen Kelapile. Â He underlined that everyone must be part of the net-zero future.Â â€œThe global transformation to address climate change must be just, inclusive, and equitable to ensure that no one is left behind, especially women, children, youth, indigenous peoples and displaced populations,â€ he said.Â Mr. Kelapile added that countries must also invest in reskilling affected workers, and in economic diversification of communities. Â Like the Secretary-General, he also called for greater support for developing countries as they pursue a greener path.Â More than 70 speakers are expected to participate in the debate, which will conclude on Tuesday evening.

title: â€˜Vagueâ€™ net zero promises not enough: planet still on track for catastrophic heating, UN report warns
text: Tuesdayâ€™s new Emissions Gap Report shows that updated Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) - the efforts by each country to reduce national emissions, as well as other commitments made for 2030 but not yet officially submitted - would only lead to an additional 7.5 per cent reduction in annual greenhouse emissions in 2030, compared to previous commitments.One week before #COP26, we were still on track for a catastrophic global temperature rise of around 2.7 degrees Celsius.Scientists are clear on the facts.Leaders need to be just as clear in their plans to avoid climate catastrophe. pic.twitter.com/EpGuuOd4YLThis is not enough. According to the agency, the world needs a 55 per cent reduction to limit global temperature increase below 1.5Â°C, the capstone defined by scientists as the less risky scenery for our planet and humanityâ€™s future.Â "Less than one week before COP26 in Glasgow, we are still on track for climate catastrophe", said UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres during a press conference introducing the new assessement."As the title of this yearâ€™s report puts it: 'The heat is on'. And as the contents of the report show â€” the leadership we need is off. Far off", he warned.The report finds that net zero pledges, if fully implemented, could make a big difference and bring down the predicted global temperature rise to 2.2Â°C, providing hope that further action could still head off the most catastrophic impacts of climate change.However, so far these promises are â€œvagueâ€ and inconsistent with most 2030 national commitments, UNEP warns.A total of 49 countries plus the European Union have pledged a net zero target. This covers over half of global domestic greenhouse gas emissions, over half of global GDP and a third of the global population. Eleven targets are enshrined in law, covering 12 per cent of global emissions.Yet, many NDCs delay action until after 2030, raising doubts over whether net-zero pledges can be delivered, the report says.Moreover, although twelve G20 members have pledged a net zero target, ambiguity still surrounds the means of reaching that goal, says the report.â€œThe world has to wake up to the imminent peril we face as a species. Nations need to put in place the policies to meet their new commitments and start implementing them within monthsâ€, warned Inger Andersen, UNEPâ€™s Executive Director in the foreword.â€œThey need to make their net zero pledges more concrete, ensuring these commitments are included in NDCs, and action brought forward. They then need to get the policies in place to back this raised ambition and, again, start implementing them urgentlyâ€, she added.The report is clear: to have a chance of reaching the 1.5Â°C target, the world needs to almost halve greenhouse gas emissions in the next eight years. This means removing an additional 28 gigatonnes of CO2 equivalent from annual emissions, over and above what is promised in the updated NDCs and other 2030 commitments.According to the agency, post-pandemic emissions, after lowering initially, have bounced back and are now raising atmospheric concentrations of CO2, higher than at any time in the last two million years."The emissions gap is the result of a leadership gap but leaders can still make this a turning point to a greener future instead of a tipping point to climate catastrophe.Â The era of half measures and hollow promises must end", urged UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres.Experts point out that the opportunity for using COVID-19 fiscal rescue and recovery spending to stimulate economies, while fostering a low-carbon transformation, â€œhas been missed in most countries so farâ€.Only a small number of high-income economies account for the majority of green spending, with developing nations and emerging markets in danger of being left behind.COVID-19 spending has been far lower in low-income economies ($60 per person) than advanced economies ($11,800 per person). Gaps in finance are likely to exacerbate gaps in vulnerable nations on climate resilience and mitigation measures, the report warns."As world leaders prepare for COP26, this report is another thundering wake-up call.Â How many do we need?...Scientists are clear on the facts.Â Now leaders need to be just as clear in their actions. They need to come to Glasgow with bold, time-bound, front-loaded plans to reach net-zero", added Guterres.Â Â Â The Emissions Gap Report 2021 also explores the potential of the reduction of methane emissions from the fossil fuel, waste and agriculture sectors, to curb warming in the short term.Cuts to methane could limit temperature increase faster than cuts to carbon dioxide, the experts explain. The gas, the second largest contributor to global warming, has a heating potential over 80 times that of carbon dioxide over a 20-year time horizon; it also has a shorter lifetime in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide â€“ only twelve years, compared to potentially hundreds, for CO2.The report indicates that available no or low-cost technical measures alone could reduce anthropogenic methane emissions by around 20 per cent per year, and with broader structural and behavioural measures, by approximately 45 per cent.

title: Middle East Green Initiative: â€˜pathbreaking workâ€™ to protect the planet
text: With only a few days until the G20 Summit of leading industrialized nations in Rome, followed immediately by the UN climate conference (COP26) in Glasgow, Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed lauded the new initiative.In our fight against climate change, failure is a choice, not a certainty. The launch of the Middle East Green Initiative #MGISummit today is a clear testimony to the region's ability to act as a frontrunner for a post-carbon, resilient and inclusive economy. #ClimateAction pic.twitter.com/ukPSUXeRqpâ€œIt will not only help reduce emissions from the oil and gas industry in the region but will also create new carbon sinks and help restore and protect vast swaths of land through afforestationâ€, she said.â€œIt is now clear that the global economy is irreversibly heading towards the deep decarbonization of all sectors, from energy, to manufacturing, transport, and food systemsâ€.Ms. Mohammed echoed the Secretary-Generalâ€™s warning that global temperature rises greater than 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, would condemn the worldâ€™s children to a â€œhellish futureâ€.â€œWe need to urgently peak, reduce, and stabilize global greenhouse gas emissions to Net Zero by 2050â€ by cutting global emissions by 2030 by 45 per cent, compared to 2010 levels, she said.â€œYour leadership is needed more than ever at this historic junctureâ€.Entire communities the world over, are already being hurt by climate impacts, with the Middle East and North Africa particularly vulnerable.Exposed to a range of systemic risks, such as desertification, food insecurity, forced displacement and extreme heat waves, without action the region will face 200 days of extreme heat, and temperatures of 50Â°C, every year by the end of the century, according to Ms. Mohammed.â€œBut the region also has incredible assets to leverage, which could make it a frontrunner for a post-carbon, resilient, and inclusive economyâ€, she added.Everyone must act quickly for a fair net-zero transition in all regions, especially those dependent on oil and gas revenues, Ms. Mohammed said, spelling out: â€œIn our fight against climate change, failure is a choice, not a certaintyâ€.While transitioning away from fossil fuels will be â€œa challenge of epic proportionsâ€, requiring targeted support to those temporarily impacted, she upheld that those investments â€œcould yield innumerable benefits in the long termâ€.â€œSolidarity and fairness are core principles that underpin the multilateral regimeâ€ she said. â€œThat is why I am pleased to see that the Middle East Green Initiative is a regional and cooperative approach to climate actionâ€.During COP26, the deputy UN chief urged the leaders to be prepared to make it not only a success, but a real turning point towards â€œa green, resilient, and just transitionâ€.Â Against that backdrop, she suggested that all countries update their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) for increasingly ambitious climateÂ actions that â€œbring us closer to our collective emission reduction goalâ€ globally.â€œG20 countries, who are responsible for up to 80 per cent of global emissions must lead by exampleâ€, said the UN official, asking donors to allocate at least half of their climate finance to adaptation.â€œAs shareholders of multilateral, regional and national development banks and funds, you can instruct your representatives at the Boards of these institutions to work toward allocating 50 per cent of climate finance to adaptationâ€, she said.Pointing out that the Paris Agreement on climate change requires that all public and private finance investment flows be aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), she urged that private finance reach constituencies that are â€œnot always on their radarâ€, such as least developed countries, small-developing islands and in general vulnerable communities.â€œAnd private finance institutionsâ€¦need to pass the credibility test...[including] robust taxonomies and standards; mandatory climate risk disclosure; and more transparency across the board to ensure that all financial flows contribute to keeping the 1.5C degree goal within reachâ€, she said. â€œCredibility will be keyâ€.And top executives in the private sector, should understand that developing countries should not be saddled with unsustainable levels of debt, forced to make â€œimpossible trade-offs to the detriment of their people and our planetâ€.

title: COP26: Praise for updated national climate plans, but â€˜nowhere nearâ€™ goal
text: TheÂ findings updateÂ an earlierÂ reportÂ whichÂ synthesizesÂ plans outlined by countries in their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) under the Paris AgreementÂ on climate change,Â which aims to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius.Â Â Â "Parties must urgently redouble their climate efforts if they are to prevent global temperature increases (that) will lead to a destabilised world and endless suffering." -@PEspinosaC on the updated NDC Synthesis Report published today.ğŸ”—https://t.co/3mtAXuFhV4 | #COP26 pic.twitter.com/Dn2w0LFOJHPartiesÂ to the accord requested the Synthesis Report, published in September, to help them in assessing progress ahead of the COP26Â UNÂ climate change conference, which opens this weekend in Glasgow, Scotland.Â The update has been provided soÂ that countriesÂ will have the latest information to consider at the conference.Â ItÂ incorporatesÂ information from the 165 latest available NDCs, representing all 192 parties to the Paris Agreement.Â Â ThisÂ includes 116 new or updated NDCs received from 143 parties as ofÂ this month, compared to 86 new or updated NDCs covered by the September report.Â Patricia Espinosa, the UNFCCC Executive Secretary, said the NDCs â€œclearly represent a commitment to acting on climate change.â€â€¯â€¯Â For the 143 parties that have submitted new or updated NDCs, total emissions are estimated at around nine per cent below the 2010 level by 2030.Â  Additionally, 71Â nationsÂ have communicated that they hope to reach carbon neutrality byÂ roughlyÂ mid-century. Their total GHG emission level could be up to 88 per cent lower in 2050 than in 2019.Â However, the update also confirmed that for all available NDCs of all 192 parties, when taken together,Â would seeÂ a â€œsizeable increaseâ€ of around 16 per cent in global GHG emission in 2030 when compared to 2019.Â  This could lead to a global temperature rise of around 2.7 degrees Celsius by the end of the century.Â Ms. Espinosa saidÂ partiesÂ â€œmust urgently redouble their climate effortsâ€Â if they are toÂ preventÂ temperature increases beyond theÂ goals of theÂ Paris Agreement.Â Â â€œOvershooting the temperature goals will lead to aÂ destabilisedÂ world and endless suffering, especially among those who have contributed the least to the GHG emissions in the atmosphere.â€œThis updated report unfortunately confirms the trend already indicated in the full Synthesis Report, which is that we are nowhere near where science says we should be,â€ she warned.Â Limiting global average temperature increases to 1.5 degrees,Â requires a 45 per cent reduction in carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions in 2030, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), or 25 per cent reduction by 2030 to keep it toÂ twoÂ degrees.Â Â UNFCCC, also known as UN Climate, added that â€œif emissions are not reduced by 2030, they will need to be substantially reduced thereafter to compensate for the slow start on the path to net zero emissions, but likely at a higher cost.â€Â The report underscores why countries need to show ambitious climate action at COP26, saidÂ UKÂ Cabinet Office Minister,Â Alok Sharma, the COP26 President, noting that while progress has been made, it is not enough.Â He called for â€œthe biggest emittersâ€, the G20 nations,Â to show stronger commitments to keep the 1.5Â degree goal in reach over what â€œthis critical decade.â€Â Said Mr. Sharma: â€œGlasgow must launch a decade of ever-increasing ambition. At COP26 we must come together for ourselves, future generations and our planet.â€Â Ms. Espinosa emphasized that parties can submit NDCs, or â€œrevisitâ€ earlier submissions to increase action, at any time, including during the conference.Â Many developing countries have NDCs that contain more ambitious commitments to reduce emissions, which can only be implemented with increased financialÂ resources and other support.Â  Doing so could allow for global emissions to peak before 2030, according to the report.Â â€œThis underscores that developing countries need financial, technological and capacity-building support to increase their level of ambition, both with respect to reducing emissions, as well as in terms of building resilienceÂ to the effects of climate change,â€ said Ms. Espinosa.Â Â â€œThe pledge to mobilizeÂ $100 billion annually by 2020 is key for enhancing climate action by developing countries. I call on developed countries to fulfill this pledge in full at COP26,â€â€¯she added.

title: â€˜No time to loseâ€™ curbing greenhouse gases: WMO
text: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) Greenhouse Gas Bulletin contains a â€œstark, scientific messageâ€ for climate change negotiations at the upcoming UN climate conference, known asÂ COP26, in Glasgow, said Petteri Taalas, head of the UN agency.Greenhouse gas levels are at new records. AgainConcentration of CO2 in 2020 was 149% of pre-industrial timesEconomic slowdown from COVID-19 had no real impactWe are set for a ğŸŒ¡ï¸ increase much higher than #ParisAgreement target of 1.5Â°C-2Â°C.https://t.co/LQ5sVilzcE#COP26 pic.twitter.com/S0NHxa5jg9â€œAt the current rate of increase in greenhouse gas concentrations, we will see a temperature increase by the end of this century far in excess of theÂ Paris AgreementÂ targets of 1.5 to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levelsâ€, he explained. â€œWe are way off track.â€Concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in 2020 was 149 per cent above the pre-industrial level; methane, 262 per cent; and nitrous oxide, 123 per cent, compared to the point when human activitity began to be a destabilizing factor.And although the coronavirus-driven economic slowdown sparked a temporary decline in new emissions, it has had no discernible impact on the atmospheric levels of greenhouse gases or their growth rates.As emissions continue, so too will rising global temperatures, the report maintained.Moreover, given the long life of CO2, the current temperature level will persist for decades, even if emissions are rapidly reduced to net zero.From intense heat and rainfall to sea-level rise and ocean acidification, rising temperatures will be accompanied by more weather extremes â€“ all with far-reaching socioeconomic impacts.â€œThe last time the Earth experienced a comparable concentration of CO2Â was three to five million years ago, when the temperature was 2-3Â°C warmer and sea level was 10-20 meters higher than nowâ€, stated the WMO chief. â€œBut there werenâ€™t 7.8 billion people thenâ€, he reminded.Roughly half of todayâ€™s human-emitted CO2 remains in the atmosphere and the other half is absorbed by oceans and land ecosystems, the Bulletin flagged.At the same time, the capacity of land ecosystems and oceans to absorb emissions may become a less effective buffer against temperature increases in the future.Meanwhile, many countries are currently setting carbon neutral targets amidst the hope that COP26 will see a dramatic increase in commitments.â€œWe need to transform our commitment into action that will have an impact of the gases that drive climate change. We need to revisit our industrial, energy and transport systems and whole way of lifeâ€, said the WMO official.Â â€œThe needed changes are economically affordable and technically possible", he assured. â€œThere is no time to loseâ€.CO2 is the single most important greenhouse gas and has â€œmajor negative repercussions for our daily lives and well-being, for the state of our planet and for the future of our children and grandchildrenâ€, argued the WMO chief.CarbonÂ sinksÂ areÂ vital regulators of climate change because they remove one-quarter of the CO2 that humans release into the atmosphere.Nitrous Oxide is both a powerful greenhouse gas and ozone depleting chemical that is emitted into the atmosphere from both natural and anthropogenic sources, including oceans, soils, biomass burning, fertilizer use and various industrial processes.Multiple co-benefits of reducing methane, whose gas remains in the atmosphere for about a decade, could support the Paris Agreement and help to reach many Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), said the Bulletin.

title: From the Field: Costa Rica points the way to a sustainable world
text: The award also highlights just how far Costa Rica has come: in the 1990s, the country had the worldâ€™s highest global deforestation rates, and less than a quarter of its original forest cover remained, largely due to agricultural expansion and logging.Since then, policies that encourage sustainable land use practices have proved to be successful in reversing the decline, and today, Costa Rica is one of the only countries in the world to reverse its deforestation, stop biodiversity loss, and increase forest cover to over half its total territory, whilst increasingÂ economic growth.You can read more about Costa Rica and the Earthshot prize here.

title: 'Landmark decisionâ€™ gives legal teeth to protect environmental defenders
text: â€œI remain deeply concerned by the targeting of environmental activistsâ€, said Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, welcoming the rapid response mechanism as â€œan important contribution to help advanceÂ myÂ Call to Action for Human Rightsâ€.Â The agreement will delegate setting up the new mechanism to the United Nations, or another international body."20 years ago, the #AarhusConvention entered into force, bridging the gap between human & environmental rights. Today, as the devastating effects of #climatechange continue to ravage the world, the Conventionâ€™s core purpose has never been more critical" -ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡³@UN SG @antonioguterres pic.twitter.com/Ucw9TzPvvpAs the first ever internationally-agreed tool to safeguard environmental defenders, it marksÂ an important stepÂ in upholding the universal right to a clean,Â healthyÂ and sustainable environment â€“Â as recognized by the Human Rights Council earlier this month.Â â€œTwenty years ago, the Aarhus Convention entered into force, bridging the gap between human and environmental rights.Today, as the devastating effects of climate change continue toÂ ravageÂ the world, the Conventionâ€™s core purpose â€“ of allowing people to protect their wellbeing and that of future generations â€“ has never been more criticalâ€, spelled out the UN chief.Â The agreement to establishÂ the mechanism was adopted on Thursday by the Meeting of the Parties to the Convention on Access to Information, Public Participation inÂ Decision-MakingÂ and Access to Justice in Environmental Matters, known as the Aarhus Convention.Â â€œThisÂ landmarkÂ decisionÂ is a clearÂ signal toÂ environmental defendersÂ that they will not be left unprotectedâ€, said UNECE chief OlgaÂ Algayerova.â€œItÂ demonstrates a new level of commitment to upholding the publicâ€™s rights under the Aarhus Convention,Â as well asÂ Partiesâ€™ willingness to respond effectively to grave and real-time challenges seen in the Conventionâ€™s implementation on the groundâ€.Â Â Â WhetherÂ it is groups protesting the construction of a dangerous dam or individuals speaking out against harmful agricultural practices in their local community, these activists are vital to environmental preservation across the globe, said the UNECE.The Aarhus Convention ensures that those exercising their rights in conformity with the provisions of the Convention shall not be penalized,Â persecutedÂ or harassed in any way for their involvement.As such, the mechanism will establish a Special Rapporteur â€“ or independent rights expert â€“ who will quickly respond to alleged violations and take measures to protect those experiencing or under imminent threat of penalization, persecution, or harassment forÂ seekingÂ to exercise their rights under the Convention.Â Â As time is of the essence to buttress the safety of environmental defenders, any member of the public, secretariat or Party to the Aarhus Convention, will be able to submitÂ a confidential complaint to the Special Rapporteur, even before other legal remedies have been exhausted.Â Â Â Although it is crucial for environmental defenders to confidently exercise their rights, cases have been reported in which instead, they face being fired, heavy fines, criminalization, detention, violence,Â and even death.Â Moreover, incidents of harassment and violence against environmental defenders are far from uncommon.Â A report to the Human Rights CouncilÂ byÂ Mary Lawlor, Special RapporteurÂ onÂ the situation ofÂ human rights defenders,Â found thatÂ one-in-two human rights defenders who were killed inÂ 2019 hadÂ been working with communities around issues of land, environment,Â impactsÂ of business activities,Â povertyÂ and rights of indigenous peoples,Â AfrodescendantsÂ and other minorities.Â Â Since January 2017, among the Parties to the Aarhus Convention,Â incidentsÂ of persecution, penalization and harassment of environmental defendersÂ have been reported in 16 countries.Â In contrast to current existingÂ initiatives, whichÂ mainly rely on applying political pressure through the media, the Aarhus Conventionâ€™s rapid response mechanism will be built on a binding legal framework, giving it much greater powers to act.

title: Madagascar: Severe drought could spur worldâ€™s first climate change famine
text: The region has been hit hard by successive years of severe drought, forcing families in rural communities to resort to desperate measures just to survive.Â Madagascar, the fourth largest island in the world, has a unique ecosystem which includes animals and plants found nowhere else on the planet. The country experiences a dry season, usually from May to October, and a rainy season that starts in November. Â However, climate change has disrupted the cycle, affecting smallholder farmers and their neighbours, said Alice Rahmoun, WFP Communications Officer in the capital, Antananarivo, speaking to UN News on Thursday.Â â€œThere is of course less rain, so when there is the first rain, they can maybeâ€¯haveâ€¯hope and sow some seeds. But one little rain is not a proper rainy season,â€ she said. Â â€œSo, what we can say is that the impacts of climate change are really stronger and strongerâ€¦.so harvests fail constantly, so people donâ€™t have anything to harvest and anything to renew their food stocks.â€Â Ms. Rahmoun was recently in southern Madagascar, where WFP and partners are supporting hundreds of thousands of people through short and long-term assistance. Â Â The impact of the drought varies from place to place, she said. While some communities have not had a proper rainy season for three years, the situation might be even worse 100 kilometres away. Â She recalled seeing villages surrounded by dried-out fields, and tomato plants which were â€œcompletely yellow, or even brownâ€, from lack of water. Â â€œIn some areas they are still able to plant something, but it's not easy at all, so they are trying to grow sweet potatoes. Â But in some other areas, absolutely nothing is growing right now, so people are just survivingâ€¯onlyâ€¯eating locusts, eating fruits and cactus leaves,â€ said Ms. Rahmoun. Â Â â€œAnd, just as an example, cactus leaves are usuallyâ€¯forâ€¯cattle; it is not for human consumption.â€ Â Â The situation is even more dire because, she added, â€œeven the cactusâ€¯areâ€¯dying from theâ€¯drought,â€¯from the lack of rain and the lack of water, so it's really, really worryingâ€.Â The plight of families is also deeply troubling. â€œPeople have already started to develop coping mechanisms to survive,â€ she said. Â â€œAnd that means that they are selling cattle, for example, to get money to be able to buy food, when before, they were able to get food and feed themselves from their own field production, so it's really changing the daily life for people.â€Â Valuable assets such as fields, or even houses, are also put up for sale.Â  Some families have even pulled their children out of school.Â â€œItâ€™s also a strategy right now to gather the family'sâ€¯forcesâ€¯on finding income-generating activities involving children, so this has obviously a direct impact on education,â€ Ms. Rahmoun said.Â WFP is collaborating with humanitarian partners, and the Malagasy Government, to provide two types of response to the crisis. Â Some 700,000 people are receiving life-saving food aid, including supplementary products to prevent malnutrition.Â â€œThe second one is more long-term response to allow local communities to be able to prepare for, respond to and recover from climate shocks better,â€ said Ms. Rahmoun. â€œSo, this includes resilience projects such as water projects.Â  Weâ€™re doing irrigation canals, reforestation and even microinsurance to help smallholder farmers to recover from a lost harvest, for example.â€Â WFP ultimately aims to support up to one million people between now and April, and is seeking nearly $70 million to fund operations. Â â€œBut we are also involving more partners to find and fund climate change solutions for the community to adapt to the impacts of climate change in southern Madagascar.â€Â In just over a week, world leaders will gather in Glasgow, Scotland, for the COP26 UN climate change conference, which UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has called the last chance to â€œliterally turn the tideâ€ on an ailing planet.Â Ms. Rahmoun said WFP wants to use the conference to shift the focus from crisis response, to risk management. Â Countries must be prepared for climate shocks, and they must act together to reduce severe impacts on the worldâ€™s most vulnerable people, which includes the villagers of southern Madagascar.Â â€œCOP26 is also an opportunity for us to askâ€¯governmentsâ€¯and donors to prioritize funding relating to climate adaptationâ€¯programmes,â€¯to help countries to build a better risk management system, and even in Madagascar, because if nothing is done, hunger will increase exponentially in the coming years because of climate change,â€ she said, adding: â€œnot only in Madagascar, but in other countries.â€

title: Plastic pollutionÂ on course to double byÂ 2030
text: The report highlightsÂ dire consequences for health,Â theÂ economy, biodiversity and the climate. It also says a drasticÂ reduction in unnecessary, avoidable and problematic plastic,Â is crucial to addressing the global pollution crisisÂ overall.Â Â ToÂ help reduce plastic waste at the needed scale, it proposes an accelerated transition from fossil fuels to renewable energies, the removal of subsidies and a shift towardsÂ moreÂ circular approachesÂ towards reduction.Â TitledÂ From Pollution to Solution: a global assessment of marine litter and plastic pollution,Â the reportÂ shows that there is a growing threat, acrossÂ all ecosystems,Â from source to sea.Â Our oceans are full of plastic. A new @UNEP assessment provides a strong scientific case for the urgency to act, and for collective action to protect and restore our oceans from source to sea. #CleanSeashttps://t.co/97DMOZD3Ee pic.twitter.com/3xjthnsTh2But it also shows thatÂ there isÂ the know-howÂ to reverseÂ theÂ mountingÂ crisis,Â provided theÂ political willÂ is there,Â and urgent actionÂ isÂ taken.Â TheÂ document isÂ beingÂ released 10 days ahead of theÂ start of the crucialÂ UN Climate Conference,Â COP26,Â stressingÂ that plastics are a climate problem as well.Â Â For example,Â in 2015,Â greenhouse gas emissions from plastics were 1.7 gigatonnes of CO2 equivalent; by 2050, theyâ€™reÂ projected to increase to approximately 6.5Â gigatonnes.Â That number representsÂ 15 per cent of theÂ wholeÂ global carbonÂ budgetÂ -Â theâ€‹â€‹Â amount of greenhouse gas that can be emitted,Â whileÂ still keepingÂ warming within the Paris Agreement goals.Â AddressingÂ solutionsÂ to the problem, the authors pour cold water on the chances of recycling our way out of the plastic pollution crisis.Â TheyÂ alsoÂ warn against damaging alternatives,Â such as bio-based orÂ biodegradable plastics, which currently pose a threat similar to conventional plastics.Â The report looks at critical market failures, such as the low price of virgin fossil fuel feedstocksÂ (any renewable biological material that can be used directly as aÂ fuel)Â compared to recycled materials, disjointed efforts in informal and formal plastic waste management, and the lack of consensus on global solutions.Â Instead, the assessment calls for the immediate reductionÂ in plasticÂ productionÂ and consumption,Â and encourages a transformation across the whole value chain.Â It also asks forÂ investments in far more robust and effective monitoring systems to identify the sources, scale and fate of plastic. Ultimately, a shift to circular approachesÂ andÂ moreÂ alternativesÂ are necessary.Â Â For theÂ Executive Director of UNEP,Â Inger Andersen,Â this assessmentÂ â€œprovides the strongest scientific argument to date for the urgency to act, and for collective action to protect and restore our oceans,Â from source to sea.â€Â She said thatÂ aÂ major concern isÂ what happens withÂ breakdown products, such as microplastics and chemical additives, which are known to be toxicÂ and hazardous to human and wildlife health and ecosystems.Â â€œThe speed at which ocean plastic pollution is capturing public attention is encouraging.Â It is vital that weâ€¯use this momentum to focus on the opportunities for a clean, healthy and resilient oceanâ€, Ms. AndersenÂ argued.Â Â Currently, plastic accounts for 85 per cent ofÂ allÂ marine litter.Â By 2040,Â itÂ will nearly triple, adding 23-37 million metric tons of waste into the ocean per year. This means about 50kg of plastic per meter of coastline.Â Because of this, all marine life,Â from plankton and shellfish;Â to birds, turtles and mammals;Â faces the grave risk of toxification, behavioral disorder, starvation and suffocation.Â The human body is similarly vulnerable.Â Plastics are ingested through seafood, drinks and even common salt.Â TheyÂ alsoÂ penetrate the skin and are inhaled when suspended in the air.Â InÂ water sources, this type of pollution canÂ cause hormonal changes, developmental disorders, reproductive abnormalities andÂ evenÂ cancer.Â According to the report, there are alsoÂ significantÂ consequences forÂ the global economy.Â Globally, when accounting forÂ impacts on tourism, fisheries and aquaculture, together withÂ the price of projectsÂ such as clean-ups,Â the costsÂ were estimated to beÂ sixÂ toÂ 19 billionÂ dollarsÂ per year,Â duringÂ 2018.Â By 2040,Â there could be aÂ $100 billion annual financial risk for businesses if governments require them to cover waste management costs.Â ItÂ can also lead to a rise in illegal domestic and international waste disposal.Â The report will inform discussions at theÂ UN Environment AssemblyÂ in 2022, where countries will come together to decide a way forward forÂ moreÂ global cooperation.

title: 1.5 billionÂ people,Â living with soil too salty to be fertile
text: The information is part of theÂ Global Map of Salt-Affected Soils, aÂ newÂ tool launched this Wednesday by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO).Â Â These soilsÂ are less fertile and less productive,Â creatingÂ a threat to the global fight against hunger and poverty. They also reduce water quality and soilÂ biodiversity,Â andÂ increaseÂ soil erosion.Â With the new map, aÂ joint project involving 118 countries and hundreds of data-crunchers,Â FAO is hoping toÂ betterÂ inform policy makers when dealing with climate change adaptation and irrigation projects.Â The launch took place on the opening day of theÂ Global Symposium on Salt-Affected Soils, a three-day virtual conference gathering more than 5,000 expertsÂ which runs throughÂ Friday.Â Â Did you know soil is a living resource, home to more than 25% of our ğŸŒ's biodiversity?Soil biodiversity is key to global food security, we need to protect our soils! #SoilBiodiversity pic.twitter.com/unn5uV1HSVOpeningÂ the symposium, FAO Director-General, QUÂ Dongyu, said the world â€œmust look for innovative ways to transform our agri-food systems to be more efficient, more inclusive, more resilient and more sustainable.â€Â Â Saline or sodic soilsÂ occur naturally,Â andÂ are home toÂ valuable ecosystems, includingÂ a range of plants thatÂ have adapted to the saltyÂ conditions.Â In total, there are more than 833 million hectares of salt-affected soils around the globe, orÂ 8.7Â per centÂ of the planet. Most of them can be found in naturally arid or semi-arid environments in Africa, Asia and Latin America.Â Â ButÂ theyÂ can also be caused by human activity,Â due to mismanagement, excessive or inappropriate use of fertilisers, deforestation, sea level rises, a shallow water table which affects the rootzone, or seawater intrusion into groundwater that is then used for irrigation.Â At the same time, climate change is raising the stakes, with models suggesting that global drylands could expand by as much as 23 per cent, mostly in developing countries, by the end of the century.Â According to FAO, salinization (an increase in water-soluble salts) andÂ sodificationÂ (an increase in high sodium content) of soilsÂ isÂ among the most serious global threats to arid and semi-arid regions,Â but also for croplands in coastal regions and inÂ theÂ case of irrigation,Â with wastewater in any climate.Â Combating the problem requires a variety of tools, from raising awareness to adopting sustainable soil management practices, promoting technological innovation,Â to stronger political commitment.Â Healthy soils are a pre-requisite to achieve the United Nationsâ€™Â Sustainable Development GoalsÂ (SDGs)Â and form the basis ofÂ FAOâ€™s Four Betters:Â better production, better nutrition, a better environment, and a better life, leaving no one behind.Â The main objective of theÂ Global Symposium on Salt-Affected Soilsâ€¯is to share knowledge on salinity prevention, climate change and ecosystem restoration and to connect policy makers with food producers, scientists, and practitioners.â€¯Â The gathering will also feature a photo contest offering participants the opportunity to share their testimonies on the effects of soil salinity andÂ sodification.Â Â The event takes place ahead ofÂ World Soil DayÂ on December 5, which this year is dedicated to salt-affected soils with the motto,Â "Halt soil salinization, boost soil productivity".

title: Fossil fuel production â€˜dangerously out of syncâ€™ with climate change targets
text: Thatâ€™s according to the 2021Â Production Gap Report,Â released this WednesdayÂ by leading research institutes and the UN EnvironmentÂ ProgrammeÂ (UNEP).Over the next two decades, governments are projecting an increase in global oil and gas production, and only a modest decrease in coal production.Â Taken together,Â theseÂ plansÂ mean thatÂ fossil fuel productionÂ willÂ increaseÂ overall,Â to at least 2040.There is still time to limit long-term warming to 1.5Â°C but only just. At #COP26 govts. must take immediate steps to close the fossil fuel production gap & ensure a just and equitable transition. This is what climate ambition looks like.#ProductionGaphttps://t.co/aawuetAbzQForÂ Executive Director of UNEP,Â Inger Andersen,Â â€œthere is still time to limit long-term warming to 1.5Â°CÂ [above pre-industrial levels], but this window of opportunity is rapidly closing.â€Â Ms. Andersen said that at the UN Climate Conference,Â COP26, taking place inÂ early NovemberÂ in Glasgow, â€œgovernments must step up, taking rapid and immediate steps to close the fossil fuel production gap and ensure a just and equitable transition.â€Â â€œThis is what climate ambition looks likeâ€, she said.Â This yearâ€™sÂ report provides profiles for 15 major producer countries,Â showingÂ that mostÂ willÂ continue to support fossil fuel productionÂ growth.Reacting to the report,Â theÂ UN Secretary GeneralÂ highlighted recent announcements by the worldâ€™s largest economies to end financing of coal, calling them â€œa much-needed stepâ€Â in phasing out fossil fuels.ForÂ AntÃ³nio Guterres, though,Â the report shows thatÂ â€œthere is still a long way to go to a clean energy future.â€Â â€œIt is urgent that all remaining public financiers as well as private finance, including commercial banks and asset managers, switch their funding from coal toÂ renewables to promote full decarbonization of the power sector and access to renewable energy for allâ€, he said.CountriesÂ surveyedÂ plan to produce around 110Â per centÂ more fossil fuels in 2030 than would be consistent withÂ theÂ 1.5Â°CÂ limit, and 45Â per centÂ more thanÂ what would allow aÂ 2Â°CÂ heatingÂ impact.The report, first launched in 2019, measures the gap between governmentsâ€™ productionÂ plansÂ and the levels consistent with theÂ Paris Agreement.Â Two years later,Â the size of the gap has remained largely unchanged.CurrentÂ plans would lead to about 240Â per centÂ more coal, 57Â per centÂ more oil, and 71Â per centÂ more gasÂ productionÂ in 2030,Â than would be consistent with limiting global warming to 1.5Â°C.Global gasÂ outputÂ is projected to increase the most between 2020 and 2040, continuing a trend ofÂ long-term global expansionÂ inconsistent with the ParisÂ Agreement.Since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, countries have directed overÂ $300 billion in new funds towards fossil fuel activitiesÂ -Â more than they have towards clean energy.In contrast, international public finance for fossil fuels from G20 countries and major multilateral development banks has decreased. Currently,Â aÂ third ofÂ these banksÂ and G20 development finance institutions have adopted policies that exclude fossil fuelÂ production in the future.ForÂ lead author ofÂ the report,Â PloyÂ Achakulwisut, the research is clear:Â â€œGlobal coal, oil, and gas production must start declining immediately and steeply to be consistent with limiting long-term warming to 1.5Â°C.â€Â The report is produced by the Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI), International Institute for Sustainable Development (IISD), ODI, E3G, and UNEP.Â More than 80 researchers contributed to the analysis and review,Â includingÂ numerous universities, think tanks and other research organizations.

title: UNHCR responding to worst flooding in decades in South Sudan
text: Weeks of heavy rain have caused unrelenting floods, affecting more than 700,000 people across the country, UNHCR Representative in the country Arafat Jamal said on Tuesday. Â Â South Sudan is experiencing its worst floods in decades.Urgent #climateaction is needed to help rebuild and protect people's lives and livelihoods. pic.twitter.com/BnuzRPsbYcThe rains have swept away homes and inundated farmlands, forcing families to seek safety on higher ground or in neighbouring towns.Â Mr. Jamal said UNHCR teams in Upper Nile State alone, met around 1,000 people who had walked for seven days to reach Malakal, the state capital.Â â€œWomen, children, and elderly people arrived exhausted and hungry,â€ he told journalists at the weekly UN humanitarian briefing in Geneva. Â â€œSome had not eaten in days. Others are marooned on islands surrounded by water, sheltering under trees and unable to cross to safety. Women are deeply worried about the health of their children, with the increased risk of infections from deadly water-borne diseases.â€Â UNHCR and humanitarian partners are helping the South Sudanese authorities to deliver urgently needed support to the most affected people, including hygiene items, food, emergency shelter and solar lanterns to provide light.Â The floods have primarily affected four States. Â â€œIn some areas, communities have not seen flooding to this extent since 1962,â€ said Mr. Jamal, who is also the interim UN Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator in the country. Â Meanwhile, other areas have seen three years of consecutive flooding.Â Mr. Jamal said although the effects of the climate emergency are being felt on every continent, and in every region, East Africa has been profoundly affected.Â â€œCommunities, already struggling, are facing unprecedented floods and storms, unreliable rainfall, and distress under hotter and drier conditions as their basic needs and rights to water, food, livelihoods, land, and a healthy environment are hit hard.â€ Â His observations are in line with a report published on Tuesday by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and partners, which reveals how climate change contributed to mounting food insecurity, poverty and displacement in Africa during 2020.Â With rains in South Sudan expected to continue for the remainder of the year, Mr. Jamal said the number of people needing humanitarian aid is also expected to increase.Â Furthermore, climatic stresses can also provoke inter-communal conflict, he added. Â Flooding and drought sometimes occur within the same year, forcing communities to seek and share refuge in ever-shrinking patches of higher ground, while also trying to make up for lost income.Â â€œDialogue between host and displaced communities who share resources will continue to be essential,â€ he advised.Â Mr. Jamal pointed to an encouraging development, amidst the storm clouds, as the Government of South Sudan, one of the poorest nations in the world, has allocated $10 million to flood response efforts. Â Local governments are also working to address suffering, through efforts such as building dikes and installing systems to pump out flood waters, he said, while communities and displaced people â€œalso continue to show incredible resilience and generosity.â€

title: BusinessÂ leaders join UN chief to step upÂ action for sustainability
text:
TheÂ Global Investors for Sustainable Development (GISD) Alliance,Â which brings togetherÂ 30 business giants worthÂ an estimatedÂ $16 trillion,Â metÂ Mr. GuterresÂ inÂ New York, and outlinedÂ concrete actions for the future.Â Â Since October 2019, when the Secretary-General convened the GISD Alliance,Â its CEOsÂ and other top executives have beenÂ workingÂ with the UN and other partners to develop guidelines and products that align the existing finance and investment ecosystem,Â with theÂ Sustainable Development GoalsÂ (SDGs).Â Â 
â€œI count on the membersÂ of the GISD Alliance to catalyze greater investment for developing countries" - UN Secretary-GeneralÂ AntÃ³nio Guterres
Acknowledging theÂ â€œgreat responsibilityâ€ facing private sector leaders, Mr. Guterres said that the goals were clear: to â€œbuild a sustainable, net zero, resilient, and equitable world, toÂ better align investment with sustainable development,Â andÂ toÂ act onÂ theirÂ commitments, with credible timelines, targets and plansâ€.Â Since its creation, the GISD Allianceâ€¯hasÂ developedÂ standards and tools aimed at moving trillions of dollars to bridge the gap in financing, to realizeÂ the UNâ€™s 2030 Agenda.Â Â The groupÂ works throughÂ increasingÂ the available supply of long-term investment for sustainable development, realizingÂ SDG investment opportunities in developing countries,Â and enhancingÂ the impact of private investmentÂ forÂ sustainable development.Â Â â€œI count on the membersÂ of the GISD Alliance to catalyze greater investment for developing countries and make net zero and sustainability the core of everyoneâ€™s policies and business models.â€, Mr. Guterres continued.Â Â GISD alsoÂ sprangÂ into action to address crises, including in 2020, by developing aÂ COVID Bond Call to Action. The call prompted companies and governments to use innovative social bonds toÂ respond toÂ the pandemic, contributing to a sustainable economic recovery.Â Â This year, GISD published its latest investment tool designed to alignÂ financingÂ with the SDGs.Â ThroughÂ a set of sector-specific metrics, it proposes to accurately measure the impact of companies on sustainable developmentÂ targets,Â andÂ provide investors with key insights.Â This is an important step, since previous reporting frameworks would largely focus on measuring the impact of company operations on sustainability acrossÂ wholeÂ industries.Â Â According to Leila Fourie, GISD co-chair, and group CEO of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange,Â â€œindustry-agnostic performance indicators, while useful, tend to fall short in capturing the full sector-specific impact of products and services that companies produce.â€Â In the coming months, GISD will launch a net-zero Exchange Traded Fund (ETF) and a blended finance fund,Â helping theÂ â€œmove toward creating real lifeÂ opportunitiesâ€¯to finance the SDGsâ€,Â saidâ€¯Oliverâ€¯BÃ¤te, GISD Co-chair and CEO of Allianz.Â GISD isÂ alsoÂ working with the G20 Sustainable Finance Working Group, the COP26 climate conference bureau and G7Â leading economies, as well as engaging with the multilateral development banks, to develop actionable recommendations on ways to scale up private investment for sustainable development.

title: UN-backed report reveals rising climate change risk across Africa
text: The State of the Climate in Africa 2020 report highlights the continentâ€™s disproportionate vulnerability but also reveals how investing in climate adaptation, early warning systems, and weather and climate services, can pay off.Â #StateofClimate in #Africa Africa's remaining glaciers are of big scientific importance. They are expected to melt entirely by 2040s, signalling the "threat of imminent and irreversible change to the Earth system," says WMO Secretary-General Prof. Petteri Taalas.#ClimateAction pic.twitter.com/Rjz7LahOcaPetteri Taalas, the WMO Secretary-General, said the climate indicators in Africa during last year were characterized by continued warming temperatures, accelerating sea-level rise, extreme weather, and climate events - such as floods, landslides and droughts. Â â€œThe rapid shrinking of the last remaining glaciers in eastern Africa, which are expected to melt entirely in the near future, signals the threat of imminent and irreversible change to the Earth system,â€ he warned.Â Only three mountains in Africa are covered by glaciers: the Mount Kenya massif, the Rwenzori Mountains in Uganda, and Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania. Â Even though the glaciers are too small to act as significant water reservoirs, WMO underlined their touristic and scientific importance. Â Currently, their retreat rates are higher than the global average, and â€œtotal deglaciationâ€ could be possible by the 2040s.Â Mount Kenya is expected to be deglaciated a decade sooner, the agency added, which will make it one of the first entire mountain ranges to lose glacier cover due to human-induced climate change. Â The report is a collaboration between WMO, the African Union Commission, the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) through the Africa Climate Policy Centre (ACPC), UN agencies, and international and regional scientific organizations.Â It was issued during the extraordinary session of the WMO Congress currently underway online, and ahead of the COP26 UN climate change conference, which opens in Glasgow, Scotland, in less than two weeks.Â Increased weather and climate variability is disrupting lives and economies, said Josefa Leonel Correia Sacko, Commissioner for Rural Economy and Agriculture with the African Union Commission. Â Â Estimates reveal that by 2030, up to 118 million extremely poor people on the continent will be exposed to drought, floods and extreme heat, which will hinder progress towards poverty alleviation and growth.Â â€œIn sub-Saharan Africa, climate change could further lower gross domestic product (GDP) by up to 3%, by 2050,â€ she said. â€œThis presents a serious challenge for climate adaptation and resilience actions because not only are physical conditions getting worse, but also the number of people being affected is increasing.â€Â The report estimated that the investment in climate adaptation for sub-Saharan Africa would cost between $30 to $50 billion each year over the next decade, or roughly two to three per cent of GDP.Â The authors said rapid implementation of African adaptation strategies will spark economic development, as well as more jobs as part of post-pandemic recovery. Â Pursuing the priorities of an African Union green recovery plan would also allow for sustainable recovery as well as effective climate action.

title: The right to a healthy environment: 6 things you need to know
text: For the first time ever, the United Nations body whose mission is to promote and protect human rights around the world, passed a resolution recognising access to a healthy and sustainable environment as a universal right.The text also calls on countries to work together, and with other partners, to implement this breakthrough.â€œProfessionally that was probably the most thrilling experience that I ever have had or that I ever will have. It was a massive team victory. It took literally millions of people, and years and years of work to achieve this resolutionâ€, said David Boyd, UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights and Environment, who was in the room when President Nazhat Shameem from Fiji, brought down her gavel, announcing the voting results.43 votes in favour and 4 abstentions counted as a unanimous victory to pass the text that cites the efforts of at least 1,100 civil society, child, youth and indigenous peopleâ€™s organizations, who have been campaigning for global recognition, implementation and protection of the human right to a safe, clean, healthy and sustainable environment. Â A little bit of joyful emotion at the very staid Human Rights Council, as the UN for the first time recognizes the right to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment! (Mask was only off for a moment!) pic.twitter.com/8rUXJpz9z0But why is this recognition important, and what does it mean for climate change-affected communities?Here are six key things you need to know, compiled by us here at UN News.The Human Rights Council is an inter-governmental body within the United Nations system, responsible for strengthening the promotion and protection of human rights around the globe and for addressing situations of human rights violations and make recommendations on them.The Council is made up of 47 UN Member States which are elected by the absolute majority in the General Assembly and represent every region of the world.Human Rights Council resolutions are â€œpolitical expressionsâ€ that represent the position of the Councilâ€™s members (or the majority of them) on particular issues and situations. These documents are drafted and negotiated among States with to advance specific human rights issues.They usually provoke a debate among States, civil society and intergovernmental organisations; establish new â€˜standardsâ€™, lines or principles of conduct; or reflect existing rules of conduct.Resolutions are drafted by a â€œcore groupâ€: Costa Rica, the Maldives, Morocco, Slovenia and Switzerland, were the countries who brought resolution 48/13 for its adoption in the council, recognising for the first time that having a clean, healthy and sustainable environment is indeed a human right.In 1972, the United Nations Conference on the Environment in Stockholm, which ended with a historical declaration, was the first one to place environmental issues at the forefront of international concerns and marked the start of a dialogue between industrialized and developing countries on the link between economic growth, the pollution of the air, water and the ocean, and the well-being of people around the world.UN Member States back then, declared that people have a fundamental right to "an environment of a quality that permits a life of dignity and well-being," calling for concrete action. They called for both the Human Rights Council and the UN General Assembly to act.Since 2008, the Maldives, a Small Island Developing State on the frontline of climate change impacts, has been tabling a series of resolutions on human rights and climate change, and in the last decade, on human rights and environment.In the last few years, the work of the Maldives and its allied States, as well as the UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights and Environment and different NGOs, have been moving the international community towards the declaration of a new universal right.Support for UN recognition of this right grew during the COVID-19 pandemic. The idea was endorsed by UN's Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres and High Commissioner for Human Rights Michelle Bachelet, as well as more than 1,100 civil society organisations from around the world. Nearly 70 states on the Human Rights Council also added their voices to a call by the councilâ€™s core group on human rights and environment for such action, and 15 UN agencies also sent a rare joint declaration advocating for it.â€œA surge in emerging zoonotic diseases, the climate emergency, pervasive toxic pollution and a dramatic loss of biodiversity have brought the future of the planet to the top of the international agendaâ€, a group of UN experts said in a statement released in June this year, on World Environment Day.To finally reach the vote and decision, the core group lead intensive inter-governmental negotiations, discussions and even expertsâ€™ seminars, over the past few years.Levy Muwana, a Youth Advocate and environmentalist from Zambia, participated in one of the seminars.â€œAs a young child, I was affected with bilharzia, a parasitic disease, because I was playing in the dirty water near my household.A few years later, a girl died in my community from cholera. These events are sadly common and occurring more often.Water-born infectious diseases are increasing worldwide, especially across sub-Saharan Africa, due to the changing climateâ€, he told Council members last August.Muwana made clear that his story was not unique, as millions of children worldwide are significantly impacted by the devastating consequences of the environmental crisis. â€œ1.7 million of them die every year from inhaling contaminated air or drinking polluted waterâ€, he said.The activist, along with over 100.000 children and allies had signed a petition for the right to a healthy environment to be recognised, and they were finally heard.â€œThere are people who want to continue the process of exploiting the natural world and have no reservations about harming people to do that. So those very powerful opponents have kept this room from going forward for decades.It's almost like a David and Goliath story that all of these civil society organizations were able to overcome this powerful opposition, and now we have this new tool that we can use to fight for a more just and sustainable worldâ€, says David Boyd, the UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights and Environment.Mr. Boyd explains that the resolution should be a catalyst for more ambitious action on every single environmental issue that we face.â€œIt really is historic, and it really is meaningful for everyone because we know right now that 90% of people in the world are breathing polluted air.â€œSo right off the bat if we can use this resolution as a catalyst for actions to clean up air quality, then we're going to be improving the lives of billions of peopleâ€, he emphasizes.Human Rights Council resolutions might not be legally binding, but they do contain strong political commitments.â€œThe best example we have of what kind of a difference these UN resolutions make is if we look back at the resolutions in 2010 that for the first time recognized the right to water. That was a catalyst for governments all over the world who added the right to water to their constitutions, their highest and strongest lawsâ€, Mr. Boyd says.The Rapporteur cites Mexico, which after adding the right to water in the constitution, has now extended safe drinking water to over 1,000 rural communities.â€œThere are a billion people who can't just turn on the tap and have clean, safe water coming out, and so you know, for a thousand communities in rural Mexico, that's an absolutely life-changing improvement. Similarly, Slovenia, after they put the right to water in their constitution because of the UN resolutions, they then took action to bring safe drinking water to Roma communities living in informal settlements on city outskirtsâ€.According to the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), the recognition of the right to a healthy environment at the global level will support efforts to address environmental crises in a more coordinated, effective and non-discriminatory manner, help achieve the Sustainable Developing Goals, provide stronger protection of rights and of the people defending the environment, and help create a world where people can live in harmony with nature.Mr. Boyd has witnessed firsthand the devastating impact that climate change has already had on peopleâ€™s rights.In his first country mission as a Special Rapporteur, he met the first community in the world that had to be completely relocated due to rising sea levels, coastal erosion and increased intensity of storm surges.â€œYou know, from this beautiful waterfront paradise on a Fijian island, they had to move their whole village inland about three kilometers. Older persons, people with disabilities, pregnant women, they're now separated from the ocean that has sustained their culture and their livelihoods for many generationsâ€.These situations are not only seen in developing countries. Mr. Boyd also visited Norway where he met Sami indigenous people also facing the impacts of climate change.â€œI heard really sad stories there. For thousands of years their culture and their economy has been based on reindeer herding, but now because of warm weather in the winters, even in Norway, north of the Arctic Circle, sometimes it rains.â€œThe reindeer who literally for thousands of years had been able to scrape away snow during the winter to get to the lichens and mosses that sustained them, now can't scrape away the ice - and theyâ€™re starvingâ€.The story repeats itself in Kenya, where pastoralists are losing their livestock because of droughts that are being exacerbated by climate change.â€œThey have done nothing to cause this global crisis and theyâ€™re the ones who are suffering, and that's why it's such a human rights issue.â€œThat's why it's such an issue of justice. Wealthy countries and wealthy people need to start to pay for the pollution they've created so that we can help these vulnerable communities and these vulnerable peoples to adapt and to rebuild their livesâ€, Mr. Boyd said.The Council resolution includes an invitation to the UN General Assembly to also consider the matter. The Special Rapporteur says he is â€œcautiously optimisticâ€ that the body will pass a similar resolution within the next year.â€œWe need this. We need governments and we need everyone to move with a sense of urgency. I mean, we're living in a climate, biodiversity, and pollution crisis, and also a crisis of these emerging diseases like COVID which have environmental root causes. And so that's why this resolution is critically important because it says to every government in the world â€˜you have to put human rights at the centre of climate action, of conservation, of addressing pollution and of preventing future pandemicsâ€™â€.For Dr. Maria Neira, the World Health Organizationâ€™s (WHO) environment chief, the resolution is already having important repercussions and a mobilizing impact.â€œThe next step will be how we translate that on the right to clean air and whether we can push, for instance, for the recognition of WHOâ€™S Global Air Quality Guidelines and the levels of exposure to certain pollutants at a country level. It will also help us to move certain legislation and standards at the national levelâ€, she explains.Air pollution, primarily the result of burning fossil fuels, which also drives climate change, causes 13 deaths per minute worldwide. Dr. Neira calls for the end of this â€œabsurd fightâ€ against the ecosystems and environment.â€œAll the investments need to be on ensuring access to safe water and sanitation, on making sure that electrification is done with renewable energy and that our food systems are sustainable.â€According to WHO, achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement would save millions of lives every year due to improvements in air quality, diet, and physical activity, among other benefits.â€œThe climate emergency has become a matter of survival for many populations. Only systemic, profound and rapid changes will make it possible to respond to this global ecological crisis", says the Special Rapporteur.For Mr. Boyd, the approval of the historical resolution in the Human Rights Council was a â€˜paradoxicalâ€™ moment.â€œThere was this incredible sense of accomplishment and also at the exact same time a sense of how much work remains to be done to take these beautiful words and translate them into changes that will make people's lives better and make our society more sustainableâ€.The newly declared right to a healthy and clean environment will also hopefully influence positively negotiations during the upcoming UN Climate Conference COP26, in Glasgow, which has been described by the UN chief as the last chance to â€˜turn the tideâ€™ and end the war on our planet.

title: From the Field: Lao farmers serve up fish with rice
