What will you do? #EarthDay pic.twitter.com/5ph5lOAmOdThe country is also ranked the least peaceful globally, owing to longstanding conflict that has killed and injured thousands of people and displaced millions.Recurring floods and droughts â€“ along with population growth - have compounded food insecurity and water scarcity and reduced the prospects of refugees and IDPs being able to return to their home areas, UNHCR said.It pointed to indications that 16.9 million Afghans â€“ nearly half of the countryâ€™s population - lacked enough food in the first quarter of 2021, including at least 5.5 million facing emergency levels of food deprivation.As of mid-2020, more than 2.6 million Afghans were internally displaced and another 2.7 million were living as registered refugees in other countries, mainly Pakistan and Iran, according to UNHCR.Mozambique is experiencing a similar confluence of conflict and multiple disasters, says the agency, with one cyclone after another battering the countryâ€™s central region while increasing violence and turmoil to the north displaces hundreds of thousands of people.Many of the countries most exposed to the impacts of climate change are already host to large numbers of refugees and internally displaced.In Bangladesh, more than 870,000 Rohingya refugees who fled violence in Myanmar are now exposed to increasingly frequent and intense cyclones and flooding.Â â€œWe need to invest now in preparedness to mitigate future protection needs and prevent further climate caused displacement,â€ said UN High Commissioner for RefugeesÂ Filippo Grandi, earlier this year.

title: The planetâ€™s on â€˜red alertâ€™ UN chief warns leaders at President Bidenâ€™s climate summit
text: â€œMother Nature is not waitingâ€, the UN chief warned, as the past decade was the hottest on record, and the world continues to see rising sea-levels, scorching temperatures, devastating tropical cyclones and epic wildfires.Â We are at the verge of the abyss. We must ensure the next step is in the right direction.Itâ€™s time to mobilize political leadership & move ahead together â€“ to overcome climate change, end our war on nature & build lives of dignity & prosperity for all. https://t.co/1ukeUNYylhâ€œWe need a green planet â€” but the world is on red alert,â€ he said. Â â€œWe are at the verge of the abyss. Â We must make sure the next step is in the right direction. Â Leaders everywhere must take action.â€ Â The Secretary-General thanked President Biden for hosting the two-day Leaders Summit on Climate, and applauded US commitment to cut greenhouse gas emissions.Â In his introductory remarks, President Biden announced the country would slash emissions in half, by 2030. Â He spoke of the â€œextraordinary job creation and economic opportunityâ€ that climate response provides, proposing investments in sectors such as energy, transportation, construction and farming.Â President Biden acknowledged that no nation can solve the climate emergency alone, and he called for leaders of the worldâ€™s largest economies to â€œstep upâ€ in the race to a sustainable future.Â â€œScientists tell us that this is the decisive decade. Â This is the decade we must make decisions that will avoid the worst consequences of the climate crisis,â€ he said.Â Mr. Guterres used the Summit to amplify his call for a global coalition to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, and for countries to ramp up their commitments under the landmark Paris Agreement on climate change. Â The 2015 treaty aims to limit global temperature rise to below 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, and requires governments to commit to increasingly ambitious climate action through plans known as Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs).Â â€œAll countries â€“ starting with major emitters â€“ should submit new and more ambitious Nationally Determined Contributions for mitigation, adaptation and finance, laying out actions and policies for the next 10 years aligned with a 2050 net-zero pathwayâ€, he said.Â These commitments also must be translated into â€œconcrete, immediate actionâ€, he added, as it is estimated that less than a quarter of pandemic recovery spending will go towards mitigating emissions, reducing air pollution or strengthening natural capital. Â â€œThe trillions of dollars needed for COVID-19 recovery is money we are borrowing from future generations.â€¯â€¯We cannot use these resources to lock in policies that burden them with a mountain of debt on a broken planet.â€Â The UN chief appealed for leaders to â€œput a price on carbonâ€ through taxation. Â He called for ending subsidies for fossil fuels and instead, ramping up investment in renewable energy and green infrastructure.â€¯Â â€œStop the financing of coal and the building of new coal power plants. Phase out coal by 2030 in the wealthiest countries, and by 2040 everywhere else.â€¯Â Ensure a just transition for affected people and communitiesâ€, he said.Â Building the global net zero coalition will require a breakthrough in both finance and adaption, the Secretary-General said. Â He urged donors, as well as banks, to move from 20 to 50 per cent in all climate finance flows to resilience and adaptation.Â â€œBefore the United Nations climate conference in November in Glasgow, we need concrete proposals that ease access to greater finance and technological support for the most vulnerable countries,â€ he added.Â â€œDeveloped States must deliver on public climate finance, including the long-promised US $100 billion for climate action in developing countries, at the G7 Summit in June.â€Â Growing dangerÂ The head of the UN climate convention body (UNFCCC) Patricia Espinosa, issued a statement on the Summit, noting that the global climate change emergency was â€œa clear, present and growing danger to all people on this planet.Â â€œIt recognizes no borders and while nations may be impacted differently, none are immuneâ€, she said. â€œThis is a time for leadership, courage and solidarity by global leaders; a time they must make the tough decisions necessary to finally fulfill the promises of the Paris Agreement and move the world away from disaster and towards an unprecedented era of growth, prosperity and hope for all.

title: First Person: â€˜Youth wonâ€™t stay silentâ€™ says Madagascar climate activist
text: MarieÂ ChristinaÂ Kolo, who describes herself as a climate activist, ecofeminist and social entrepreneur,Â was one of two young peopleÂ whoÂ spoke to the UN Secretary-General, AntÃ³nio GuterresÂ ahead ofÂ International MotherÂ EarthÂ DayÂ marked annually on 22 April.Â Â SheÂ expressedÂ herÂ concerns,Â aboutÂ theÂ dualÂ impactÂ on the IndianÂ Ocean islandÂ of the COVID-19 pandemic and the ongoingÂ climate crisis:Â Â â€œClimate change didnâ€™t stop with COVID-19Â and thatâ€™s true of myÂ country, Madagascar.Â The current pandemic has taught us lessons".Â Â The first one is that global trade requires global cooperation. In developing countries like mine, we were able to receive lots of donationsÂ andÂ support from the international community. It was also a good opportunity for us to prove again, our traditional solidarity and solidarity among countries.Â Â However,Â the questionÂ we faceÂ isÂ how can we promoteÂ healthy water and sanitationÂ initiativesÂ like handwashing,Â which play a part in defeating the virusÂ when three out of four peopleÂ in MadagascarÂ donâ€™t have access toÂ cleanÂ water and sanitationÂ services?Â Â How can you promoteÂ these initiativesÂ when there are droughts and floodsÂ which areÂ related to climate change?Â Â So,Â we need to focus onÂ climate actionsÂ thatÂ are relevant in terms of increasing access to water, for example,Â rehabilitatingÂ wetlandÂ areas.Â We need to learn how to focus on climate-smart agriculture. We need to learn how to be self-sufficient in food production, to depend less on tourism and trade.Â Â The second lesson for me is important as well.Â When we think about support, we need to consider climate change adaptation and resilience. Health is one of the key areas of adaptation, so itâ€™s a perfect time to invest in health infrastructureÂ andÂ in human resources.Â Â COVID-19 also disruptedÂ the supply chain, so thatâ€™s another area for countries like mine to consider.Â Last but not the least, COVID-19 relief and recoveryÂ investmentÂ must address theÂ disproportionate ways in which women and other marginalized populations have been affected.Â Â I think my countryâ€™s biodiversity has been put at risk during the pandemic, because,Â you know, in this context,Â whereÂ people are suffering from poverty, they go to the forest to just find a way of living.Â Â HereÂ most ofÂ the poorest people, depend on natural resources;Â 80 per cent of the populationÂ of MadagascarÂ live in rural areas.Â They only think about their daily life;Â they can bring food to their familiesÂ from the forest.Â So, when you talk about biodiversity in this pandemic,Â we are looking at a crisis in terms of protecting ourÂ natural habitat.Â At thisÂ time of crisis, itâ€™s really a big challenge for us to mobilize, to bring awareness toÂ peopleÂ thatÂ we need to protectÂ these natural resources,Â thatÂ we need to find a balanceÂ between ourÂ livelihoodsÂ and protecting the natural world.Â I keep saying thatÂ Iâ€™m optimisticÂ because more and more young people are trying to promote a greener economy, and to prove that we donâ€™t need to exploit these natural resources too much.Â I want to say thatÂ theÂ youth wonâ€™t stay silent, we have a voice, and we will be heardÂ and thatÂ we need to be included in decision-making. We need to do it first at the national level.Â We can workÂ together,Â we can share best practices.Â Â Â So,Â I take this opportunityÂ toÂ call on all the youth movements around the world to workÂ together to bring change.

title: Commit to restoring the planet, UN chief says in message for International Mother Earth Day
text: This yearâ€™s observation is taking place as the planet is at â€œa tipping pointâ€, he said, as humanity continues to abuse the natural world.Â â€œWe heedlessly plunder the Earthâ€™s resources, deplete its wildlife and treat air, land and seas as dumping grounds. Crucial ecosystems and food chains are being pushed to the brink of collapseâ€, the UN chief stated.Â â€œThis is suicidal. We must end our war on nature and nurse it back to healthâ€.Â The Secretary-General said ending this war calls for â€œbold climate actionâ€ to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Â Stronger steps to protect biodiversity, and reducing pollution and waste, are also needed.Â Mr. Guterres assured that these steps will not only safeguard the planet, â€œour only homeâ€, but will also create millions of new jobs.Â â€œRecovery from the COVID-19 pandemic is a chance to set the world on a cleaner, greener, more sustainable pathâ€, the Secretary-General said.Â â€œOn International Mother Earth Day, let us all commit to the hard work of restoring our planet and making peace with natureâ€.Â For the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), the International Day highlights the need to shift to a more sustainable economy that benefits both people and the planet.Â â€œMother Earth is clearly urging a call to actionâ€, the agency said. â€œNature is suffering. Australian fires, heat records and the worst locust invasion in Kenya. Now we face COVID-19, a worldwide health pandemic link to the health of our ecosystemâ€.Â UNEP has developed a Climate Action Note, which provides data showing global progress towards meeting the goals of the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change, signed by more than 190 countries.Â â€œAs the climate emergency intensifies, the transition towards climate stability becomes increasingly critical. Progress will depend on countries and their ability to cover ground on their commitments under the Paris Agreement and eventually, their collective contributions to keep the global average temperature well below 2Â°C.â€

title: ILO kicks off Green Week to â€˜jump-startâ€™ a sustainable future
text: The International Labour Organization event highlighted how a justÂ  transition towards environmentally sustainable economies and societies can take place while also addressing the imperatives of decent work.Â For a sustainable future, the UN agency stressed the need for a â€œstrong social consensusâ€ on the goals and pathways to move forward, maintaining that social dialogue must be an integral part of institutional frameworks for policymakers, with the inclusion of workers and employers being critical for an equitable transition at all levels.Â If we want to advocate for people and planet, #GreenJobs are key. For @ilo's #ILOGreenWeek join innovators, experts and environmental leaders from around the globe to explore what a green future of work could look like, and how we can get thereğŸŒ±â€“ https://t.co/no7zto98z6 pic.twitter.com/UdvjdM6K0Vâ€œWorking together, Governments, workersâ€™ and employersâ€™ organizations can jump-start a just transition to a sustainable future, todayâ€, said ILO.Â Although Africa generates a low share of global carbon emissions, the continent is highly vulnerable to climate change.Â According to ILO, global warming and heat stress will lead to the loss of nearly five per cent of total working hours in western Africa alone â€“ equivalent to losing nine million full-time jobs.Â Climate vulnerability could also reduce yields from rain-fed agriculture, affecting millions of jobs and livelihoods.Â Â Rich in minerals, such as lithium, nickel, cobalt, copper and iron - needed for electric vehicles and machinery, the continent has all the elements needed to â€œwin the battle against climate changeâ€, along with the potential to generate some two million additional jobs, ILO said.Â Africa is home to the Congo Basin, the worldâ€™s second largest rain forest, which absorbs significant amounts of global carbon dioxide emissions caused by human activity and possess 60 per cent of the worldâ€™s arable land, which, the UN agency pointed out â€œcould drive a new green, sustainable agricultural revolutionâ€.Â Â Moreover, it is home to the Great Green Wall â€“ the worldâ€™s largest solar power station, located in the Moroccan desert â€“ and has the potential to use its ocean resources for sustainable economic development.Â Â â€œWith assets like these, Africa can have a more sustainable future, with more and better jobsâ€, ILO said, while also cautioning that as a leading producer of oil, coal and natural gas, it must end its dependence on fossil fuels, which could lead to the loss of some two million jobs.Â In the context of Green Week and this yearâ€™s Earth Day, ILO and its partners hosted a regional launch of the Climate Action for Jobs Initiative to showcase how jobs feature at the heart of global action to protect the environment and promote climate-neutral and climate-resilient economies and societies.Â Â Countries need to adopt clear and comprehensive policies that address income and job losses, skills and enterprise development, and labour mobility to achieve a â€œhuman-centred future of work in Africaâ€, said ILO.Â With its young and dynamic population, vast natural resources, and political and social engagement, the UN agency upheld that â€œAfrica offers solutions to the worldâ€.Â Â Â â€œThere is indeed an urgent need to put African young people and women as agents of change, to drive innovation and green job creationâ€, CynthiaÂ Samuel-Olonjuwon, ILO Assistant Director-General and Regional Director for Africa, said at the event.

title: Ocean benefits increasingly undermined by human activity, UN assessment reveals
text: The second World Ocean Assessment (WOA II) is the work of hundreds of scientists from across the globe and follows an initial report published in 2015. Â It warns that many benefits the ocean provides are increasingly being undermined by human actions, the UN chief said, describing the findings as alarming.Â â€œPressures from many human activities continue to degrade the ocean and destroy essential habitats â€“ such as mangrove forests and coral reefs â€“ hindering their capacity to help address climate change impactsâ€, Mr. Guterres said in a video message.Â â€œThese pressures also come from human activities on land and coastal areas, which bring dangerous pollutants into the ocean, including plastic waste. Meanwhile, overfishing is estimated to have led to an annual loss of $88.9 billion in net benefitsâ€.Â The Secretary-General added that carbon released into the atmosphere is driving ocean warming and acidification, which have destroyed biodiversity. At the same time, sea level rise is threatening the worldâ€™s coastlines.Â Mr. Guterres reported that the number of â€˜dead zonesâ€™ in the ocean has nearly doubled, increasing from more than 400 globally in 2008 to about 700 in 2019. Â Around 90 per cent of mangrove, seagrass and marsh plant species, as well as more than 30 per cent of seabird species, are also facing the threat of extinction.Â â€œThe experts attribute this to our general failure to achieve integrated sustainableÂ management of coasts and the oceanâ€, he said. Â â€œI urge all stakeholders to heed this and other warnings. Better understanding of the ocean is essentialâ€.Â With the pandemic showing how human health and the health of the planet are linked, Mr. Guterres called for transforming our relationship with nature in efforts to recover better, achieve sustainable development and keep global temperature rise to the 1.5-degree Celsius target of the Paris Agreement on climate change.Â â€œAs the Assessment makes clear, ocean sustainability depends on us all workingÂ together â€“ including through joint research, capacity development and the sharing of data, information and technology. Â We also need to better integrate scientific knowledge and policy-makingâ€, he said.Â This year marked the start of the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development, which the Secretary-General said provides a framework for collective action to achieve this goal.Â â€œThe findings of this Assessment underscore the urgency of ambitious outcomes in this yearâ€™s UN biodiversity, climate and other high-level summits and eventsâ€, he added.Â â€œTogether, we can foster not only a green â€“ but also a blue â€“ recovery from theÂ COVID-19 pandemic, and help ensure a long term resilient and sustainableÂ relationship with the oceanâ€.

title: World on the verge of climate â€˜abyssâ€™, as temperature rise continues: UN chief
text: According to the World Meteorological Organizationâ€™s (WMO) flagship State of the Global Climate report, the global average temperature in 2020 was about 1.2-degree Celsius above pre-industrial level.State of Global Climate 2020:#COVID19 combined with extreme weather in a double blow for millions but failed to put a brake on #climatechange and accelerating impacts.â¬†ï¸ CO2ğŸŒ¡ï¸temperatures ğŸŒŠ heat and acidificationâ¬‡ï¸ ice and glaciersğŸŒ¡ï¸https://t.co/MqpKp7KthJ#ClimateAction pic.twitter.com/fBfgodpI3EThat figure is â€œdangerously closeâ€ to the 1.5-degree Celsius limit advocated by scientists to stave off the worst impacts of climate change.The six years since 2015, have been the warmest on record, and the decade beginning up to this year, was the warmest ever.â€œWe are on the verge of the abyssâ€, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said at a press conference announcing the findings.The stark warning from WMO comes ahead of the virtual Leaders Summit on Climate this week, convened by United States President Joe Biden, to galvanize efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and meet the targets of the historic 2015 Paris Agreement, agreed by all the nations of the world.The UN chief underscored that 2021, â€œmust be the year for actionâ€, calling for a number of â€œconcrete advancesâ€, before countries gather in Glasgow in November, for COP26 â€“ the 26th session of Conference of the Parties (COP26) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).â€œCountries need to submit ambitious new nationally determined contributions (NDCs) that were designed by the Paris Agreement. Their climate plans for the next 10 years must be much more efficient.â€He also urged that climate commitments and plans must be backed with immediate action, and that the trillions of dollars invested by mostly richer nations for domestic COVID-19 recovery, be aligned with the Paris Agreement on climate change and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and that subsidies directed to fossil fuels be shifted to renewable energy.â€œDeveloped countries must lead in phasing out coal â€“ by 2030 in OECD countries, and 2040 elsewhere. No new coal power plants should be builtâ€, Mr. Guterres stressed.The State of the Global Climate report also noted how climate change undermines sustainable development efforts, through a cascading chain of interrelated events that can worsen existing inequalities, as well as raise the potential for feedback loops, perpetuating the deteriorating cycle of climate change.Petteri Taalas, WMO Secretary-Secretary, cautioned that the â€œnegative trendâ€ in climate could continue for the coming decades independent of mitigation efforts, calling for greater investments in adaptation.â€œThe report shows that we have not time to waste. The climate is changing, and the impacts are already too costly for people and the planet. This is the year for actionâ€, he said, calling for all countries to commit to zero emissions by 2050.â€œOne of the most powerful ways to adapt is to invest in early warning services and weather observing networks. Several less developed countries have major gaps in their observing systems and are lacking state-of-the-art weather, climate and water servicesâ€, he highlighted.Amongst its findings, the 2020 WMO report noted that concentrations of the major greenhouse gases continued to increase in 2019 and 2020, with global average for carbon dioxide concentrations having already exceeded 410 parts per million (ppm), with a further warning that if the concentration follows the same pattern as in previous years, it could reach or exceed 414 ppm this year.WMO also noted that ocean acidification and deoxygenation continued, impacting ecosystems, marine life and fisheries, as well as reducing its capacity to absorb CO2 from the atmosphere.Â Furthermore, 2019 saw the highest ocean heat level on record, and the trend likely continued in 2020, as did the global mean sea-level rise.The report also said that the since the mid-1980s, Arctic air surface temperatures have warmed at least twice as fast as the global average, with â€œpotentially large implicationsâ€ not only for Arctic ecosystems but also for the global climate, such as thawing permafrost releasing methane, a potent greenhouse gas into the atmosphere.In addition, record low Arctic sea-ice extent were observed in the months of July and October 2020, while the Greenland ice sheet lost approximately 152 gigatonnes of ice, between September 2019 and August 2020.Extreme weather events were also recorded in several locations globally, with heavy rains and floods, severe and long-term droughts, disastrous storms, and widespread and prolonged wildfires, such as in the US and Australia.

title: Green transformation will rival industrial revolution: US climate envoy
text:
Mr. Kerry expressed the view in a discussion with Kristalina Georgieva, the head of the International Monetary Fund as part of the 2021 Spring meetings of the IMF and World Bank.They agreed that a â€œgreen and resilient recoveryâ€ from the COVID-19 pandemic is possible but economic growth globally is likely to be slow and uneven.John Kerry: There are many ways that we can address the climate challenge in America. President Biden has put a $2 trillion plan on the table, which will result in 500,000 charging stations for electric vehicles being built in the country, thousands of electric buses, including school buses, and a target of 100 per cent carbon-free power, by 2035.All these measures will generate actions in the private sector. The decisions of some of the largest financial institutions in the world are being driven by environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors, and trillions of dollars is going to be invested in this new sector to avoid sheer catastrophe. We're way behind, but we believe that this is going to be the biggest economic transformation since the industrial revolution.In Europe, no bank or financial institution or even private source will fund a coal-fired power plant, but we have to move away from coal faster. Many old coal-fired plants are operating at less than 50 per cent efficiency. They are losing money and are not even sending energy to the main grid. They could be phased out over a period of time. Gas will, to some degree, be a bridge fuel [to renewables].The United States could help mobilize finance to reduce risk, and then bring more money to the table for a commercial investment in alternative fuel sources.Kristalina Georgieva: At the IMF we have identified three pillars in the transition to a low-carbon economy. First of all, put a price on all carbon emissions. Today only 23 per cent of emissions are being priced. The average price is $2 per ton. By 2030, we need to be at $75 a ton.Carbon Pricing is seen as the most cost-effective and flexible way to curb greenhouse gas emissions. The cost of carbon is calculated according to its cost to society, in land lost to rising sea levels, crop damage resulting from changing rainfall patterns, or health costs associated with heat waves and droughts. Under this scheme, responsibility of paying for the damages of climate is shifted from the public to the producers of greenhouse gas emissions. This provides a strong financial case for shifting investments away from high-emission fossil-fuels based technology towards cleaner technology.Second, funding is needed for public investment in green infrastructure. The IMF can support countries in this regard. Five per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) invested now, would generate an additional 0.7 per cent growth every year. This means that the investment would pay for itself within 15 years and create at least 12 million net jobs.The third, hugely important pillar, is to lessen the impact on those who are currently employed in the high carbon economy. For example, there must be a just transition for miners, so that they can have benefit from new job opportunities. If we raise revenues from carbon pricing, some of that money must be used to provide a buffer, to soften the pressure on those businesses that need to move away from carbon dependency. This is doable, and it must be done.John Kerry : Right now, China is saying that they are going to reach peak emissions by 2030, and that they may be able to reach that target earlier, maybe by 2025. The problem is that the current models shows China peaking but then basically staying at a plateau, rather than sufficiently lowering emissions.Some 30 per cent of all the emissions on the planet are produced by China, so if we don't see a reduction between 2020 and 2030, we lose the capacity to keep the global temperature to 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels, and we lose the capacity to hit net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.Every nation must work together on this. If the United States went to zero emissions tomorrow, it wouldn't make the kind of difference we need because we all have to reduce at the same time. That's the struggle weâ€™re facing.China obviously has a need to continue to grow and to develop. We want that, and we're not begrudging that. We want to work with China and other countries to make sure that they donâ€™t make the mistakes that we made, and that we work together to develop new technologies such as hydrogen fuel, and biofuels for aircraft.John Kerry: The United States is the number two emitter in the world. We need to do a better job at reducing emissions on an accelerated basis. President Biden is stepping up to do that.Â  He's hosting a virtual climate summit in April, he has rejoined the Paris climate agreement, and he has put together a $2 trillion piece of infrastructure legislation.Climate action means jobs, whether in the creation of new energy sources, or transitioning out of the existing ones, building new cars or retrofitting homes. Those are jobs for workers in all countries. We should embrace this.The economists have warned us again and again: doing nothing is more expensive to our citizens, our taxpayers, than responding to the climate crisis. We spent $365 billion cleaning up after three storms a couple of years ago, but we haven't invested the $100 billion in the Green Climate Fund that would have provided resilience and adaptation to climate change, and prevented some of that damage from being done. We're just not making the right choices.Kristalina Georgieva:Â  Weâ€™ve already started offering a helping hand, especially to countries devastated by natural disasters.Â  We have put measures in place to help countries to be in a better position when disaster hits. For example, we are discussing with our membership a provision that will make $650 billion available for countries to not only take the necessary measures to deal with the pandemic and its impact, but also to take on the investments necessary for transformation of their economy.The urgency to act is evident, and vivid: over the last six months, 10 million people were displaced by floods and other forms of natural disasters. Fast-forward to a world in which there are more climate-related disasters, and more migration.
We have a chance to take advantage of a transformation for growth and for jobs. But we are also under tremendous pressure to prevent a future that would be bleak for those we love the most: our children and grandchildren.

title: Guterres urges cities to embrace â€˜generational opportunityâ€™ for climate action, sustainable development
text: Addressing the C40 Mayors Climate Alliance, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres highlighted the that cities and urban centres are â€œon the frontlinesâ€ of the climate crisis, emitting more than 70 per cent of global greenhouse gases as well as facing risks ranging from rising sea levels to deadly storms.Â But cities can also boost climate action, clean energy and sustainable development, through more effective strategies and policies, especially as they recover from the impacts of the coronavirus pandemic, he added.â€œInvestment in recovery is a generational opportunity to put climate action, clean energy and sustainable development at the heart of citiesâ€™ strategies and policiesâ€, Mr. Gtuerres said.Â â€œHow we design power generation, transport and buildings in cities â€“ how we design the cities themselves â€“ will be decisive in getting on track to achieve the Paris Agreement on climate change and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).â€Â The UN chief called for urgent action in three key areas, urging Mayors to work with national leaders to develop and present ambitious Nationally Determined Contributions or NDCs, well before the 26th session of Conference of the Parties (COP26) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), this November in Glasgow.â€œThey need to hear from you that climate action coupled with policies for a just transition brings decent work and higher living standards and is supported by your residentsâ€, he said.Mr. Guterres also called on the local leaders to commit their cities to net-zero by 2050, make ambitious plans for the next decade.He also urged them use the recovery from the coronavirus pandemic to accelerate investment and implementation in clean, green infrastructure and transport systems.The Secretary-General also highlighted the importance of ending the use of coal as the â€œsingle most important stepâ€ the world can take to ensure temperature rise is limited to 1.5 degree Celsius.â€œCities stand to gain most from phasing out coal: clean air, green outdoor spaces, healthier peopleâ€, he said, calling for at least 80 per cent of power generation in cities from renewable energy sources by 2030.Mr. Guterres also noted that innovations urban transport and urban planning, would further help cut emissions and improve wellbeing. He also highlighted the importance of financial resources for cities to address gaps in the investments needed to drive such efforts.

title: UN atomic energy agency to work with Japan on Fukushima water disposal
text: IAEA Director General Rafael Mariano Grossi said that Japanâ€™s solution wasÂ both â€œtechnically feasible and in line with international practiceâ€ â€“ and thatÂ the agency was also ready â€œto provide technical support in monitoring and reviewing the planâ€™s safe and transparent implementationâ€.Controlled water discharges into the sea are routine practice for operating nuclear power plants in the world after safety and environmental impact assessments, the IAEA chief explained.IAEA ready to support Japan on #Fukushima water disposal, Director General @RafaelMGrossi says.ğŸ“ https://t.co/kAQGjQVfDB pic.twitter.com/zRYlLZgkg3â€œTodayâ€™s decision by the Government of Japan is a milestone that will help pave the way for continued progress in the decommissioning of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant,â€ Mr Grossi said, while also underlining that â€œthe large amount of waterâ€ at Fukushima made this a â€œunique and complex caseâ€.He added: â€œTanks with the water occupy large areas of the site, and water management, including the disposal of the treated water in a safe and transparent manner involving all stakeholders, is of key importance for the sustainability of these decommissioning activities.â€According to reports, Japan plans to start releasing the 1.25 million tonnes of treated seawater into the Pacific Ocean in two years, but only after it has been filtered and stripped of most radioactive material.These include radioactive isotopes strontium and cesium but not tritium, which is linked to hydrogen and said to pose little health risk in low concentrations.However, ChinaÂ and South Korea have publicly denounced the move, along with environmental group Greenpeace Japan, which described the Japanese Governmentâ€™s decision as â€œwholly unjustifiedâ€. Greenpeace argues that radiation hazards would be better contained by storing and processing the water of the longer term.Releasing all the treated seawater will take three decades.It comes 11 years after a deadly tsunami flooded the reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant, leading to a number of explosions and forcing the evacuation of more than 60,000 people.â€œWe will work closely with Japan before, during and after the discharge of the water,â€ said IAEA Director General Grossi, who visited the Fukushima nuclear power plant last year.â€œOur cooperation and our presence will help build confidence â€“ in Japan and beyond â€“ that the water disposal is carried out without an adverse impact on human health and the environment.â€

title: FROM THE FIELD: Solar energy powers COVID-19 treatment
text: Formerly dependent on costly and polluting diesel generators, which often do not provide sufficient electricity, over 900 health facilities, mainly in Sub-Saharan Â Africa, have been provided with equipment such as solar rooftops and batteries. It has given them access to clean, affordable and reliable electricity, while saving money which can be re-invested in health services.The health facilities benefiting from the UN Development Programme-supported Solar for Health initiative are making a positive contribution to the vaccine rollouts in their countries: COVID-19 vaccines need to be stored securely at low temperatures, something that can only be achieved where there is a low risk of power cuts.Read more here about how vulnerable communities are staying healthier thanks to solar technologies.

title: Paris goals still â€˜long way offâ€™, says President of UN climate conference
text: British politician Alok Sharma was speaking during a global discussion on the â€˜greenâ€™ transition in sectors such as energy, transport and food systems, held as part of the 2021 Spring Meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).Â â€œOceans are warming, storms are intensifying, and yet we are a long way off meeting the goals of the Paris Agreementâ€, he told the virtual meeting. Â â€œUnless we act now, the human, economic and environmental cost will dwarf anything that humanity has seen before.â€ Â COP26, which will be held this November in Glasgow, Scotland, aims to accelerate action towards the Paris treaty goals, which centre around limiting global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels by curbing greenhouse gas emissions. Â Â John Kerry, US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate, called the conference â€œthe last best opportunity we have to get real and serious.â€ He particularly urged developed countries to step up efforts to reduce emissions.Â â€œIt is essential we raise ambition; we make Glasgow the next step in defining not what weâ€™re willing to do but what we really need to do in order to be able to get the job done.â€Â For Prince William, the Duke of Cambridge, COP26 represents an opportunity to put nature at the heart of the climate fight. Â He called for banks to invest in nature,Â noting that spending so far has been minimal.Â Â â€œWe cannot recover sustainably from coronavirus, eradicate global poverty, achieve net-zero emissions, or adapt to climate change, without investing in natureâ€, he said.Â Energy access must also be part of the green transition, according to Damilola Ogunbiyi, Chief Executive Officer at Sustainable Energy for All (SEforALL), a UN partner. Â Â Globally, nearly 800 million people do not have access to electricity, while 2.8 billion lack access to clean cooking sources, she said, which is equivalent to the populations of Africa, Europe and China combined.Â To change their lives, she recommended that governments focus on policies in the areas ofÂ promoting renewable and sustainable energy, and on ease of doing business and regulations. Again, financing here is needed, together with commitment.Â â€œWe all see that globally, when we come together, just the amazing work we can do, and the COVID vaccine is a perfect exampleâ€, said Ms. Ogunbiyi, who is also the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General for Sustainable Energy for All.Â â€œWe literally have to have a COVID vaccine response to help a lot of developing countries because itâ€™s not that they donâ€™t want to transition, or they donâ€™t want to do the right thing. Itâ€™s a fact that if you do need to transition, there is a lot of funding that is needed.

title: New project to help 30 developing countries tackle marine litter scourge
text: The GloLitter Partnerships Project will supportÂ  30 developing countries in preventing and reducing marine litter from the maritime transport and fisheries sectors, which includes plastic litter such as lost or discarded fishing gear.Â ğŸ”µ 30 countries partner with @FAO and @IMOHQ in a major initiative to tackle marine litter and clean up the world's oceans.ğŸ‘‰ https://t.co/N74emFuY99 #MarinePlastic https://t.co/cFdrcdimjcThe project was launched on Thursday by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the International Maritime Organization (IMO), with initial funding from Norway.Â â€œPlastic litter has a devastating impact on marine life and human health", said Manuel Barange, FAO's Director of Fisheries and Aquaculture. Â â€œThis initiative is an important step in tackling the issue and will help protect the ocean ecosystem as well as the livelihoods of those who depend on it.â€Â Protecting the marine environment is the objective of Sustainable Development Goal 14, part of the 2030 Agenda to create a more just and equitable future for all people and the planet.Â The GloLitter project will help countries apply best practices for the prevention and reduction of marine plastic litter, in an effort to safeguard the worldâ€™s coastal and marine resources.Â Actions will include encouraging fishing gear to be marked so that it can be traced if lost or discarded at sea. Another focus will be on the availability and adequacy of port reception facilities and their connection to national waste management systems. Â "Marine litter is a scourge on the oceans and on the planetâ€, said Jose Matheickal, Head of the IMO's Department for Partnerships and Projects. â€œI am delighted that we have more than 30 countries committed to this initiative and working with IMO and FAO to address this issue.â€Â The nations taking part in the GloLitter project are in Asia, Africa, the Caribbean, Latin America and the Pacific.Â They will also receive technical assistance and training, as well as guidance documents and other tools to help enforce existing regulations.Â The project will promote compliance with relevant international instruments, including the Voluntary Guidelines for the Marking of Fishing Gear, and the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL), which contains regulations against discharging plastics into the sea.

title: Renewable energy access key to climate adaptation in Africa: UN chief
text: â€œAs the continent that has contributed least to the climate crisis, Africa deserves the strongest possible support and solidarityâ€, he told an online dialogue for leaders convened by the African Development Bank.Mr. Guterres warned that â€œadaptation must not be the neglected half of the climate equationâ€.Although Africa has abundant and untapped renewable resources, it has received just two per cent of global investment in renewable energy over the past decade, he reported.Old models of development and energy use have failed to provide Africans with universal energy access, he said, meaning hundreds of millions of people still lack reliable and affordable electricity or are cooking with polluting and harmful fuels.â€œWe can provide universal access to energy in Africa primarily through renewable energy. I call for a comprehensive package of support to meet this objective ahead of COP26,â€ Mr. Guterres said, referring to the UN climate change conference in November.â€œIt is achievable. It is necessary. It is overdue. And it is smart: climate action is a $3 trillion investment opportunity in Africa by 2030," he added.However, the Secretary-General pointed to â€œthe major financeâ€ gap blocking progress towards this goal. He urged developed countries to deliver on their $100 billion climate commitment made over a decade ago.â€œDeveloped countries and main financers must ensure a swift shift of the billions to support African green investments, to increase resilience and to create the conditions for scaled-up private financeâ€, he said.â€œAnd the private sector must step up and get organized to provide immediate, concrete solutions to governments. Local authorities can work with unions and community leaders on reskilling and social security nets.â€While African Governments also can lead the way by committing to ambitious adaptation and mitigation plans, they first need to regain their fiscal autonomy, he said.The Secretary-General stressed the need to extend the debt moratorium for developing countries, made last year in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and even cancelling debts where appropriate.Furthermore, Special Drawing Rights, a type of supplementary foreign reserve maintained by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), must also be made available to support Africaâ€™s recovery.

title: Climate change top challenge over the next decade, UNESCO global survey finds
text: More than 15,000 people worldwide contributed to the survey, which was held online between May and September 2020, and made available in 25 languages. Â Last year we asked 15,000 people across the globe on what they think are the main global challenges in the World in 2030. We have the full survey results now!Read the survey report here & see what people think of the #WorldIn2030! â¡ï¸ https://t.co/8S6iCRDNRh #Agenda2030 pic.twitter.com/7mEZkFRSzkRespondents were mainly young people, with 57 per cent under age 35, and 35 per cent under 25. Results also were analyzed along regional, gender, age and other demographic lines.Â Â â€œGreater efforts are needed to address peopleâ€™s specific concerns, and multilateralism is the way to do this. Restoring confidence in multilateralism requires the implementation of concrete and impactful projects, and this is at the heart of our Organization's roleâ€, said Audrey Azoulay, the UNESCO Director-General.Â The World in 2030 survey invited people from across the globe to share their specific worries about 11 challenges, and solutions for overcoming them. Â Most participants, or 67 per cent, selected climate change and loss of biodiversity as their top concern, mainly due to issues such as increasing natural disasters and extreme weather. Â Â Respondents felt investment in â€˜greenâ€™ solutions, education on sustainability, promoting international cooperation and building trust in science, were the best ways to address the issue.Â Violence and conflict, discrimination and equality, and lack of food, water and housing were other big challenges, the survey revealed. Â Â Participants believed that overall, more education was the crucial solution to every single challenge. Â They also felt that it was the area that most needed to be re-thought, in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, followed by the overall relationship between humankind and nature.Â The survey further showed that while 95 per cent of respondents extoll the importance of global cooperation in overcoming common challenges, only one in four felt confident that the world would be able to address these issues.Â UNESCO said that â€œtaken together, the results suggest not a lack of appreciation of the importance of multilateralism but rather a crisis of faith in its effectiveness.â€

title: More climate action needed during â€˜make-or-break yearâ€™ for people and planet
text:
With countries across the world having agreed through the Paris Agreement to a goal of limiting temperature increases to 1.5 degree Celsius above pre-industrial levels to mitigate global warming, Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed spelled out at the Climate and Development Ministerial Meeting: â€œWe now need to spare no effort to achieve it in this â€˜make-or-break yearâ€™â€.Â To achieve the #ParisAgreement goals, we must spare no effort. Just transitions ensuring jobs, clean energy and food security are an imperative. @UN identified 5 concrete #ClimateActions to achieve breakthroughs in adaptation and resilience in 2021. pic.twitter.com/wVP80Zl7cnShe painted a picture of climate financing to Least Developed Countries and Small Island Developing States at 14 and two per cent respectively; one person in three not adequately covered by early warning systems; and women and girls â€“ who make up 80 per cent of those displaced by the climate emergency â€“ often excluded from decision-making roles.Â She said the need to adapt and be resilient, was â€œa moral, economic and social imperativeâ€, pointing out that it receives just one-fifth of total climate finance. She said â€œwe cannot wait until 2030 or 2050 to rectify these failingsâ€.Â The UN has identified five concrete and achievable actions to help countries throughout the year respond to the climate emergency and â€œsecure the breakthrough that the Secretary-General has called forâ€, said the Deputy UN chief.Â Firstly, donors need to increase their financial support to climate adaptation by least 50 per cent by June, when the United Kingdom hosts the G7 Summit of industrialized countries, followed by national and multilateral development banks once the UN climate conference (COP26) convenes in November.Â Â Access to climate support must be â€œstreamlined, transparent and simplifiedâ€, especially for the most vulnerable and for a â€œsignificant scale-upâ€ of existing financial instruments designed to handle disasters, along with new instruments to â€œincentivize resilience-buildingâ€.Â Â Next, the deputy UN chief said that developing countries needed to have the tools at their disposal to embed climate risk in all planning, budget, and procurement strategies.Â Â â€œRisk information is the critical first step for risk reduction, transfer and managementâ€, she said.Â Â Â The final action highlighted, was to support locally and regionally led adaptation and resilience initiatives in vulnerable countries, cities and communities, at the frontlines of climate disruption.Â Â 
Information is the critical first step for risk reduction, transfer and management -- UN deputy chief
â€œWe must support efforts that provide local actors, including indigenous people, women and youth, with a much greater voice in the decisions that most affect themâ€, Ms. Mohammed said.Â Â Noting that a â€œdecade of transformationâ€ cannot be delivered with soaring debt levels, she welcomed calls for a massive injection of liquidity and extensive debt relief to provide vulnerable countries with extra resources.Â Â â€œEqually important will be transforming the international debt architecture so that it ensures all can emerge from this crisis with an equal chance of building back better and differentlyâ€, she said.Â In closing, the deputy UN chief urged ministers online to seize the opportunity to â€œpush again today for a concrete outcome that is bold, decisive and ambitiousâ€ to ensure â€œan inclusive and climate resilient transitionâ€.Â â€œI very much look forward to working with you all to achieve the success people and planet deserve at COP26.â€Â At the same time, top international energy and climate leaders met at the International Energy Agency (IEA)-COP26Â  Net Zero Summit to discuss how to accelerate clean energy momentum and examine how countries can more effectively work together to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero.Â The meeting took stock of the growing list of commitments from countries and companies to reach the goals of the Paris Agreement and focused on implementing the necessary actions to turn the growing number of net zero targets into a reality.Â Â To sort out future measures, participants from more than 40 countries shared insights on what has worked so far.Â Â Â The event was designed to increase momentum towards COP26 and informed the preparation of IEAâ€™s upcoming Special Reportâ€¯â€œThe Worldâ€™s Roadmap to Net Zero by 2050â€.Â Click here if you want to watch the summit in its entirety.

title: Plastic pollution disproportionately hitting marginalized groups, UN environment report finds
text: The report, entitled,Â Neglected: Environmental Justice Impacts of Plastic Pollution, was produced by the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) together with the grassroots environmental group, Azul. The findings aim to empower communities affected by plastic waste and advocate for their inclusion in local decision making.â€œEnvironmental justice means educating those on the frontlines of plastic pollution about its risks, including them in decisions about its production, use, and disposal, and ensuring their access to a credible judicial systemâ€, said Inger Andersen, UNEP Executive Director.The report showcases how environmental injustices are linked to plastic production, in areas such as deforestation for road building, the displacement of indigenous peoples to conduct oil drilling, as well as contamination of potable water by fracking operations to extract natural gas, in countries such as the United States and Sudan.Moreover, the report warns of health problems among African-American communities living near oil refineries in the Gulf of Mexico, and the occupational risks faced by some two million waste pickers in India.The impacts of plastics on marginalized populations are severe, and existÂ at all stages of the production cycle, from extracting raw materials and manufacturing, through to consumption and disposal, according to the report.Plastic waste not only endangers the livelihoods of those relying on marine resources, it also causes a raft of health issues for people who consume seafood infested with toxic micro and nano plastics.Women, in particular, suffer from plastic-related toxicity risk, due to higher aggregate exposure to plastics at home and even in feminine care products.Differences in gender, social roles, and political power in regulating plastic use and health standards place women at high risk of miscarriages and cancer, further exacerbating gender-related disparities overall.Aggravated by the COVID-19 pandemic, plastic waste has become a major part of the global pollution crisis, along with biodiversity loss and climate change, representing a triple emergency that must be tackled by strong and effective action plans, says UNEP.The report calls for governments to prioritize the needs of those disproportionÂ­ately affected by plastic pollution, underscoring that action must be taken at multiple levels.It calls for an expansion in plastic waste monitoring, better studies into its health impacts, and more investment in waste management. Governments should further enforce bans on single-use plastics and encourage their reduction, recycling and reuse.Other actors such as business andÂ industry leaders, non-governmental actors, and consumers should also make efforts to reverse the situations for those who are socially, economically, politically marginalized.

title: Guterres calls on US to lead global vaccination plan effort, climate action, welcoming Blinken to Headquarters
text: â€œI welcome the many initiatives the new United States administration has already taken to support multilateral responses to global challenges, and to strengthen cooperation between the US and the UNâ€, saidÂ AntÃ³nio Guterres, sharing a screen with Secretary of State Antony Blinken, and the host countryâ€™s new UN Ambassador, Linda Thomas-Greenfield.The UN chief cited rejoining the Paris Agreement, re-committing to the World Health OrganizationÂ (WHO) in the face of the continuing coronavirus pandemic, and re-engaging with the Human Rights Council, as vital reversals of the previous Trump administrationâ€™s withdrawal from the multilateral stage.â€œThe commitment and contribution of the United States are essential to resolve the many serious global challenges we face â€“ starting with the COVID-19 pandemicâ€, said Mr. Guterres. Â â€œTo end the pandemic everywhere, I have been insisting and I strongly believe we need a global vaccination plan, and I think the United States can play a very important role on this because, as you know, I have proposed that the G20 should establish an emergency task force to develop and coordinate such a plan but there is no way that this can work without an effective American leadership.â€On the need to drastically slow the pace of global warming and take climate action to fulfil the promises made in Paris, the UN chief said the postponed COP26 in Glasgow, was a true make or break moment â€œfor our planetâ€.â€œWe are working closely together to build a global coalition for net zero emissions by mid-century, which has been a top priority for us in the UN for 2021, and to mobilize an immediate quantum leap in adaptation, and in finance to support developing countriesâ€, he told the top US diplomats. â€œAdaptation cannot be the forgotten part of climate action and we very much count on US leadership in this regard.Â  In my last contacts with John Kerry, he was very keen on working very strongly on adaptation and financing.â€Famine is already destroying lives across six countries, and Mr. Guterres said he was happy to see the US using its presidency of the Security Council this month, to lead debates on fighting hunger and using diplomacy for peace.â€œWe will work to reach lasting agreements in Afghanistan and Yemen; to consolidate our efforts in Libya; to achieve tangible progress through the political dialogue in Syria that has not yet happened; and to restart the Middle East peace processâ€, he said.We need a new movement for peace, from war zones to peopleâ€™s homes, where women and girls are facing an epidemic of gender-based violence. On the other hand I am very keen that we can deliver on what I call my Call to Action on Human Rights.â€ Â The Secretary-General said that people everywhere were â€œdemanding an end to systemic racism, discrimination and persecution, and protection for the rights of women, the marginalized, and minorities of all kinds. Â â€œThe United Nations is I believe the place to tackle our joint challenges and reaffirm our common values.â€In response, Mr. Blinken said the UN was â€œthe anchor of the multilateral systemâ€, which the Biden administration sees as â€œvitally importantâ€.â€œWhen we think about virtually all of the problems and challenges that are actually going to affect the lives â€“ are affecting the lives â€“ of our citizens, whether itâ€™s COVID-19, whether itâ€™s climate, whether it is the disruption of emerging technologies, not a single one can be dealt with by any one country acting alone, even the United Statesâ€, he said.â€œWe need to find ways to cooperate, to coordinate, to tackle problems together.Â  And of course, the United Nations is where countries come together to work on common challenges.â€Mr. Blinken said the US had a â€œprofound stakeâ€ in the UN working well, noting President Bidenâ€™s own commitment to multilateralism, as evidenced through re-engagement with UN institutions, â€œfrom day oneâ€.â€œIâ€™ve very much appreciated your own leadership on these issues and in dealing with many of the crises and challenges that we face around the world, from Ethiopia to Burmaâ€, he told the UN chief.Â â€œWe have a broad, broad agenda.Â  I think youâ€™ve got one of the toughest jobs in the world, but weâ€™re grateful that youâ€™re doing it and grateful to have the United Nations as a strong partner in our efforts.â€

title: Earth Hour: â€˜Make peace with natureâ€™ â€“ UN chief
text: In his message to mark the event, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said that â€œwe must all do our part to safeguard the planetâ€.â€œWe need to make peace with nature. Without natureâ€™s help, we cannot thrive or even survive on this planet Earthâ€, he spelled out.Warning that climate disruption, biodiversity loss and pollution â€œthreaten lives, jobs and healthâ€, the UN chief called 2021 â€œa year to change courseâ€.â€œItâ€™s time to re-evaluate and reset our relationship with natureâ€, he said.Â The Secretary-General upheld that solutions are â€œavailable, affordable, practical and realisticâ€.â€œWe can provide renewable energy and sustainable food systems for all. We can reduce emissions and use nature-based solutions to help us build a more resilient, carbon-neutral worldâ€, he said.Â In short, together the world can â€œbuild a brighter and more prosperous futureâ€.The UN chief reminded that â€œsmall actions can make a big differenceâ€ and said that â€œthe United Nations is proud to join in the global effort to mark Earth Hourâ€.â€œIn this â€˜make-or-breakâ€™ year, let your actions and voices send a clear message to leaders everywhere: now is the time to be bold and ambitiousâ€, he stated.â€œLetâ€™s show the world that we are determined to protect the one home we all shareâ€, concluded the Secretary-General.As in previous years, the UN will switch off it lights at Headquarters in New York at 8:30 p.m. NY time.

title: FROM THE FIELD: Preparing for disaster in Nepal
text: Floods, landslides and wildfires are regularly occurring threats in Nepal, and the climate crisis is making such extreme weather events more frequent, and unpredictable.Â Working closely with the UN Development Programme (UNDP), the Nepalese Government is ensuring that the voices of marginalized groups, such as women, people with disabilities, and indigenous communities, are heard and taken into consideration in their plans, which include early warning systems, off-grids clean energy solutions, and reforestation.Read more on how Nepal is adapting to the challenges of climate change here.

title: Biodiversity at risk, threatens human survival, UN forum hears
text: The Director-General of the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), Audrey Azoulay opened the UNESCO Forum on Biodiversity by pointing out that one year after its emergence, the COVID-19 pandemic has confirmed what we had already known; â€œby threatening biodiversity, humanity is threatening the conditions for its own survivalâ€.Â Audrey Azoulay @AAzoulay: "Without biodiversity there would be no life nor beauty in this planet. Biodiversity is the living tissue of the Earth, and its health is intimately linked to to human health. We are part of that living tissue."  #UnescoBiodiversityForum #ForNature pic.twitter.com/QJ2kCekmLQâ€œThe pandemic demonstrated that human health depends on the health of living thingsâ€, she said flagging that it is â€œimperative to rethink our development modelsâ€.Â Biodiversity protection is at the forefront of UNESCOâ€™s ambition along with ocean sciences â€œto rebuild humanities relationship with nature and with living beingsâ€, Ms. Azoulay stated.Â Â Â In kicking off the forum, Ms. Azoulay officially launched the 50th anniversary of UNESCOâ€™s â€œMan and the Biosphere (MAB) programme, which envisioned territories where people could create new ways to enhance the relationship between people and nature.Â â€œFifty years later, this vision is no longer a mere theory, as 275 million people now live in the 714 UNESCO biosphere reserves in 129 countriesâ€, she said, adding that together with the 252 World Heritage Sites and geoparks, â€œsix per cent of the worldâ€™s land mass â€“ equivalent to the surface of China â€“ is protectedâ€.Â As a so-called â€œsuper yearâ€ for biodiversity, UNESCO will join with partners to set new objectives for the coming decade.Â Â â€œOur goal is to preserve 30 per cent of the planet in protected areasâ€, Ms. Azoulay said, noting that caring for the planet means preserving the climate, protecting biodiversity and fighting against declining ocean health â€“ another UNESCO priority.Â Earlier this year, the UNESCO chief heralded the UN Decade of Ocean Science.Â â€œWe now have ten years to better understand and preserve the ocean, to reforge the relationship between humans and the seas and, in the process, to make important strides towards protecting biodiversity and the environmentâ€, she said.Â Â Â UNESCO is also strongly committed to enhancing education programmes dealing with the natural world, and has called on its 193 Member States to â€œbetter integrate sustainable development and nature into curriculaâ€.Â Â And to guarantee that education gives future generations the tools they need to save the planet, the UN agency is compiling a global framework of best practices in the field.Â Â â€œMany other important milestones lie ahead of us â€“and this UNESCO Forum aims to be a launchpad for these major eventsâ€, she said, pointing to the IUCN World Conservation Congress in Marseille, the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow, and the COP15 biodiversity convention in Kunming.Â â€œWe need a collective commitment, which brings together civil society and the private sectorâ€, the UNESCO chief said.Â Many other luminaries lent their voices to amplify the urgency of the situation, including Pope Francis, who urged everyone to see climate change as â€œmuch more of a moral than a technical issueâ€.Â UN Sustainable Development Goals Advocate, Hindou Oumarou Ibrahim, warned that â€œif our environment disappears, who we are, our identity, and our way of life will disappear with itâ€.Â UN Messenger of Peace, Jane Goodall, underscored the need â€œto develop a new relationship with the natural world and a new relationship with animalsâ€.Â And UN Special Envoy for the Ocean, Peter Thomson, underscored that â€œwe cannot have a healthy planet without a healthy ocean.â€

title: UN chief urges â€˜clear and credibleâ€™ plans to achieve net zero
text: Addressing a ministerial meeting on climate action, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres reiterated that 2021 is a â€œmake-or-breakâ€ year to limit the global temperature rise by 1.5 degree Celsius, as set out in the Paris Agreement on climate change.Â The #ClimateAction decisions countries take during this make-or-break year have the power to limit temperature rise to 1.5 degrees.We simply cannot contemplate any alternative.This is the path to peace and prosperity on a healthy planet.https://t.co/wN6sZDaRf6â€œWe need credible, coherent plans to cut emissions by 45 per cent compared to 2010 levels, by 2030â€, Mr. Guterres said, urging countries to submit, or re-submit, ambitious nationally determined contributions (NDCs) â€œas a matter of urgencyâ€.Â He also called on development banks and donors to commit half their climate finance annually to adaptation, and to ensure those resources are accessible to the most vulnerable. Â Alongside, the Secretary-General also underlined the need for a â€œbreakthrough on ending coalâ€.Â â€œPhasing out coal is the most important step to limit temperature rise to 1.5 degrees. We must end the financing of coal-fired power. No new coal plants should be approvedâ€, he said, noting coal must be phased out by 2030 in OECD countries, and by 2040 globally.Â In particular, the UN chief urged the G7 nations to â€œtake the lead by committing to this by their summit in Juneâ€. G20 countries should do the same, he added.Â Mr. Guterres also cautioned against any delays for climate action, including due to the coronavirus pandemic.Â He urged countries to â€œmove forward immediatelyâ€ with virtual negotiations in reparation for the 26th session of the Conference of the Parties (COP26) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which will be held this November, in Glasgow.Â â€œA successful resolution at COP 26, including on Articles 6 and 13 of the Paris Agreement concerning carbon markets and transparency, depends on this effortâ€, he highlighted, underscored the â€œfull supportâ€ of the Organization â€œto ensure all countries are included, and all voices heardâ€.Â Co-convened by Canada, China and the European Union, the Ministerial on Climate Action is an annual meeting ministers and representatives from a number countries, including from the G20 and chairs of key party groupings in the UN climate negotiations.Â Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the high-level event was held in a virtual setting.

title: Oceans under threat likeÂ never before, warns World Meteorological Organization
text: In an alertÂ that warmer seas helped to fuel a record Atlantic hurricane season last year,Â along withÂ intense tropical cyclones in the Indian and South Pacific Oceans, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO)Â alsoÂ underscoredÂ the long-term threat from sea level rise.Â #WorldMetDay is 23 March.The #Ocean, our #climate and #weather. The ocean drives climate and weather. It absorbs around 90% of  excess heat trapped by C02. #ClimateChange makes it more vulnerable and hazardous.  #OceanDecadeResources at https://t.co/AnMwluwPnO pic.twitter.com/2yuYmEfNIaâ€œAbout 40Â per centÂ of the global population live within 100 kilometresÂ of the coast, there is an urgent need to protect communities from coastal hazards, such as waves, storm surge and sea level riseâ€ viaÂ â€œmulti-hazardâ€Â warningÂ systemsÂ and forecasting,Â said Professor PetteriÂ Taalas, WMOÂ Secretary-General.Â According to the UN agency, the â€œblue economyâ€ is estimated at $3-6 trillion a year,Â accountingÂ for more than three quarters of world trade and providingÂ livelihoods forÂ more than sixÂ billion people.Â Millions of dollars in goods and hundreds of lives are still lost at sea each year,Â due to extreme weather conditions such as high winds, large waves, fog, thunderstorms, sea ice and freezing spray, WMO noted.Â It described the ocean as â€œthe Earthâ€™s thermostatâ€,Â absorbingÂ and transformingÂ a significant portion of the sunâ€™s radiationÂ and providingÂ heat and water vapour to the atmosphere.Â Â AlthoughÂ vastÂ ocean currents circulate this heat around the planet, often for thousands of kilometres,Â human activitiesÂ have increasinglyÂ distortedÂ this naturalÂ ocean/atmosphere equilibrium, WMO maintained.Â The UN agencyÂ pointed to the fact thatÂ oceansÂ absorb over 90Â per centÂ of excessÂ atmosphericÂ heat trapped by greenhouse gases,Â whichÂ has come â€œat a heavy price as ocean warming and changes in ocean chemistry are already disrupting marine ecosystems and people who depend on themâ€.Â This impact â€œwill be felt for hundreds of yearsâ€,Â WMOÂ chiefÂ TaalasÂ continued, before pointing to theÂ profound repercussionsÂ of ice meltÂ for the rest of the globe, through changing weather patterns and accelerating sea level rise.Â Â â€œIn 2020, the annual Arctic sea ice minimum was among the lowest on record, exposing Polar communities to abnormal coastal flooding, and stakeholders such as shipping and fisheries, to sea ice hazards,â€ heÂ explained.Â Ahead ofÂ World Meteorological DayÂ onÂ TuesdayÂ 23 March, the UN agency highlighted theÂ value of the â€œ24/7 workâ€Â ofÂ nationalÂ weather centresÂ in protecting lives and propertyÂ â€œnot just on land but also at seaâ€.Â Although theÂ accuracy and timeliness of weather forecasting haveÂ improved,Â WMO explained thatÂ vessels lacking the latest technologyÂ oftenÂ went without thisÂ crucialÂ shipping news.Â â€œIt is vital to improve decision support services to help mariners reach a balance between minimizing costs and routing, whilst also maximizing safety and avoiding hazardous maritime weather,â€ WMO said in a statement.Â A key concern isÂ increasingÂ sea ice lossÂ as the world warms up, itÂ explained. â€œLess ice does not mean less danger and the consequences of a major accident in Arctic waters would be devastating for the environment. WMO is therefore trying to improve forecasts and warnings of both weather and ice conditions inÂ polar regions.â€Â Despite technological advancesÂ that haveÂ revolutionizedÂ ocean monitoringÂ globallyÂ andÂ helpedÂ toÂ understandÂ its link toÂ weather and climate, the UN agencyÂ cautioned thatÂ â€œbig geographical andÂ research gapsâ€Â remain in theÂ Global Ocean Observing System,Â amid increasingÂ demand for forecasts and services.Â The COVID-19 crisis made matters worseÂ when inÂ March 2020,Â governments and oceanographic institutions recalled nearly all oceanographic research vessels home.Â Â â€œIt also reduced the capacity of commercial ships to contribute vital ocean and weather observations,â€ WMO said.Â â€œOcean buoys and other systems could not be maintained, in some cases leading to their premature failure.â€Â Sea level has risen by around 15 centimetresÂ during the 20th century, according to WMO, from glacierÂ melt, the expansion of warmer sea waters andÂ additionsÂ fromÂ formerÂ ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica.Â Projections show that sea level riseÂ couldÂ be in the order ofÂ 30-60Â centimetresÂ by 2100,Â even if greenhouse gas emissions are sharply reduced and global warming is limited to well below 2Â°C.Â Â However, if greenhouse gas emissions continue unabated, the increase will be between 60-110Â centimetres.

title: FROM THE FIELD: Costa Rica communities fight duel COVID and climate threat
text: The dual threat has focused the attention of community groups on water, or rather the lack of it, and what they can do to ensure they have enough to carry on farming, protect the environment and shield themselves from the deadly virus.Â Water and the washing of hands has been promoted as one of the key ways to prevent COVID-19 from spreading. Â The UN is projecting that the global demand for clean water will increase by 50 per cent over the next 20 years.On World Water Day, marked annually on 22 March read more here about how one woman has dedicated her life to ensuring her compatriots have equal access to water.
