title: UN warns of catastrophe as second hurricane in two weeks hits Central America
text: â€œWe're running out of superlatives for this Atlantic hurricane season. It's record breaking in every sense of the word. We are currently, with Iota, on the 30th named tropical stormâ€,Â ClareÂ Nullis, spokesperson for the World Meteorological Organization, told a regular UN news briefing in Geneva.Â â€¯Â In a record-breaking season, unprecedented back-to-back category 4 hurricanes #Iota and #Eta have caused devastation and high casualty toll in Central America.Successive typhoons and floods have impacted millions in SE Asia.WMO roundup is herehttps://t.co/bivfZImTjM pic.twitter.com/Qhu80MDn4Yâ€œIota made landfall less than two weeks after Hurricane Eta, which was also a very strong category four hurricane, made landfall just 25 kilometres apart.Â SoÂ we're having these huge impacts hitting basically the same area. Nicaragua, Honduras, other parts of Central America have not recovered from Hurricane Eta, and now they're being slammed by this new terrific powerful hurricaneâ€, Ms.Â NullisÂ said.Â â€¯Â Jens Laerke, spokesperson for the U.N. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, said aid workers in Central America were still discovering the extent of damage from Eta and were now preparing to deal with a second potentially catastrophic impact.Â â€¯Â â€œIota, with its strong winds and very heavy rainfall, can cause life-threatening flash flooding, river flooding and landslides, not least because the soil is already saturated by Eta.â€â€¯Â Estimates of damage from Eta were still going up as officials and local authorities gradually got access to the most affected areas, Mr. Laerke said.Â â€¯â€¯Â â€œSo, for example, Honduras, authorities now report that 3 million people are affected. That's 1 million more than the figures that they reported last week. InÂ Guatemala, we are talking about more than 900,000 people directly affected by Eta. That's nearly triple the figure from the previous weeks.Â SoÂ this is very much still developing emergency on top of which now slams another emergency with potentially catastrophic consequences.â€â€¯Â Matthew Cochrane, spokesperson for the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), said the main concern was theÂ risk of landslides, heavy flooding and wind damage. The Red Cross had been involved in helicopter evacuations before the storm hit and it had rescue boats in Honduras ready to launch rescue operations once it had passed, he said.â€¯Â Iota had already brushed past northern Colombia and the Red Cross there was in the early stages of a recovery operation to help 50,000 families affected by the storm, Mr. Cochrane said.Â â€¯Â But a 20 million Swiss franc emergency appeal to support people affected by Hurricane Eta had so far had an extremely slow response from donors, he added.Â â€¯Â World Food Programme spokesperson Tomson Phiri said humanitarian agencies had done what they could to prepare, but the hurricane season had turned out to be even worse than expected, starting early and going on longer.â€¯Â â€œFor example, continued flooding in countries like Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua, is going to affect the incoming harvest, and this will severely strain subsistence farmers and already, whilst it's still early days, it is quite clear that this will extend the emergency even into mid-2021â€, Mr Phiri said.Â â€¯Â Ms.Â NullisÂ said that at this time of year hurricane season should be winding down, but instead there was a very tragic late surge.Â â€¯Â â€œIota is the strongest storm in the hurricane season so far to make landfall.â€

title: Climate change: UN chief calls for â€˜great leapâ€™ towards carbon neutrality
text: AntÃ³nio Guterres was addressing the third annual Bloomberg New Economy Forum, described as â€œa global town hallâ€ that brings together government, business, technology and academia.Â â€œ2021 must be the year of a great leap towards carbon neutrality,â€ he said. â€œEvery country, city, financial institution and company should adopt plans for transitioning to net zero emissions by 2050.â€Â Mr. Guterres reported that recently, the European Union, Japan, the Republic of Korea, along with more than 110 other countries, announced their pledges for achieving the carbon neutrality goal, which China also plans to reach before 2060. Â  Â â€œBy early 2021, countries representing more than 65 per cent of global carbon dioxide emissions and more than 70 per cent of the world economy are very likely to have made ambitious commitments to carbon neutrality,â€ he said.Â â€œThe signal this sends to markets, institutional investors and decision-makers is clear. Carbon should be given a price. Â The time of fossil fuel subsidies is over. Â We must phase out coal. We must shift the tax burden from income to carbon, from taxpayers to polluters.â€Â He added that financial reporting on exposure to climate risks should be made mandatory, while authorities must integrate the carbon neutrality goal into economic and fiscal policies in order to truly transform industry, agriculture, transportation and the energy sector.Â The Secretary-General highlighted the value of partnership between the United Nations and the business and private sector, including through initiatives such as the Global Investors for Sustainable Development Alliance and the Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance.Â However, he stressed that such coalitions â€œcannot be global without developing countries, which will need significant support.â€Â Mr. Guterres also acknowledged that the shift to carbon neutrality will not be easy.Â â€œWe need a just transition, with training and assistance for those who will lose jobs or be affected in other waysâ€, he said.Â Furthermore, even as countries work to mitigate emissions in the future, they must address current impacts, he continued.Â Mr. Guterres cited a recent report which revealed that only one-fifth of climate finance goes to adaptation. Â Furthermore, only 14 per cent of recent financing went to the worldâ€™s least developed countries, and only two per cent to small island developing states.Â â€œThis is not only insufficient; it is dangerous. Â Adaptation should not be the forgotten component of climate actionâ€, he stated.Â â€œAnd finally letâ€™s be smart: this will require financing, private and public â€“ but these are investments in a safer, more prosperous and sustainable future.â€Â As the COVID-19 pandemic deepens, the Secretary-General also touched on the UNâ€™s ongoing efforts to save lives, control virus spread and ease the fallout.Â Additionally, the UN also is advocating what he called â€œa massive rescue packageâ€ for the most vulnerable people and countries, in addition to pressing for a global ceasefire, among other actions.Â â€œWe are all rightly focused on responding to the pandemic. Â But as we strive to overcome one crisis, we have an opening to address another,â€ said Mr. Guterres.Â â€œThe pandemic has shown that we can think big and act big in the face of an emergency. Â We have crucial decisions to make in the weeks and months ahead. Â Letâ€™s get it right.â€

title: A deep dive into Zero Hunger: farming the seas
text:
Aquaculture, or fish farming, is one of the fastest growing food-production sectors in the world, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), reaching an all-time record high of 114.5 million tonnes in 2018. Asian countries continue to account for the vast majority of farmed fish production, some 90 per cent over the last two decades and, since 2016, aquaculture has been the main source of fish available for human consumption.Â Overfishing of wild fish is an ongoing problem, and the FAO warned in its 2020 World Fisheries and Aquaculture report, that the status of fish stocks are deteriorating: around 30 per cent are not within biologically sustainable levels, and some 60 per cent are at near capacity.Aquaculture is expected to further dominate the seafood market in the coming years and, in the same report, the FAO declared that it could have a transformational impact on the way we feed the global population, if it is managed sustainably.Â Wenche GrÃ¸nbrekk is the chairperson of the United Nations Global Compact Local Network for Norway, a group of private companies that have agree to work towards the UNâ€™s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Â  She is also an executive at salmon farming company Cermaq, which is based in Norway, Chile, and Canada. She says that the amount of seafood currently farmed could, in fact, be sustainably increased six-fold, given the right conditions.However, she acknowledges that environmental challenges persist. The detrimental effects of aquaculture include the destruction of marine habitats, the use of harmful chemicals and veterinary drugs, and the production of waste.â€œThe farmed fish industry is still relatively young and, despite the bad reputation it has had, it has developed a lot. Today, it has a strong focus on sustainability, and salmon farming, for example, is the most technologically advanced form of aquaculture. Iâ€™ve been encouraged to see that there is a real will to lift standards in the industry, and an understanding that, by working together on sustainable development issues, we will all benefit.â€Cermaq is a founding member of Seafood Business for Ocean Stewardship (SeaBOS), an industry group that is supporting the UN Global Compactâ€™s Sustainable Ocean Business Action Platform, which promotes the central role that seafood has to play in feeding the growing world population.Â 
Aquaculture is the best way to help feed some 10 billion people in the coming years Martin Exel, Managing Director, Seafood Business for Ocean Stewardship (SeaBOS)
Martin Exel, the managing director of SeaBOS, agrees that the aquaculture sector only has itself to blame for the reputation it has acquired. â€œWe have had some bad actors, who have done the wrong things and, frankly, broken the rulesâ€, he says. Nevertheless, he is confident that the industry is moving in the right direction:â€œSeaBOS brings together some of the biggest companies in the industry, and weâ€™re having frank discussions about the challenges we face. These include climate change impacts, illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing, modern slavery, the removal of ocean plastics, and how to reduce the use of antibiotics in aquaculture, especially those that are critical for human health.â€According to Mr. Exel, the seafood companies in SeaBOS understand the importance of environmental and economic sustainability, which includes looking after the people working in the business, and gaining the trust and respect of the community, and consumers. Â â€œThe fact is that aquaculture is the best way to help feed some 10 billion people in the coming yearsâ€, says Mr. Exel. â€œIt can be scaled up in a healthy and sustainable way, which is why our members are working closely with scientists to advance the technology that will ensure that we can effectively solve the food productions challenges that we are all facing.â€Peter Thomson, the UN Secretary-Generalâ€™s Special Envoy for the Ocean, is confident that, if managed properly, the Ocean will play a major role in ending hunger worldwide.â€œThe potential of the sustainable blue economy (the development of oceanic economic activities in an integrated and sustainable way) to feed the world is immense. Never forget that the Ocean covers 70 per cent of the planetâ€™s surface and that well over 90 per cent of the planetâ€™s living space is below the Oceanâ€™s surface.â€â€œThrough the development of new forms of sustainable aquaculture with appropriate species and feeds, mariculture (the farming of organisms in marine environments), shellfish farming, and much greater attention to macroalgae (seaweed) for human and animal food, the Ocean will provide us with a large proportion of the nutritious food we need.â€

title: A deep dive into Zero Hunger: the seaweed revolution
text: â€œWhen it comes to the ocean, we are still hunter-gatherersâ€, says Vincent Doumeizel, a senior advisor on ocean-based solutions at the UN Global Compact, and an evangelist for seaweed. â€œBy farming just two per cent of the ocean, we could provide enough protein to feed a world population of 12 billion people. Seaweed is extremely protein rich, low in fat, low in carbohydrates, and rich in vitamins, zinc and ironâ€.As any fan of sushi will already know, certain forms of seaweed are edible for human consumption. Whilst seaweed has been popular in Asia, particularly Japan, for many years, it is slowly becoming better known throughout the rest of the world, and Mr. Doumeizel is confident that it has the potential to become a mainstream food. â€œMost Japanese people eat seaweed three times a day, it is used in many dishes in Korea, and is eaten by many people in China. This may be a major factor in cutting the levels of non-communicable diseases in these countries.Mr. Doumeizel also touts the environmental benefits of seaweed, particularly as an ingredient in animal feed: â€œSeaweed doesnâ€™t need land, fresh water, or pesticides, just sun and saltwater. If livestock were fed on seaweed-based foodstuffs, rather than soy, methane emissions could be cut by 90 per cent, and improve digestion whilst boosting the animalsâ€™ immune systems, which reduces the need for antibiotics. This is already happening in some countries, such as Scotland and Icelandâ€.Seaweed has many other uses and benefits, as an organic fertilizer, a sustainable replacement for plastics, and an ingredient in cosmetics and medicines. It also plays a role in tackling ocean pollution, cleaning the water of nitrates and phosphates.Given the vast range of benefits seaweed offers, why isnâ€™t it being used more widely? Technical barriers are one reason, according to Mr. Doumeizel. â€œThere is a lack of space to grow underwater forests near shorelines, and it can be difficult to get a licence to grow them off-shore. We need to learn from oil companies, which have a lot of experience in dealing with strong ocean currents and wavesâ€.In fact, one company with big plans to expand seaweed production, is run by a former executive at international oil company, Shell. Kelp Blue is planning to grow huge underwater forests of seaweed off the coast of Namibia, covering some 70,000 hectares. These forests, say the company, would help to solve the worldâ€™s food crisis whilst, at the same time, removing vast amounts of harmful greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, and creating hundreds of jobs.They would be populated by giant kelp, a form of seaweed that can grow to 100 feet (30 metres). According to Kelp Blue, one million tons of carbon dioxide would be locked away by the forests and, because one of the main products from kelp is feed for livestock, it has the potential to remove much more, via reduced methane emissions. An added possible side benefits of the forests is a projected growth in fish stocks in the surrounding waters of up to 20 per cent, with the expectation that around 200 species would their home within the kelp.Whilst companies like Kelp Blue appear to have solutions to technical challenges, the main obstacle that still needs to be overcome is a lack of global safety standards for seaweed products, and resistance to collaboration, in an industry still driven by relatively small companies and entrepreneurs, who are not keen to share.To overcome this problem, the UN Global Compact has published a seaweed manifesto, which calls for internationally agreed standards, new investment efforts, and greater collaboration between governments, science and industry, to drive production to the next level.The manifesto was officially launched one the sidelines of the 2020 UN General Assembly, at an online event which brought together several players from the private and public sector, and featured Alexandra Cousteau, grand-daughter of famed ocean explorer Jacques Cousteau, and founder of Oceans 2050, a campaign and action platform dedicated to restoring ocean health over the next thirty years.If it succeeds, the seaweed industry could find itself playing a much greater role in fighting the climate crisis, strengthening marine ecosystems and bringing the world closer to the big prize: an end to hunger.

title: COVID disruption will â€˜pale in comparisonâ€™ if world fails to act on climate change, SDGs
text: â€œThe decisions we make now will determine the course of the next 30 years and beyond: Emissions must fall by half by 2030 and reach net-zero emissions no later than 2050 to reach the 1.5C goalâ€, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said in his message to the virtual Finance in Common Summit.â€œIf we fail to meet these goals, the disruption to economies, societies and people caused by COVID-19 will pale in comparison to what the climate crisis holds in storeâ€.Mr. Guterres maintained that the world has a shared responsibility to redouble its efforts to recover from the economic and social crisis and â€œget on trackâ€ to achieve the SDGs and build a sustainable, inclusive and resilient future.Crises often create opportunities for major transformation.#PDBs of the world, all gathered for the first time, commit to support the transformation of the global economy, in order to achieve the #SDGs @UN#FinanceinCommon2020 pic.twitter.com/CSfH4hZfHYâ€œGlobal solidarity is imperative to defeat the virus and recover betterâ€, he upheld.The UN chief told participants he was encouraged by the growing number of countries committing to the net zero target.He noted that the European Union (EU) had pledged to become the first carbon-neutral bloc by 2050 and has aligned its COVID-19 recovery package with that objective. And 110 other countries, including the United Kingdom, Japan and Korea, have also made the pledge for 2050 while China is aiming for 2060.â€œThis means that 50 per cent of the worldâ€™s Gross Domestic Product, and about 50 per cent of global carbon dioxide emissions, are now covered by a net-zero commitmentâ€, Mr. Guterres explained, adding that many cities and businesses are realizing the â€œwe have no alternative, and because they recognize the opportunities that are there to be seizedâ€.Â So far, however, no bold commitments have been made to finance the vehicles necessary for the SDGs.The UN chief noted that public development banks are â€œuniquely positioned to play a leading roleâ€, by providing concessionary finance where it is most needed, and leveraging private funding.Â â€œThis is essential to reboot our economies and put them firmly on the path to a carbon-neutral, sustainable futureâ€, he attested.The Secretary-General outlined five measures to achieve these goals, beginning with aligning the mandates of public development banks with the SDGs and carbon neutrality commitments by 2050.â€œInvestâ€¦in just transition programmes, that will leave no one behind, including SDG bonds, and incorporate gender and sustainability in all instrumentsâ€, he said.Painting a picture of enormous demands for emergency funding with simplified approval processes, Mr. Guterresâ€™ second point was to give priority to funding immediate relief measures, particularly on public health and food security.â€œInvestments by public development banks have been shown to bring in more private finance instead of replacing itâ€¦[and] offer opportunities to improve governance and regulatory frameworks in the countries where they operate, providing certainty and bringing in much-needed capitalâ€, he said.Â Thirdly, there is a need to dramatically increase public development finance for adaptation and resilience, particularly for the most vulnerable groups.â€œWe need to invest massively in public health, food security and education for all; in empowering women, girls and the most vulnerable; in supporting productive investment and employment; in access to energy; and in promoting human rights in generalâ€, the UN chief spelled out.Next, it was important to have transparency to ensure that both public and private finance supports the SDGs and the Paris Agreement.â€œWork together to adopt norms, standards and certification mechanisms for sustainable financeâ€, he urged all countries.Finally, Mr. Guterres underscored the need for better data.â€œWe need public development banks to invest in the data and statistics that strengthen the capacity of developing countries to make the decisions that are needed andâ€¦openly share their data with decision-makers for better, coordinated actionâ€, he elaborated.The UN chief told the participants that their decisions will â€œsend a signal to the global financial community and to policy makers around the worldâ€, transform development finance and â€œhelp build the foundations of a new economy fit for the 21st centuryâ€.

title: UN chief stresses need for greater speed to achieve carbon neutrality
text: The UN chief made the statement in a video message for the opening of the Race To Zero Dialogues, part of a global campaign that mobilizes businesses, cities, regions and investors to support net zero carbon emissions, in line with the Paris Agreement on Climate Change.Â Mr. Guterres reported that so far, the European Union, Japan and the Republic of Korea, along with more than 110 other countries, have made the pledge, while China is set to join them by 2060.Â The #RaceToZero pathways are designed to unleash the full potential of the Paris Agreement - @PEspinosaC at the opening of Race to Zero Dialogues that kicked off today. More: https://t.co/VTDSJWXEsE pic.twitter.com/vfFOyAWd3Dâ€œThat means 50 per cent of the worldâ€™s GDP and half of global CO2 emissions are now covered by a net zero commitment. And the number of net-zero commitments from companies has more than doubled in the past year to over 1,100. Yet, we are still far from where we need to be,â€ he said.Â â€œOur goal is to limit temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. Today, we are still headed towards three degrees at least.â€Â The Race To Zero dialogues are part of the lead-up to the anniversary of the Paris Agreement on 12 December, and the Climate Ambition Summit to be held that day.Â The virtual gathering began on Monday, which would have marked the start of the latest UN climate change conference, known as COP26, which had to be re-scheduled to next year due to the COVID-19 pandemic.Â â€œThe postponement highlights the disruption the COVID-19 pandemic has caused. And these dialogues highlight that climate action is more urgent than ever as we work to recover from the effects of the pandemic,â€ the Secretary-General remarked.Â The Race To Zero Dialogues are being held online, and across multiple time zones, over the next 10 days, with more than 100 virtual events scheduled.Â Sessions are organized under different daily themes, covering key sectors including transport, health, energy, industry, oceans and water, and food systems.Â The Secretary-General issued a call to participants, underlining the need for ambition and action.Â â€œI urge you and the members of the different coalitions you are part of to promote, develop and implement credible decarbonization plans,â€ he said.Â â€œBring your supply chain and partners on board in time for the Climate Ambition Summit I am co-hosting on December 12 â€“ the five-year anniversary of the Paris Agreement.â€Â The UN chief commended the dialogues for being an example of the collaboration needed to address climate change, stating that â€œWe are moving in the right direction, but we need greater speed.â€ Â However, he warned that â€œthe window of opportunity is closing.â€Â Mr. Guterres stressed that all Governments, cities, financial institutions and the private sector must establish transition plans for net zero emissions. Â Â â€œWe need everyone to commit to carbon neutrality by 2050, and to take climate action that will benefit people and the planet,â€ he said.

title: Climate Action Superheroes empower children to protect the planet
text: The Climate Action Superheroes are the face of a new campaign, to be launched on UN social media platforms thisÂ Saturday, aimed at mobilizing children under 12 to recycle and to save water and energy.Â â€œWe want children to be aware of the difference they can make through everyday actionsâ€, said Nanette Braun, Director of Campaigns in the UN Department of Global Communications, which is also home to UN News. Â â€œLifelong behaviours are shaped at an early age and we hope that providing the knowledge and tools to help build a more sustainable future will have lasting impact.â€Â The rainbow of quirky superheroes isÂ armed with advice on the steps youngsters can take towards meaningful action for themselves, and their families.Â They include the Energy Expert, Recycle Ranger, Green Guide and Water Wizard,Â who will engage children, and parents, in fun missions on topics such as reducing single-use plastic, saving energy and conserving water.Â Take theÂ Fashion Fixer, a seagreen-coloured titan taking on the global textile industry,Â which produces more than eight per cent of greenhouse gases and 20 per cent of global wastewater annually.The character shows how being stylish does not have to be wasteful by donating used clothing and mending items, thus giving them new life. Â Â Since superheroes wear masks, especially in the COVID-19 era, their â€œmissionâ€ includes making your own facemask, preferably from recycled fabric.Â Related to this is the Truth Talker, who â€œhas the facts about climate change and tells others about it.â€ Â The red-coloured characterÂ is also concerned about how best we can all communicate during this unprecedented period of global pandemic. Â Truth Talker encourages children to find out the facts and share them with their friends, thus helping to counter misinformation. As an anti-bullying crusader, the superhero encourages children to report online bullies and to speak up against any type of discrimination.Â But in order to tell others about the truth, you first need to learn what the truth is, the character advises. Children can take a simple quiz to test their knowledge about climate change, with answers and explanations provided.Â Children and their parents can learn about the superheroes and their many missions through a colourful, animated world on the UN website.Â The campaign concept was developed by students at Parsons School of Design, part of The New School, a prestigious university in New York City, home to UN Headquarters.Â TheyÂ are in a global executive masterâ€™s programme which has a focus on leading creative change. Â They worked with the UN to brainstorm new ways of engaging the public on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).Â The 17 SDGs provide a blueprint for achieving a better, more sustainable future, through addressing extreme poverty, inequality, climate change, justice, gender equality and other global challenges. Their deadline is 2030.Â The students felt a childrenâ€™s campaign would have the greatest impact towards driving long-term, transformative change.Â â€œWith climate change causing ever greater harm to people and the planet, the students were eager to take on this urgent topicâ€, said Melissa Rancourt, Academic Director for the Global Executive Master of Science in Strategic Design and Management at The New School. Â â€œBy engaging children, we target the consumers and decision-makers of the future, who will drive the change the world needs.â€Â â€¯The Climate Action Superheroes are a component of the UNâ€™s ongoingâ€¯ActNowâ€¯campaign, a call for individual action on sustainability, launched in December 2018. Â So far, nearly one million climate actions have been logged through the campaignâ€™s chat bot and mobile app, with a growing number of people making climate action an integral part of their daily life.

title: UN and partners express regret over US departure from Paris climate accord
text: On Wednesday, the US formally withdrew from the 2015 Paris Agreement on Climate Change, a decision originally announced three years ago.Â â€œWe note with regret that the US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement has formally come into effect todayâ€, the UN body said in a joint statement issued alongside Chile, France, Italy and the United Kingdom. Â "There is no greater responsibility than protecting our planet and people from the threat of climate change."Read the joint statement on the US withdrawal from the #ParisAgreement by Chile, France, Italy, UK and UN Climate Change >> https://t.co/mXRmSlUAVM pic.twitter.com/AXLxOJ2ZiRUnder the Paris Agreement, countries pledge to take action to keep temperature rise to below two degrees Celsius and limit global warming to 1.5 degrees.Â Asked about the US withdrawal, UN Spokesperson StÃ©phane Dujarric told journalists participating in the regular press briefing in New York that â€œour support, our belief in the need for a strong and active Paris Agreement, remains unchanged.â€ Â The Paris Agreement allows for a party to leave the deal at any time after three years from the date on which it entered into force for that State. Â Â Withdrawal would take effect one year after receipt of official notification.Â The US, under the Obama administration, acceded to the Paris Agreement on 3 September 2016, with entry into force occurring two months later.Â In August 2017, the Trump administration formally notified the UN Secretary-General of its intention to withdraw from the accord as soon as it was eligible. Â For the UNFCCC and partners, there is no greater responsibility than protecting the planet and the worldâ€™s people from the threat of climate change, their statement declared.Â â€œThe science is clear that we must urgently scale up action and work together to reduce the impacts of global warming and to ensure a greener, more resilient future for us all. The Paris Agreement provides the right framework to achieve thisâ€, they said.Â Next month marks five years since representatives from more than 190 countries met in the French capital and adoptedÂ the agreement.Â Mr. Dujarric reported that the UN will co-host a virtual climate ambition summit on 12 December, the treatyâ€™s anniversary. Â Â â€œWe know that the commitments made in Paris have not been met across the boardâ€, he said. â€œWe know that those commitments, given what the science is telling us, need to be increased.â€Â Recently, two major industrial nations, Japan and the Republic of Korea, announced their commitment to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, which the UN Secretary-General has welcomed.Â Mr. Dujarric expressed hope that this development â€œwill lead others down that pathâ€.Â This year, the UN was forced to postpone its latest global climate change conference, known as COP26, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Â It will be held in Glasgow, Scotland, next November, hosted by the UKÂ in partnership with Italy.Â In the interim, the UNFCCC and partners will continue to support greater climate action.Â â€œAs we look towards COP26 in Glasgow, we remain committed to working with all US stakeholders and partners around the world to accelerate climate action, and with all signatories to ensure the full implementation of the Paris Agreement,â€ their joint statement concluded.

title: FROM THE FIELD: Planning a route to green cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina
text: With one of the worldâ€™s highest levels of air pollution, the central Bosnian city of Zenica, an industrial hub, is now attempting to turn around its fortunes, with the backing of the UN Development Programme (UNDP).A host of projects are underway in Zenica, including river-bed cleaning (to avoid flooding), ending the use of coal for municipal heating and, as part of UNDPâ€™s Go Green Initiative, tree-planting.Â UNDP-supported initiatives are also designed to have a beneficial effect on surrounding rural areas, which have suffered from severe flooding in recent years.Â On World Cities Day marked annually on 31 October read more here about urban transformation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Caribbean vital to tackling COVID-19, climate change, UN chief tells regional leaders
text: AntÃ³nio Guterres was addressing a virtual meeting of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM), where he praised countries for their leadership during the crisis, even as they confront shocks to their economies, tourism sector, trade and remittances.Â â€œYour unique voice is vital as we tackle shared threats such as climate change, citizen insecurity and the COVID-19 pandemic that expose deep and systemic inequalities,â€ he said.Â The UN chief stated that the pandemicâ€™s socioeconomic impacts have been worse than the virus itself for some developing economies, including the Caribbean.Â He highlighted his push for a relief package equivalent to at least 10 per cent of the global economy, as well as an appeal for debt relief.Â Â â€œAs you have long advocated, the world must look beyond incomes and factor in the vulnerabilities of countries. The private sector, including the credit rating agencies, also must be engaged in relief effortsâ€, he said.Â Mr. Guterres also underlined his solidarity with CARICOM members in addressing climate change.Â â€œYour leadership and moral voice on the front lines is crucial for charting a recovery that will accelerate the decarbonization of the global economy and build a more inclusive and resilient future,â€ he said.Â Readers can find information and guidance on the outbreak of the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) from the UN, World Health Organization and UN agencies here. For daily news updates from UN News, click here.The Secretary-General emphasized his full support for the Caribbean vision of becoming the first fully climate-resilient region in the world. Â Â However, he noted the â€œsignificant barriersâ€ countries face, including for access to climate finance. Â Â Turning to sustainable development, Mr. Guterres reported that the UN system is ramping up support for the Caribbean and all small island developing states.Â â€œWe are putting our best capacities and resources to support your voice and participation in global governance processes, to provide sound policy advice and help broker the partnerships that will facilitate your continued progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals,â€ he said.Â â€œThis includes expanding and reconfiguring as necessary our physical presence and ensuring tailored support to every country in the Caribbean.â€Â The Secretary-General also thanked CARICOM for highlighting the crucial issue of advancing gender parity, and its unwavering support for multilateralism.

title: After nearly a decade away, La NiÃ±a weather system is backâ€¦
text: According to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), La NiÃ±a is back in the central and eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean, after nearly a decadeâ€™s absence.#LaNiÃ±a will affects rainfall and temperature patterns in many parts of the world but it is not the only climate driver. WMO's new Global Seasonal Climate Update factors in other climate drivers as well human induced #ClimateChange https://t.co/tlZQDwUK59 pic.twitter.com/ttdiC70L1tThis is expected to result in sea surface temperatures between two and three degrees Celsius cooler than average, said Dr. Maxx Dilley, Deputy Director in charge of Climate Services Department at WMO.â€œThese coolings of these large ocean areas have a significant effect on the circulation of the atmosphere thatâ€™s flowing over them. And the changes in the atmosphere in turn affect precipitation patterns around the world.â€The likely results of La NiÃ±aÂ vary around the globe, but indications are that the Horn of Africa will see below average rainfall, as will Central Asia.Elsewhere, WMOâ€™s weather models forecast above-average rainfall for Southeast Asia, some Pacific Islands and the northern region of South America.The UN agency also warned that East Africa is forecast to see drier than usual conditions, which together with the existing impacts of the desert locust invasion, may add to regional food insecurity.WMO says that there is a 90 per cent chance of tropical Pacific sea surface temperatures remaining at La NiÃ±a levels for the remainder of the year, and a 55 per cent chance that this will continue through March next year.This is important because La NiÃ±a contributes to temperatures, rainfall and storm patterns in many parts of the world.Whatâ€™s more, everyone from governments to farmers uses the announcement of a La NiÃ±a event to protect activities that are sensitive to changes in the weather, including agriculture, health, water resources and disaster management.WMO is now stepping up its support and advice for international humanitarian agencies to try to reduce the impacts among the most vulnerable at a time when coping capacities are stretched by the COVID-19 pandemic.Although La NiÃ±a typically has a cooling effect on global temperatures, thereâ€™s little chance that 2020 will buck the trend of increasingly warm years, however.Thatâ€™s because of all the heat trapped in our atmosphere by greenhouse gases, said WMO head Petteri Taalas.And he warned that â€œ2020 remains on track to be one of the warmest years on record and 2016-2020 is expected to be the warmest five-year period on recordâ€.

title: Reduce risk to avert â€˜era of pandemicsâ€™, experts warn in new report
text: Their study stems from an urgent virtual workshop convened by the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) to investigate the links between pandemic risk and the degradation of nature.Â It finds that risk is increasing rapidly, with more than five new diseases emerging in people every year, any one of which could potentially spark a pandemic.Â COVID-19 is at least the sixth global health pandemic since the Great Influenza Pandemic of 1918, also known as the Spanish flu, the 22 experts said.Â They stressed that although the new disease has its origins in microbes carried by animals, like all pandemics, its emergence has been entirely driven by human activities.Â â€œThere is no great mystery about the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic â€“ or of any modern pandemicâ€, said Dr. Peter Daszak, President of EcoHealth Alliance and Chair of the IPBES workshop. Â â€œThe same human activities that drive climate change and biodiversity loss also drive pandemic risk through their impacts on our environment. Changes in the way we use land; the expansion and intensification of agriculture; and unsustainable trade, production and consumption disrupt nature and increase contact between wildlife.â€Â However, pandemic risk can be significantly lowered, the experts said, through greater conservation of protected areas, and other measures to reduce human activities that contribute to biodiversity loss.Â This will in turn reduce wildlife-livestock-human contact and help avert the spillover of new diseases.Â â€œThe overwhelming scientific evidence points to a very positive conclusionâ€, said Dr. Daszak. Â â€œWe have the increasing ability to prevent pandemics â€“ but the way we are tackling them right now largely ignores that ability. Our approach has effectively stagnated â€“ we still rely on attempts to contain and control diseases after they emerge, through vaccines and therapeutics. We can escape the era of pandemics, but this requires a much greater focus on prevention in addition to reaction.â€ Â The â€œbusiness as usualâ€ approach of relying on response to diseases after they emerge is a â€œslow and uncertain pathâ€, the experts charged, and can also threaten biodiversity.Â Furthermore, they estimate that economic impacts are 100 times the estimated cost of prevention.Â The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) is an independent body comprising more than 130 member Governments.However, the report hasÂ not been discussed and accepted by the IPBES plenary and is not, therefore, an intergovernmental product.Â Â It represents the expertise and evidence of the 22 experts who participated in the workshop.They said it is estimated thatÂ another 1.7 million unknown viruses currently exist in mammals and birds, up to 850,000 of which could potentially infect humans.Â â€œEscaping the era of pandemics is possibleâ€, the experts said, but will require â€œa seismic shiftâ€ in approach, from reaction to prevention.Â Their recommendations include establishing a high-level intergovernmental council on pandemic prevention, to provide decision-makers with the best science and evidence on emerging diseases; and to evaluate the potential economic impacts. Â Members would also coordinate the design of a global monitoring mechanism.Â Countries could also set mutually-agreed goals or targets under an international accord or agreement, with clear benefits for people, animals and the environment.Â The report also called for enabling changes to reduce the types of consumption, globalized agricultural expansion and trade that have led to pandemics, for example through taxes or levies on meat consumption, livestock production and other forms of high pandemic-risk activities.

title: UN builds momentum for restoring forests as world enters key decade for ecosystems
text: The world has made considerable progress in the past decade, according to the new edition of FAO's international forestry journalÂ Unasylva, entitledÂ Restoring the Earth - the next decade, since 63 countries, subnational governments and private organisationsÂ have already committed to restoring 173 million hectares, and regional responses are making significant advances in Africa and Latin America.Â The goal is to meet the â€œBonn Challengeâ€ -Â the worldâ€™s largest voluntary forest landscape restoration initiative, which was launched in 2011. It is a global target to bring 150 million hectares of degraded and deforested lands into restoration by 2020 and 350 million by 2030.Â Â â€œSocieties worldwide will need to be convinced of the global restoration imperative by rational economic argument, compassion for current and future generations, and an emotional connection to natureâ€,Â according to the authors of one article in the journal.Â TheÂ UnasylvaÂ issue looks at prospects for meeting the Bonn Challenge and mechanisms for measuring and accelerating progress, and examines work going on in China, Kenya, Brazil, Madagascar, Cambodia and Sao Tome and Principe.Â Â It also discusses how restoration work can be scaled up, including various initiatives that are underway to increase funding and boost local stakeholders and technical assistance.Â Â â€œThese have enormous potential to be mainstreamed because of their cost-effectiveness, adaptability, applicability to many ecosystems and contexts, and ease of implementationâ€,Â the opening editorial inÂ UnasylvaÂ said.Â Â Next year sees the start of the United NationsÂ Decade on Ecosystem Restoration,Â â€¯a rallying call for the protection and revival of ecosystems all around the world, which runs from 2021 until the deadline for the Sustainable Development GoalsÂ (SDGs)Â in 2030.Â â€œThere is a great opportunity for the Bonn Challenge process and its contributing regional platforms to provide a model for aspiring actors to embrace or reinforce restoration efforts in other ecosystems, such as wetlands and coral reefs,â€ senior officials at the â€¯International Union for Conservation of Nature wrote in one of the articles inÂ Unasylva.

title: UN chief hails Republic of Koreaâ€™s vow to achieve carbon neutrality
text: The UN chief was â€œvery encouragedâ€ by President Moon Jae-inâ€™s announcement on Wednesday of South Koreaâ€™s commitment to get to net zero emissions by this date, according to a statement issued by his Spokesperson.Â Secretary-General @antonioguterres encouraged by President Moon Jae-inâ€™s announcement of the Republic of Koreaâ€™s commitment to get to net zero emissions by 2050, joining a growing group of major economies committed to lead by example. https://t.co/4Ho1ajufiRâ€œWith this announcement the Republic of Korea, the world's 11th largest economy and sixth largest exporter, joins a growing group of major economies committed to lead by example in building a sustainable, carbon neutral and climate resilient world by 2050â€, the statement said.Â President Moon made the vow in a speech to the national assembly to â€œactively respondâ€ to climate change, in line with a $35 billion New Green Deal, announced in July, on ending investment in coal.Â The Secretary-General described it as â€œa very positive step in the right direction after Koreaâ€™s exemplary Green New Dealâ€, the statement continued.Â The announcement came just two days after Japan said it will get to net-zero emissions by 2050, which Mr. Guterres also welcomed.Â The UN chief has long made climate action a top priority of his tenure. Â Â Speaking to international finance ministers earlier this month, he called for countries to step up commitment to achieving carbon neutrality, in terms of harmful greenhouse gas emissions.Â He urged nations to submit more ambitious Nationally Determined Contributionsâ€¯(NDCs) spelling out action to reduce emissions and adapt to climate change, as required under the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change.Â The Secretary-Generalâ€¯is now looking forward to concrete policy measures that will be proposed and implemented by South Korea, the statement said.Â This includes submitting a revised NDC â€œwhich is more ambitious and consistent with its new commitment to carbon neutrality by 2050â€ in time for the next UN climate change conference, scheduled for next year.

title: 2020 Climate Action Award winners shine ray of hope
text: While COVID-19 is the worldâ€™s most clear and present danger, climate change is a menace that threatens all future generations, according to the head of the UN climate change convention.â€œThe last eight months have been a nightmare for many throughout the worldâ€, said UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Executive Secretary, Patricia Espinosa, pointing out that the pandemic has â€œaltered lives, economies and the nature of business on every continentâ€”from the largest cities to the smallest villagesâ€.Â From carbon neutral hotels ğŸ¨ and airports âœˆï¸ to all women solar teams â˜€ï¸, the UN Global #ClimateAction awards shine a light on some of the worldâ€™s most inspiring climate solutions. Find out more about this year's 13 winning projects from @UNFCCC:https://t.co/VqYfgkHUwG pic.twitter.com/7GgyYuBdR0And while it is â€œthe most urgent threat facing humanity todayâ€, she quickly added, â€œwe cannot forget that climate change is the biggest threat facing humanity over the long term.â€The UNFCCC chief attested that the convergence of these two crises has â€œopened a window of opportunity to build forward â€“ to build cities and communities that are safe, healthy, green and sustainableâ€.Â â€œNothing exemplifies this better than the efforts of our 2020 award-winning activities to address climate changeâ€, she upheld.This yearâ€™s award-winning projects demonstrate leadership on climate change by nations, businesses, investors, cities, regions and civil society as a whole.Â They range from the Caribbean's only carbon-neutral hotel, to the world's inaugural green bonds platform and the first all-women solar team in Lebanon.Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres congratulated the winners, saying that they â€œprovide tangible proof that climate action is under way around the worldâ€.â€œIt is exciting to see these climate solutions, which reinforce my call for decisive leadership on climate change by Governments, businesses and cities, and for a green recovery from the COVID-19 pandemicâ€, stated the UN chief. â€œLet us keep pressing ahead to build a more sustainable and equitable future for all".As Governments work toward implementing the Paris Climate Change Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the awards are part of a wider effort to mobilize climate action and ambition.Â They also set the stage for two upcoming climate change events. The Race To Zero Dialogues, from 9 to19 November, will serve as critical input to the UNFCCC Climate Dialogues to advance work governing the rules of the Paris Agreement, which runs from 23 November to 4 December.The UN Global Climate Action Awards are spearheaded by the Momentum for Change initiative at UN Climate Change and each project presents an innovative solution that both addresses climate change and helps drive progress on other SDGs.Â â€œIt is crucial we celebrate all actors who are leading the way,â€ said Gabrielle GinÃ©r, Chair of the Advisory Panel.Â â€œThe recipients of the UN Global Climate Action Awards send a strong political signal to all nations â€“ and through their leadership and creativity, we see essential changeâ€. The 2020 winning activities, selected by an international Advisory Panel, can be found here.

title: Exported used cars â€˜dumpedâ€™ on developing nations, driving up pollution, UN warns
text: The study â€“ the first-ever of its kind â€“ found that some 14 million used cars, vans and minibuses were exported worldwide from Europe, the United States and Japan between 2015 and 2018.Â The trade in used vehicles matters to ğŸ”µOur healthğŸŸ¡Our safetyğŸŸ¢Our planet ğŸŒğŸŒğŸŒğŸŸ£Our walletsLearn more in our new report: https://t.co/LI41dUH3Ak#BeatPollution pic.twitter.com/9xZiWJfOB1Around 80 per cent, went to low and middle income countries, with more than half going to Africa.Â â€œCleaning up the global vehicle fleet is a priority to meet global and local air quality and climate targetsâ€, said Inger Andersen, the UNEP Executive Director. Â â€œOver the years, developed countries have increasingly exported their used vehicles to developing countries; because this largely happens unregulated, this has become the export of polluting vehicles.â€Â Globally, the transport sector is responsible for nearly a quarter of all energy-related greenhouse gas emissions.Â Vehicle emissions are a significant source of the fine particulate matter and nitrogen oxides that are major causes of urban air pollution.Â The report is based on an in-depth analysis of some 146 countries. Â The authors found that two-thirds have â€œweakâ€ or â€œvery weakâ€ policies to regulate the import of vehicles past their prime.Â Poor quality second-hand autos also lead to more road accidents. Â Countries such as Malawi, Nigeria, Zimbabwe and Burundi, which have â€œweakâ€ or very weakâ€ used vehicle regulations, have very high road traffic death rates, according to UNEP.Â However, countries that implement age and emissions standards, or other such measures, receive high-quality used vehicles including hybrid and electric cars, and at an affordable rate. They also have fewer accidents on the road.Â Ms. Andersen said the lack of effective standards and regulation means that old, polluting and unsafe vehicles are effectively being dumped.Â â€œDeveloped countries must stop exporting vehicles that fail environment and safety inspections and are no longer considered roadworthy in their own countries, while importing countries should introduce stronger quality standardsâ€, she charged.Â Used Vehicles and the Environment - A Global Overview of Used Light Duty Vehicles: Flow, Scale and Regulation calls for action by both sides to adopt harmonized minimum quality standards.Â UNEP, with the support of the UN Road Safety Trust Fund, is part of an initiative towards this goal.Â The focus initially will be on Africa, where several countries have already implemented minimum quality standards, including Morocco, Algeria, CÃ´te d'Ivoire, Ghana and Mauritius. Â More have expressed interest in joining.

title: Africa climate change report reveals heat rising north and south, Sahel getting wetter
text: â€œIn recent months we have seen devastating floods, an invasion of desert locusts and now face the looming spectre of drought because of a La NiÃ±a event. The human and economic toll has been aggravated by the COVID-19 pandemic,â€ WMO Secretary-General PetteriÂ TaalasÂ said in a statement.Â The report aims to fill a gap in reliable and timely climate informationÂ forÂ Africa, which translates into a lack of climate-related development planning, said Vera Songwe, Under-Secretary-General,Â and Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for AfricaÂ (UNECA).Â At todays launch of the #StateofClimate in #Africa report, @FAOs @ZitouniOuldDada highlighted the importance of #data & the FAO  @googleearth #HandinHand initiative to increase farmers access to realtime weather data:https://t.co/JO3Jqg6tcc @WMO @_AfricanUnion @ECA_OFFICIAL pic.twitter.com/UpJM2oCWkXAfrica has been warming progressively since the start of the last century, and in the next five years,Â northern and southern Africa are set to get drier and hotter, while the Sahel region of Western Africa will get wetter,Â WMOâ€™s Regional Strategic Office Director,Â Filipe Lucio,Â told a press conference.Â Â â€œOverall, Africa needs to take action. Action is needed today in terms of adaptation, but also is needed tomorrow in terms of mitigationâ€, Lucio said.Â Â The agricultural sector is key to building climate resistance, since it is the dominant employer and it relies on the use of water and energy â€“ both heavily implicated in climate change, he said.Â Â Northern and southern areas under threat of aridity and desertification would benefit from reforestation, which helps to prevent water runoff and creates vegetation which supports the hydrological cycle.Â Policy changes are also recommended in transport, energy, infrastructure and industry. Financing has improved with the establishment of a UN-backedÂ Green Climate FundÂ but there are still limitations in terms of the continentâ€™s ability to tap into such funds, he added.Â Â Climate change has contributed to a jump in food insecurity, mosquito-borne disease and mass displacement in the past decade, and the rise in sea levels has led to unusual weather patterns such as Tropical CycloneÂ Idai, which hit Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe in 2019.Â Â It showed the need forÂ communitiesÂ toÂ learnÂ about the risks and for impact-based warnings about the appropriate actions to take.Â A day after the cyclone made landfall, it appeared to have dissipated and people thought the worst was over. But then disaster struck when flooding followed, overwhelmingÂ Mozambiqueâ€™s majorÂ portÂ city of Beira, Lucio said.Â Â â€œPeople were asked to find refuge in appropriateÂ placesÂ but the city of Beira was never built to withstand a category-5 tropical cyclone. So that means the building codes need to be changed, but the building codes cannot be changed using what tropical cyclones used to be like in the past.Â Â â€œThey need to have forward looking analysis to anticipate the trends into the future and start designing infrastructure and other systems taking into account the changing nature of these tropical cyclones.â€

title: FROM THE FIELD: Women guardians of the environment
text: Globally, countries are being encouraged to update their plans to curb climate change and restrict the increase in temperatures to at least two degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, a process which is being supported by UNDP.The impacts of a warming planet are being felt globally, as weather patterns become more unpredictable, and the frequency and intensity of disasters increase.The knowledge and leadership skills of women are being factored into the plans to reverse adverse climatic conditions; farmers in particular are considered to have a key role in introducing agricultural practices which are more favourable to the environment, and can help reduce the emission of harmful gasses, which are accelerating climate change.Read more here about how women are increasingly taking on the role of guardians of the environment.

title: FROM THE FIELD: Cultivating a response to disasters in Malawi
text: In recent years, East and Southern Africa have experienced an increase in floods, droughts and other severe and irregular climatic conditions which have wiped out crops and crippled the productivity of many farmers.But the UNDP and government-backed project is now providing three million Malawians with life-saving climate information and early warnings of extreme weather, as well as techniques they can adapt to grow crops which are more resilient to the change in climatic conditions.On the International Day for Disaster Risk Reduction read more here about how farmers are cultivating a new approach to the land.

title: Shift needed from what weather will be, to â€˜what the weather will doâ€™
text:
The State of Climate Services 2020 Report: Move from Early Warnings to Early Action, released on Tuesday by the UN World Meteorological Organization (WMO), underscored the need to switch to impact-based forecasting â€“ an evolution from â€œwhat the weather will beâ€ to â€œwhat the weather will doâ€ so that people and businesses can act early, based on the warnings.Â 
Being prepared and able to react at the right time, in the right place, can save many lives and protect the livelihoodsÂ â€“ WMO Secretary-General
â€œEarly warning systems constitute a prerequisite for effective disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation. Being prepared and able to react at the right time, in the right place, can save many lives and protect the livelihoods of communities everywhere,â€ Petteri Taalas, Secretary-General of WMO, said in a foreword to the report.Â He also highlighted that while it could take years to recover from the human and economic toll of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is crucial to remember that climate change will continue to pose an on-going and increasing threat to human lives, ecosystems, economies and societies for centuries to come.Â â€œRecovery from the COVID-19 pandemic is an opportunity to move forward along a more sustainable path towards resilience and adaptation in the light of anthropogenic climate change,â€ added Mr. Taalas.Â Globally over the past 50 years, some 11,000 disasters, attributed to weather, climate and water-related hazards, claimed over 2 million lives and cost the world economy $3.6 trillion, according to WMO.Â In 2018 alone, storms, floods, droughts and wildfires left some 108 million people in need of international humanitarian assistance. By 2030, this number could increase by almost 50 per cent at a cost of around $20 billion a year.Â In spite of the alarming figures, one in three people are still not adequately covered by early warning systems, with communities in Africa, least developed countries and small island developing States most affected, the UN agency added, citing challenges such as weak dissemination of early warning, inadequate observing networks, and insufficient capacity to translate early warning into early action.Â The report outlines six key recommendations to improve the implementation and effectiveness of early warning systems, globally:

title: UN chief urges ministers to provide â€˜decisive leadershipâ€™ on climate action
text:
Addressing the fourth Ministerial Meeting of the Coalition of Finance Ministers for Climate Action, via a video message, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres urged greater leadership and vision.â€œYour recovery plans will determine the course of the next 30 yearsâ€, he said.â€œWe need speed, scale, and decisive leadership. I count on this coalition to rise to the challenge.â€The meeting brought together top officials from around the world to discuss the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on fiscal policies related to climate change.The Secretary-General called on the ministers to serve as models and advocates for a green recovery, noting the need for governments to align COVID recovery and stimulus plans with the goals of the Paris Agreement on climate change.
We need speed, scale, and decisive leadership. I count on this coalition to rise to the challenge - UN chief Guterres
â€œThat means investing in green and decent jobs. Do not bail out polluting industries. End fossil-fuel subsidies. And take climate risks into account in all financial and policy decisionsâ€, said Mr. Guterres, welcoming steps to embed climate goals into macroeconomic policies and recovery measures.Alongside, the UN chief also called for sharp and permanentÂ cuts in greenhouse gas emissions.â€œCoal should not be part of any recovery plansâ€, he stressed.Mr. Guterres also called on finance ministers to commit to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, and to submit more ambitious nationally determined contributions before the 26th Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP26), to be held in Glasgow in November 2021, after being postponed this year due to the pandemic.â€œWe need all of you, through your NDCs and Net Zero plans, to send a clear and unambiguous signal to markets that the decarbonization of the global economy is inevitableâ€, he added, referring to theÂ Nationally Determined ContributionsÂ â€“ what each country will do to reduce national emissions and adapt to the impacts of climate change.Mr. Guterres also called on the ministers, together with central banks and financial regulators to ensure that every financial decision takes climate risks and opportunities into account.This includes improving the quality and quantity of climate-related financial disclosures, ensuring that the financial sector can measure and manage climate-related financial risks and creating approaches and frameworks for measuring portfolio alignment with the transition to net zero, he explained.In his address, the Secretary-General also underlined the importance of international cooperation and solidarity in recovery efforts.Noting their important role in national, regional and multilateral development finance institutions as well as in shaping their strategic direction, Mr. Guterres called on the finance ministers to use their â€œvoice and voting powerâ€ to ensure that by COP26, these institutions agree to align their policies, portfolios and pipelines with the 1.5-degree goal of the Paris Agreement.â€œThis will mean an end to new coal power plants and a phasing out of fossil fuel investments; more ambitious climate finance goals and targets; increased support for adaptation and resilience for the most vulnerable; and rapidly scaled up investments in renewable energy,â€ underlined Mr. Guterres.

title: â€˜Staggeringâ€™ rise in climate emergencies in last 20 years, new disaster research shows
text: In an urgentÂ call for countries toÂ prepare better forÂ allÂ catastrophic eventsÂ â€“ from earthquakes and tsunamis toÂ biologicalÂ threatsÂ such asÂ the new coronavirusÂ â€“Â data fromÂ the UN Office on Disaster Risk Reduction (UNDRR)Â indicatesÂ thatÂ wealthy nationsÂ have done little toÂ tackleÂ theÂ harmfulÂ emissionsÂ thatÂ are linked toÂ climateÂ threatsÂ whichÂ make up the bulk ofÂ disasters today.Â Disaster risk governance done well can be the difference between: life and death; being injured or being fit; having a roof over your head or being homeless. 13 October is #DRRday and #ItsAllAboutGovernance https://t.co/KrX0T3sbUp pic.twitter.com/hfa9IOe2UTâ€œDisaster management agencies have succeeded in saving many lives through improved preparedness and the dedication of staff and volunteers. But the odds continue to be stacked against them,Â in particular byÂ industrial nations that are failing miserably on reducing greenhouse gas emissions,â€ said MamiÂ Mizutori, UNDRRÂ chief,Â andÂ Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Disaster Risk Reduction.Â According to the UNDRR report - produced with Belgiumâ€™s Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters atÂ UCLouvainÂ -Â thereÂ wereÂ 7,348Â recordedÂ disaster eventsÂ worldwide, during the last two decades.Â Approximately 1.23 millionÂ people diedÂ â€“Â approximatelyÂ 60,000 perÂ yearÂ â€“ with more than fourÂ billionÂ affected in total;Â manyÂ more than once.Â Â These two decades ofÂ disasterÂ alsoÂ causedÂ $2.97 trillionÂ inÂ lossesÂ to the global economy, with data also indicating that poorer nationsÂ experienced deaths ratesÂ more than four times higher than richer nations.Â By comparison, the previous 20-year periodÂ (1980 to 1999)Â sawÂ 4,212Â reportedÂ disastersÂ fromÂ natural hazards,Â withÂ 1.19 millionÂ deaths, more than threeÂ billion peopleÂ affected and economic lossesÂ totallingÂ $ 1.63 trillion.Â Although better recording and reporting of disasters may help explain some of the increaseÂ in the last two decades,Â researchers insisted that theÂ significant rise in climate-relatedÂ emergencies wasÂ theÂ mainÂ reasonÂ for the spike, with floods accounting forÂ more than 40Â per centÂ of disastersÂ â€“ affecting 1.65 billion people -Â storms 28 per cent,Â earthquakesÂ (eight per cent) and extreme temperatures (six per cent).Â â€œThis is clear evidence that in a world where the global average temperature in 2019 was 1.1Â degreesÂ Celsius above the pre-industrial period, the impacts are being felt in the increased frequency of extreme weather events including heatwaves, droughts, flooding, winter storms, hurricanes and wildfires,â€ UNDRR reportedÂ .Â DespiteÂ the pledge madeÂ by the international communityÂ inÂ Paris inÂ 2015Â to reduce global temperature rise to 1.5Â degreesÂ Celsius above pre-industrial levels, Ms.Â MizutoriÂ added that it was â€œbafflingâ€ that nationsÂ wereÂ continuingÂ knowinglyÂ â€œto sow the seeds of our own destruction, despite the science and evidence that we are turning our only home into an uninhabitable hell for millions of peopleâ€.Â Turning toÂ theÂ COVID-19Â pandemic, which has â€œlaid bare many shortcomings in disaster risk managementÂ (despite)Â repeated warningsâ€, theÂ UNDRRÂ reportÂ recommended urgent action from GovernmentsÂ toÂ betterÂ manageÂ suchÂ overlappingÂ disasters.Â TheseÂ hazardsÂ includedÂ known â€œrisk driversâ€,Â such as poverty, climate change, air pollution, population growth inÂ dangerousÂ locations, uncontrolled urbanization and the loss of biodiversity.Â By way ofÂ anÂ exampleÂ of chronicÂ weatherÂ risksÂ whichÂ should be the focus ofÂ betterÂ nationalÂ preparednessÂ measures,Â the agency pointed that shifting rainfall patterns pose a risk to the 70Â per centÂ of global agriculture thatÂ relies on rainÂ and the 1.3 billion people dependent on degrading agricultural land.Â Â Despite the fact thatÂ extreme weather events have become so regular in last 20 years, onlyÂ 93 countries haveÂ implementedÂ disaster riskÂ strategiesÂ at a national levelÂ ahead of the end-of-year deadline, Ms.Â MizutoriÂ said.Â â€œDisasterÂ risk governance depends on political leadership above all, andÂ delivery on the promises made when the Paris agreement andÂ the Sendai FrameworkÂ for Disaster Risk Reduction were adopted,â€ she said.Â â€œBut the sad fact is that we are wilfully destructive.Â And that is the conclusion of this report; COVID-19 is but the latest proof that politicians and business leaders have yet to tune into the world around them.â€Â She added:Â â€œIt really is all about governance if we want to deliver this planet from the scourge of poverty, further loss of species and biodiversity, the explosion of urban risk and the worst consequences of global warmingâ€,Â in a joint statement withÂ UCLouvainâ€™sÂ ProfessorÂ DebaratiÂ Guha-Sapir.Â Although the UNDRR report indicatesÂ that there has beenÂ some success inÂ protecting vulnerable communitiesÂ fromÂ isolated hazards,Â thanks toÂ more effectiveÂ early warningÂ systems, disaster preparedness and response,Â projected global temperature rises could make theseÂ improvements â€œobsoleteÂ in many countriesâ€,Â the agencyÂ warned.Â Currently, the worldÂ isÂ on course for a temperature increase of 3.2Â degrees CelsiusÂ or more,Â unless industrialisedÂ nationsÂ canÂ deliver reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of at least 7.2Â per centÂ annually over the nextÂ 10Â years in order to achieve the 1.5Â degreeÂ target agreed in Paris.

title: Greening of India's railway network on track
text:
With over 68,000 kilometres of track and serving over a mind-boggling eight billion passengers a year, Indian Railways is vast and amongst the most complicated and involved transport systems in the world.And, perhaps not surprisingly, moving hundreds of thousands of passengers each day across tens of thousands of kilometres of network requires enormous amounts of energy, energy which in the past has often been provided by burning polluting fossil fuels. Those fuels have been identified as one of the key drivers of climate change.Indiaâ€™s transport sector contributes to 12 per cent of the countryâ€™s harmful climate-inducing gas emissions with railways accounting for about 4 per cent of that. One solution is to actually use the railways more and road transport less. Indian railways has committed to increasing the amount of freight transported by rail from about 35 per cent in 2015 to 45 per cent by 2030.Even though it takes a lot of fuel to move a train, passenger and freight-mile emissions are much lower than levels recorded by vehicle traffic.â€œDue to economic development and increased consumption, there is an increasing demand on the resources,â€ said Vinod Kumar Yadav, Chairman of the Railways Board.The Indian Government has been working on greening the railways, with over half of the network electrified, and a target to electrify the entire network in the next three to four years. Electrification would introduce a more centralized, efficient power system and make higher emitting diesel engines redundant.â€œWe need to take care of the environmental concerns along with the economic development to ensure sustainabilityâ€™, said Mr. Yadav. â€œIndian Railways has embarked on a mission to improve energy efficiency and replace fossil fuel sources with renewable energy sources like solar and wind to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2030â€.Reaching that goal would mean eliminating emissions of 7.5 million tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO2) each year, about the same as two coal power plants.The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has been supporting the efforts of Indian Railways, providing advice and training on sustainability and the green economy.Â Atul Bagai, Head of UNEPâ€™s India Office, said, â€œIndiaâ€™s rail network has long been an integral part of the countryâ€™s societal fabric. Greening the railways not only is vital to achieve the Governmentâ€™s climate objectives but is also an important symbol of Indiaâ€™s environmental initiative. UNEP is proud to assist these efforts through training and other support.â€Emissions from power generation are only one part of the equation. Indian Railways is also looking to make stations and installations green-certified. Over 100 water treatment and recycling plants have been established.And, in a unique development, the railroad operator has fitted long-distance coaches with bio tanks to deal with human waste from passengers. These bio tanks may prevent emissions of up to 155 tonnes of CO2 annually.
With more people and more freight set to ride the rails as Indiaâ€™s economy grows, it will be more important than ever to ensure that the future of Indiaâ€™s renowned rail network is sustainable.

SudanÂ isÂ thatÂ largeÂ areasÂ of farmlandÂ are under water orÂ ruinedÂ just before harvest.Â  â€œMost families in Sudan already spent around 65 per cent of their income on food, so these price hikes lead to increased hunger and less education, health and other services that families de-prioritize as they try to cope with the economic hardshipâ€,Â Mr.Â LaerkeÂ explained.Â The UN population fund
