title: At Davos, UN chief urges â€˜big emittersâ€™ to take climate action
text: The UN chiefÂ observed that while many smaller developing countries and the European Union have committed to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, â€œthe big emittersâ€ have yetÂ to act.Â Â I'm in Davos to deliver a strong message on #ClimateAction. While our planet is burning, too many decision makers are fiddling. Every city, region, bank, pension fund & industry must completely reimagine how they operate and invest to avoid a point of no return. #WEF20If the big emitters do not rallyÂ around theÂ principle of achievingÂ carbon neutralityÂ byÂ 2050,Â â€œwe will be doomed because they represent a very important shareâ€,Â the UN chief said.Â Â Â Â â€œThe G20 representsÂ 80 per cent of the emissions that contribute to climate change.â€Â Â Â Â Mr. Guterres saidÂ GovernmentsÂ can take stepsÂ to help move the world towards a greener future,Â such as cutting subsidies for fossil fuels.Â â€œAs a taxpayer, I canâ€™t really accept the idea that my taxes are used to boost hurricanes, or to bleach coral, or to melt glaciersâ€,Â he stated.Â Â For theÂ Secretary-General, climate change is the defining issue of our time, representing an â€œexistential threatâ€ to the entire planet and threatening development.Â Mr. Guterres said he isÂ encouraged by private sector commitment to the environment,Â as evidenced byÂ increasing numbers of financialÂ institutions and asset managersÂ making carbon neutrality a priorityÂ in their investments.Â Similarly, cities, voters and young people have been mobilizingÂ for action.Â Â â€œI am hopeful that it will be possible to mobilize both the private sector and public authorities in orderÂ to take transformational decisions in theÂ wayÂ we produceÂ ourÂ food, powerÂ our economy, move, support industry and plan our citiesÂ -Â theÂ transformational changes that are necessaryÂ for us,Â to reach the objectives that theÂ scientific community tells us itÂ is absolutely essential to doâ€,Â he said.

title: UN chief outlines solutions to defeat â€˜four horsemenâ€™ threatening our global future
text: In a wide-rangingÂ speechÂ to the General Assembly,Â the UNÂ chief outlinedÂ strategiesÂ to addressÂ what he called theÂ â€œfour horsemenÂ in our midstâ€, and heÂ urged countries to take advantage of the UNâ€™s 75thÂ anniversaryÂ year to secure a peaceful future for all people.Â â€œThese four horsemenâ€¦can jeopardize every aspect of our shared futureâ€,Â Mr. Guterres warned.Â â€œThat is why commemorating the 75th anniversary with nice speeches wonâ€™t do.Â  We must address these four 21st-century challenges with four 21st-century solutions.â€Â Geopolitical tensions.The climate crisis.Global mistrust.The dark side of technology.These "four horsemen" are looming threats in the 21st century.To meet them, we need a UN fit for the challenges of our age.https://t.co/IFt3pBfv30 pic.twitter.com/RmP6shuDb6For the Secretary-General, global tensionsÂ are at their highest level in years,Â makingÂ the risk of fractureÂ real.Â AlthoughÂ developments such as the formation of theÂ ConstitutionalÂ Committee in Syria and the recent Berlin conference on Libya are signs of hope,Â heÂ stressedÂ thatÂ â€œwe have our work cut out for usâ€.Â Mr. Guterres underlined theÂ centralÂ role of preventionÂ in UNÂ engagementÂ in theÂ peaceÂ and securityÂ dimension, andÂ emphasized the need toÂ focus on the root causes of crisis and upheaval.Â â€œWe must strengthen our mediation capacity and our tools for sustaining peace, leading to long-term developmentâ€,Â he added.Â â€œWe need to create the conditions for effective peace enforcement and counter-terrorism operations by our regional partners, under chapter VII of the Charter and with predictable funding.Â This is especially true in Africa, from the Sahel to Lake Chad.â€Â On climate change, the science is clear, Mr. Guterres stated.Â Â â€œRising temperatures continue to melt records.Â  The past decade was the hottest on record.Â  Scientists tell us that ocean temperatures are now rising at the equivalent of five Hiroshima bombs a second.Â  One million species are in near-term danger of extinction.Â Our planet is burningâ€,Â he told ambassadors.Â Yet,Â in the midst ofÂ the crisis,Â some leaders â€œcontinue to fiddleâ€, he said,Â as evidenced by the outcome of theÂ lastÂ UN climate conference, known as COP25,Â held in Madrid in December.Â ButÂ the Secretary-GeneralÂ is adamant that the climate battle can be wonÂ as peopleÂ everywhereÂ â€œget itâ€,Â whileÂ the overwhelming majority ofÂ scientistsÂ are clearÂ there is still time to act.Â â€œAt the next climate conference -Â COP26 in Glasgow - governments must deliver the transformational change our worldÂ needsÂ and that people demand, with much stronger ambition â€“ ambition on mitigation, ambition on adaptation, and ambition on finance,â€ he stated.Â The third horsemanâ€”deep and growing global mistrustâ€”can be defeated throughÂ fair globalization, boosting economic growth and preventing conflict.Â Back in 2015, world leaders adoptedÂ an agendaÂ to bringÂ about aÂ more just and fairÂ planetÂ for all.Â  This year,Â theÂ UNÂ hasÂ launched aÂ Decade of ActionÂ to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by the 2030 deadline.Â â€œThroughout the Decade of Action, we must invest in the eradication of poverty, in social protection, in health and fighting pandemics, in education, energy, water and sanitation, in sustainable transport and infrastructure and in internet accessâ€,Â said the Secretary-General.Â â€œWe must improve governance, tackle illicit financial flows, stamp out corruption and develop effective, common sense and fair taxation systems. We must build economies for the future and ensure decent work for all, especially young people. And we must put a special focus on women and girls because it benefits us all.â€Â The Secretary-GeneralÂ also encouraged leaders to workÂ to rebuild trust, including through listening to theirÂ citizensÂ and harnessing ideas for change and other constructive solutions put forward by youth.Â Bringing light to the dark side of the digital worldÂ will require action on several fronts, including in theÂ labourÂ market as automation will displace tens of millions of jobs in the next decade.Â The UN chief recommended that education systems be redesigned to address this reality by teaching people how to learn across the course of their entire lives.Â â€œWe also mustÂ usher in order to the Wild West of cyberspace,â€ he said.Â â€œTerrorists, white supremacists and others who sow hate are exploitingÂ the internet and social media.Â Bots are spreading disinformation, fueling polarization and undermining democracies.Â Next year, cybercrimeÂ willÂ cost $6 trillion.â€Â Mr. Guterres highlighted the UN as the platform to bring together governments, the private sector, civil society and others to counter what he called â€œdigital fragmentationâ€ through global cooperation.Â The â€œalarming possibilitiesâ€Â of artificial intelligence also must be addressed, and he appealed to countries to immediately ban lethal autonomous weapons, also known as killer robots.Â â€œLethal autonomous weaponsÂ -Â machines with the power to kill on their own, without human judgement and accountabilityÂ -Â are bringing us into unacceptable moral and political territoryâ€,Â heÂ warned.

title: UN human rights ruling could boost climate change asylum claims
text: The historic rulingÂ marks the first decision by a UN human rights treaty bodyÂ based on a complaint filed byÂ an individual seeking protection from the effects of climate change.Â Historic case opens door to #ClimateChange asylum claims â¡ï¸ UN #HRCttee finds that countries may not deport individuals who face climate change-induced conditions that violate the right to life.ğŸ‘‰ https://t.co/bU6UsB56AY#ICCPR pic.twitter.com/KynQvNFbcYIoaneÂ TeitotaÂ from the Pacific island nation of KiribatiÂ lodgedÂ the complaint in 2015 after being deported from New Zealand when his asylum application was denied.Â Mr.Â TeitotaÂ argued thatÂ his right to lifeÂ had been violated,Â asÂ rising sea levelsÂ and otherÂ destructiveÂ effects of climate change had made his homelandÂ uninhabitable.Â Â He said he was forced to migrate from the island of Tarawa,Â to New Zealand,Â due to impacts such asÂ a lack ofÂ freshwater due to saltwater intrusion, erosion of arable land,Â andÂ associatedÂ violent land disputes whichÂ hadÂ resulted in numerous fatalities.Â While the UN Committee determined thatÂ Mr.Â Teitotaâ€™sÂ right to life had not been violated asÂ sufficientÂ protection measures had been implemented in Kiribati, member YuvalÂ ShanyÂ said:Â â€œNevertheless,Â this ruling sets forth new standards that could facilitate the success of future climate change-related asylum claims.â€Â The Committee further clarified that people seeking asylum are not required to prove that they would face immediate harm,Â if deportedÂ backÂ to their home countries.Â Their rationale was that because climate-related events can occur both suddenlyÂ -Â such as intense storms or floodingÂ -Â or over time through slow-onset processes such as sea level rise and land degradation, either situation could spur people to seek safety elsewhere.Â Additionally, Committee members underlined that the international communityÂ must assist countries adversely affected by climate change.

title: East Africa locusts threaten food security across subregion, alerts UN agriculture agency
text: Destroying hundreds of thousands of acres of crops, the outbreak is impacting the regionâ€™s food insecurity. The UN agency urged for a collective campaign to deal with the crisis, concerned over the risk that the swarms spill over into more countries in East Africa, â€œif efforts to deal with the voracious pest are not scaled up across the regionâ€.Â  Moreover, unusual climate conditions have favoured rapid locust reproduction. The agency stressed that as favourable breeding conditions continue, the increase in locust swarms could last until June. And left unchecked, the numbers of crop-devouring insects could grow 500 fold by then. Kenya has not faced a locust threat of this magnitude in 70 years, FAO warned. The outbreak of desert locusts, considered the most dangerous locust species, has also affected parts of Somalia and Ethiopia, the likes ofÂ  which have not been seen on this scale in 25 years. South Sudan and Uganda are not currently affected, but are at risk, FAO added. In a press release issued on Monday, FAO Director-General QU Dongyu said the agency is activating fast-track mechanisms to support governments, warning that the situation is now of â€œinternational dimensionsâ€. Â "Authorities in the region have already jump-started control activities, but in view of the scale and urgency of the threat, additional financial backing from the international donor community is needed so they can access the tools and resources required to get the job done," Mr. Qu said. Swarms potentially containing hundreds of millions of individual desert locusts can move 150 kilometres a day â€“ devastating rural livelihoods. According to the UN agency, â€œgiven the scale of the current swarms, aerial control is the only effective means to reduce the locust numbersâ€. FAO is assisting with forecasts, early warning and alerts on the timing, scale and location of invasions and breeding. Mr. Qu also warned the response must include efforts to restore peopleâ€™s livelihoods."Communities in Eastern Africa have already been impacted by extended droughts, which have eroded their capacities to grow food and make a living. We need to help them get back on their feet, once the locusts are gone," FAOâ€™s Director General said.The UN is seeking $70 million to urgently support both pest control and livelihood protection operations in the three most affected countries.In addition, numerous desert locust swarms have been breeding in India, Iran and Pakistan since June 2019. And some have migrated to southern Iran where recent heavy rains have nurtured a breeding ground that could generate swarms in the spring.Egypt, Eritrea, Saudi Arabia, Sudan and Yemen are also seeing substantial breeding activity that could see locust bands expand into swarms in the coming months, FAO added. The agency concluded that it stands ready to leverage its expertise and facilitate a coordinated response.

title: Climate crisis â€˜affecting quality of life and fuelling discontentâ€™
text:
The UN economic experts behind the report are unequivocal in their call for â€œmassive adjustmentsâ€ to the energy sector, which is currently responsible for around three-quarters of global greenhouse gas emissions. If the world continues to rely on fossil fuels over the next few years, and emissions in developing countries rise to the level of those in richer nations, global carbon emissions would increase by more than 250 per cent, with potentially catastrophic results.The reportâ€™s authors insist that the worldâ€™s energy needs must be met by renewable or low-carbon energy sources, which will lead to environmental and health benefits, such as lower air pollution, and new economic opportunities for many countries.However, the 2020 WESP finds that the urgent need to switch to clean energy continues to be underestimated, noting that countries are continuing to invest in oil and gas exploration, and coal-fired power generation (read our story on the the move away from coal here).This reliance on fossil fuels is described as â€œshort-sightedâ€, leaving investors and governments exposed to sudden losses, as the price of oil and gas fluctuates, as well as contributing to deteriorating climatic conditions, such as global warming.â€œRisk associated with the climate crisis are becoming an ever-greater challengeâ€, concludes the report, and â€œclimate action must be an integral part of any policy mixâ€.Strategies and technology for a transition to a clean economy that delivers accessible to reliable and decarbonized energy already exist, continues the report, but will require political will and public support. Failure to act will significantly increase the ultimate costs.The East Asia region continues to be the worldâ€™s fastest growing region, with Chinaâ€™s economy growing at a rate of 6.1 per cent in 2019. Although growth is expected to level off, China will still see world-beating growth of 5.9 per cent by 2021. The more economically developed parts of the world are seeing much slower growth, with the USA expected to see a slowdown from 2.2 per cent in 2019, to 1.7 per cent in 2020. The European Union is only expected to grow by 1.6 per cent, although this is an improvement on 2019, when the bloc only grew by 1.4 per cent. The sluggish growth in both regions is blamed mainly on global uncertainty.Africa, meanwhile, continues to suffer from near stagnation. In a third of developing countries dependent on commodities, including Angola, Nigeria and South Africa, average real incomes are lower today than they were in 2014 and, in several sub-Saharan African countries, the number of people living in extreme poverty has risen.Although the report assumes that trade tension will ease, the potential for a relapse is high, says the report, as the root causes behind disputes have not yet been tackled.Continuing weak growth in the global economy will make it harder to achieve the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The Agenda, the UNâ€™s blueprint for a better future for people and the planet, includes commitments to eradicate poverty and create decent jobs for all.It is produced annually by the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA), the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and the five UN regional commissions (Africa, Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean, Asia and the Pacific, and Western Asia).
On the launch of the WESP, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned of the potential impacts of a slowdown: â€œThese risks could inflict severe and long-lasting damage on development prospects. They also threaten to encourage a further rise in inward-looking policies, at a point when global cooperation is paramountâ€.The authors of the 2020 WESP conclude that it is not enough to simply focus on economic growth, at any cost, and governments must ensure that growth is inclusive.â€œPolicymakers should move beyond a narrow focus on merely promoting GDP growth, and instead aim to enhance well-being in all parts of societyâ€, said Elliott Harris, UN Chief Economist and Assistant Secretary-General for Economic Development. Â In order to improve well-being for all, Mr. Harris emphasizes the importance of prioritizing investment in sustainable development to promote education, renewable energy, and resilient infrastructure, and called for governments to pay closer attention to the implications of their policies on the environment, and a fairer distribution of wealth within their countries.

title: 2019 second hottest year on record, UN confirms
text: â€œThe average global temperature has risen by about 1.1Â°C since the pre-industrial era and ocean heat content is at a record level,â€Â saidÂ WMO Secretary-General PetteriÂ Taalas.Â Â WMO confirms that 2019 is 2nd warmest year on record, based on consolidated data from @NASAGISS, @NOAA, @metoffice, @CopernicusECMWF and Japan Meteorological Agency https://t.co/M2TrSOKEld#StateofClimate #ClimateChange pic.twitter.com/5nplGy5I60â€œOn the current path of carbon dioxide emissions, we are heading towards a temperature increase of 3 to 5 degrees Celsius by the end of century.â€Â WMO analysisÂ showedÂ the annual global temperature in 2019 wasÂ 1.1Â°C warmerÂ than in the period from 1850-1900, or the pre-industrial era.Â Only 2016 was hotter, due to a very strong El NiÃ±oÂ which causes warming, combined with long-term climate change.Â Furthermore, average temperatures for the past five years and 10 years, respectively, were the highest on record.Â Since the 1980s, each decade has been warmer than the previous one: a trend the UN agency expects will continue due to the record level of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.Â Â WMOÂ added thatÂ 2019 and the past decade also were characterized by retreating ice, record sea levels, increasing ocean heat and acidification, and extreme weather, all of which haveÂ â€œmajor impactsâ€ on human health and the natural environment.Â Meanwhile, the New Year began where 2019 left off, according to Mr.Â Taalas.Â â€œAustralia had its hottest, driest year on record in 2019, setting the scene for the massive bushfires which were so devastating to people and property, wildlife, ecosystems and the environment,â€ he said.Â â€œUnfortunately, we expect to see much extreme weather throughout 2020 and the coming decades,Â fuelledÂ by record levels of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.â€

title: Capacity of cities to tackle climate change key in â€˜crucial battleâ€™ for planetâ€™s preservation, says UN chief
text: NatureÂ hasÂ respondedÂ toÂ thisÂ â€œsuicide warâ€ many times,Â â€œas we have seen through hurricanes, fires, and severe drought in various regions of the world,â€Â Mr. Guterres told the ceremony, at which the European CommisionÂ honouredÂ Lisbonâ€™s push for a green transformation that could serve as a role-model for other European cities.Â But the UN chief stressed thatÂ no matter how much harmÂ we do toÂ theÂ Earth, â€œit will continue to spin around the sun for millions of years.â€ TheÂ realÂ problem is that â€œhumanity is destroying itself,Â and the possibility of being able to live on the planet,â€Â he explained.Â Congratulations to Lisbon - Europeâ€™s Green Capital for 2020. Iâ€™m very proud of the transformation my hometown has undertaken to become a more sustainable, inclusive and green economy. The future for all economies. pic.twitter.com/voTghk8ow3Mr. GuterresÂ emphasizedÂ that in the â€œcrucial battle for the preservation of the planet,Â andÂ above all,Â for the preservation of our presence in the planetâ€ are two essential factors: the capacity of the cities and the European commitment to reach carbon neutrality by 2050.Â Â Highlighting that cities have half of the world population, two thirds of the European population, and account for 70Â per centÂ of greenhouse gas emissions,Â the Secretary-GeneralÂ said: â€œCities can be the basis of our success.â€Â Â As forÂ the European commitment to reach carbon neutrality by 2050,Â he stated thatÂ â€œour hope is that Europe will lead the example and convince otherÂ super powersÂ to enter the right path to defeat climate changeâ€.Â In his remarks,Â Mr. GuterresÂ alsoÂ spotlightedÂ 2020Â asÂ the year to make the fight against climate change more efficient. He identified three opportunities to start breaking the â€œcycle of war, which we are waging against natureâ€:Â The Secretary-GeneralÂ pointed out that these major events will take place during Lisbonâ€™s presidency as the Green Capital of Europe,Â and at a timeÂ when threeÂ majorÂ battles are being lost:Â one millionÂ of the Earthâ€™sÂ species are at risk of disappearing;Â pollutionÂ is increasing, especially plastics in the ocean; more efforts are needed to ensureÂ theÂ Paris AgreementÂ is an effective tool to fight climate change.Â The Secretary-General, however, expressed optimism because the international community knows what needs to be done.Â Â Â There is â€œno reason to continue to rely on fossil fuels,â€™â€™ when other technologies already exist. He also stressed that another hopeful development is the growing mobilization of youthÂ who areÂ demandingÂ theÂ â€œpolitical will to drive these transformations.â€Â â€œWe see cities defending the environment, defending a green perspective and fighting against climate change,â€Â he continued.Â Mentioning C40, the network of the worldâ€™s megacities committed to climate action, Mr. Guterres praised the cities that are the most determined to fight the battle against climate change.Â Â â€œThose cities are available to do everything that is necessary to guarantee that we can defeat climate change. The problem is that often governmentsÂ [hinder]Â their action and the action of the regions in achieving a green economy, in leading an effective battle against climate change,â€ the Secretary-General added.Â This article was originally published by UNRIC, the UN Regional Information Centre in Brussels, and can be found here.

title: Inaction over climate emergency â€˜not an optionâ€™ says UN Assembly chief
text: Tijani Muhammad-BandeÂ was addressing the International Organization for Renewable Energy High-Level meeting on theÂ particular threatÂ faced by Small Island Developing States, or SIDS, and their partners in development.Â â€œInaction will put at risk all life on earth as we know itâ€, warned the veteran Nigerian diplomat.Â â€œInaction will only lead to more severe and extreme weather events, land degradation and deforestation, loss of biodiversity, pollution and acidification of oceans, global food insecurity as well as drought and floods.â€Â More than 1,500 delegates including senior ministers, heads of international and regional organizations together with finance leaders and private sector executives are meeting for the 10thÂ session of the International Renewable Energy Agency Assembly (IRENA), in the United Arab Emirates.Â â€œDespite our collective disappointment with the international communityâ€™s inability to reach consensus on vital issues during the last Climate Change Conference (COP 25), we are here to chart a way forward, with respect to a related matter: renewable energy,â€ said Mr. Muhammad-Bande.Â â€œInaction will lead to continued sea level rise, risking the displacement of 280 million people from coastal areas and islands by 2050â€, he reminded the session.Â â€œClimate change is the single greatest security and development threat facing SIDS, despite this being a crisis not of their making.Â SIDS are bearing the climate crisisâ€™ most immediate and most severe consequences, including greater recurrenceÂ of devastating natural disasters that erase development gains and create additional debt burdens.â€Â He noted that rising sea levels put the low-lying nations and their entire infrastructure at risk, literally eating away territory,Â â€œwith some states at risk of being partially or fully submerged in the not too distant future.â€Â The international community mustÂ â€œexert all effortsâ€Â to ensure thatÂ the civilizations that have settled on small island States for often thousands of years,Â â€œare not only safeguarded but thrive in the futureâ€, he added.Â Climate change is indifferent to borders and is thus not amenable to â€˜nationalâ€™ solutions. We are all in this together.â€Â The General Assemblyâ€™s top official told the room that â€œwe are duty-bound to ensure that no one is left behind, and that we reach the farthest left behind first. Commitments to assist in funding the SDGs, including climate action, have been reiterated. Sadly, action has lagged far behind. We need to reverse this before it is too late for our SIDS brothers and sisters, and indeed for us all.â€Â SIDS were a key focus during Septemberâ€™s opening week of the Assembly, when a high-level summit was convened to discuss their vulnerability, and the search for solutions, on theÂ fronlineÂ of the climate crisis.Â Â â€œSmall Island Developing States are a special case for sustainable development, said the UN chief,Â AntÃ³nio Guterres, during the late September meeting. Theyâ€¯requireâ€¯theâ€¯concerted long-term attention and investmentâ€¯of the entire international communityâ€,Â he said.Â Mr. Muhammad-BandeÂ said that despite all the challenges, SIDS are still leading the way in implementing their ambitious Nationally Determined ContributionsÂ (NDCs)Â under theÂ 2015Â Paris AgreementÂ to limit climate change to well below 2 degrees Celsius.Â â€œIt is the international community that is now required to do more to support and match their efforts, including by facilitating concessionary financing for SIDSâ€™ adaptation and mitigation initiatives.Â IRENAâ€™s work, as one of the custodians of â€˜SDG 7: Sustainable Energy for Allâ€™, is vital for its implementation and a just transition to the new green economy globallyâ€, he added.Â Â â€œTime is running out for the woman losing her livelihood to climate-induced desertification; for the child who will have to abandon her home to a rapidly-rising sea level; and for the communities that will have to build back only to be washed away again.â€

title: Australia bushfire crisis: UNICEF offers help and support
text:
While acknowledging â€œthe selflessness, professionalism and dedicationâ€ of first responders and all organizations working on the ground, UNICEF issued a statement on Monday extending its condolences to the children and families affected by the fires that continue to devastate the country. Flagging its experience in providing crucial long-term support to children across the world through the three stages of relief, recovery and rehabilitation, UNICEF expressed it â€œvery real desireâ€ to assist Australia.â€œUNICEF has significant expertise and experience globally in responding to emergencies, including natural disastersâ€, the statement said. â€œFrom decades of work with millions of people around the world, we know that children are always among the most vulnerable in circumstances such as theseâ€. In many situations, UNICEF added that climate change is making scenarios â€œworse and more enduringâ€. â€œOur recent experience in working with children and young people affected by the drought in New South Wales brings this current bushfire crisis into sharp focus and that is why UNICEF Australia is currently prioritizing internal resources, speaking with partners and other agencies to ensure that we can continue to be a back-up to first-responders and committing support where possible to the immediate and long term needs of childrenâ€, the statement spelled out.UNICEF upheld the vital importance that children who have lived through disasters â€œreturn to normal life as quickly as possibleâ€, which is best done by resuming their education. â€œIn the longer term it is also vital that the views of children are taken into consideration when decisions are being madeâ€, which is why UNICEF Australia has been in discussion with the Fundâ€™s international offices, and other local organizations and government agencies â€œto plan the provision of our support and expertise into the futureâ€.As the situation continues to unfold, needs are yet to be fully determined. While a needs assessment is pending, key initiatives are likely to include assisting relief partners, said UNICEF, so that affected children may to return to school, provide them with psychosocial support and convene forums to ensure childrenâ€™s voices shape future responses.Pointing out that in addition to those children who have been directly affected, the agency is also highly concerned for those children witnessing traumatic events relating to the bushfires through media and social media. 
We encourage all parents to consider talking to their children about what is happening and to take steps to make their children feel safeÂ Â â€“Â UNICEF
â€œWe encourage all parents to consider talking to their children about what is happening and to take steps to make their children feel safeâ€, UNICEF stated.On top of the toll taken on human lives and the destruction of thousands of homes, the months-long blazes have also killed millions of animals. Acknowledging that it may be a difficult time for some of its regular supporters directly affected or living in or near bushfire-affected areas, UNICEF Australia encouraged them to suspend donations to ensure they have the means to provide for their families.â€œThe recovery process from such an unprecedented disaster will take a long time and UNICEF Australia calls for more child-centred responses and for the needs of children to continue to be prioritizedâ€, the statement continued. As disaster response and planning should include childrenâ€™s views and experiences, UNICEF Australia â€œintends to ensure that children who have been affected by this disaster are consulted as a consequence, and their views and opinions taken to decision makersâ€.

title: Stop escalation, urges UN chief, as geopolitical tensions reach â€˜highest level this centuryâ€™
text: The New Year has begun with our world in turmoil. We are living in dangerous timesâ€, said the UN chief, noting that turbulence is only escalating.Â  Secretary-General @antonioguterres tells reporters: The New Year has begun with our world in turmoil. Geopolitical tensions are at their highest level this century. And this turbulence is escalating. pic.twitter.com/TfoyiX2aO8â€œEven nuclear non-proliferation can no longer be taken for grantedâ€ he added, without specifically referencing the events of recent days following the targeted killing by a United States drone, of Iranâ€™s most influential general, Qasem Soleimani, in Iraq last Friday.Iran has vowed to avenge the killing of the elite Quds Force commander, and on Sunday it signified it would no longer be bound by the restrictions on its nuclear programme, outlined in the 2015 deal known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, or JCPOA. The deal was debated in the Security Council just last month.On 1 January, Mr. Guterres also expressed his deep concern at the announcement by the Democratic Peopleâ€™s Republic of Korea (DPRK), commonly known as North Korea, that it was ending its self-imposed moratorium on nuclear missile testing.On Sunday, the Iraqi parliament also passed a non-binding resolution calling for US troops to leave the country, in a clear response to the killing of the Iranian general on their soil. In response, President Trump has threatened Iraq with sanctions if forced to withdraw its forces, and also threatened on Twitter, to destroy multiple sites of â€œculturalâ€ significance within Iran, if there are reprisal attacks against Americans. Mr. Guterres told the noon stakeout for correspondents at UN Headquarters in New York, that a â€œcauldron of tensions is leading more and more countries to take unpredicted decisions with unpredictable consequences and a profound risk of miscalculation. At the same time, we see trade and technological conflicts that fracture world markets, undermine growth and widen inequalitiesâ€, he added.Â  Furthermore, said the UN chief, â€œour planet is on fire.Â  The climate crisis rages on.Â  In many parts of the world, we see many people frustrated and angry.Â  We see increased social unrest and growing extremism, nationalism and radicalization, with a dangerous advance of terrorism, notably in Africa.Â  He said it was clear that â€œthis situation cannot go on. I have been following the recent rise in global tensions with great concern. I am in constant contact with leading officials around the world.Â  The UN chief had a clear four-point message for what needs to happen now, in capitals across the world: â€œStop escalation. Exercise maximum restraint. Re-start dialogue. Renew international cooperation.â€Â  â€œLet us not forget the terrible human suffering caused by war,â€ he concluded. â€œAs always, ordinary people pay the highest price.Â  It is our common duty to avoid it.â€
