title: Take action on air pollution to save lives, and the planet, urges UN chief
text: As well as claiming seven million lives every year, and damaging childrenâ€™s development, the UN chief noted that many air pollutants cause global warming, which he has described as â€œan existential threat.â€In his video address, the UN Secretary-General recalled his recent experience in the South Pacific island states, which he visited last month to show solidarity with those suffering from the worst effects of climate change. Mr. Guterres said that he had seen first-hand the severe and worsening impacts of the global climate emergency.With the environment facing â€œunprecedented perils,â€ caused by human activity, the UN chief said that action to fight climate change is â€œthe battle of our livesâ€, that we must win, by taxing pollution, ending fossil fuel subsidies, and halting the construction of new coal plants.World Environment Day, widely celebrated in over 100 countries, is the United Nations day for encouraging international awareness and action to protect the environment. The theme for 2019 is air pollution, calling on governments, industry, communities and individuals to take action to explore renewable energy and green technologies, and improve the air quality in cities and regions across the world.Every World Environment Day has a different host country: this year's host is China, with the official celebration taking place in the eastern city of Hangzhou, in the presence of senior Chinese government officials and Joyce Msuya, Acting Executive Director of the UN Environment Programme, (UNEP).Although the rapid development of many Chinese cities has led to poor air quality, and associated health problems for many citizens, the country has made significant strides in addressing the problem in recent years.In the Chinese capital, Beijing, which has become almost synonymous with air pollution, the concentration of fine particulates (the tiny, deadly elements largely responsible for deaths and illnesses) in the air, has fallen by a third over the past two decades, beating the target set by the State Council, Chinaâ€™s main administrative body.Speaking to UN News ahead of World Environment Day, Tiy Chung, Communications Officer for the Climate & Clean Air Coalition at UNEP, said that Beijing is â€œshowing the way,â€ by taking the issue very seriously, and implementing strong policies. The city, he said, has taken a systematic approach based on good science, and coordinated successfully with surrounding cities and regions.Looking at other cities and countries, Mr. Chung is hopeful that the world is moving in the right direction. â€œWe are getting at a mix of good policies and technologies.Â  Innovative low-emission technology is at the forefront of a new revolution driven by policies pushing for lower air pollution and de-carbonization of economy.â€More information about the international events to mark World Environment Day can be found here.

We are not able to vaccinate, we are not able to treat those who are ill, we are not able to follow up on those who may have had access to the virus.â€Â Â The development follows last weekâ€™s appointmentÂ of a UN Ebola response chief DavidÂ Gressly, who isâ€¯alsoâ€¯deputy head ofâ€¯UN Stabilization Mission in the DRC,Â MONUSCO.Â Continuing her trip to London, the UN Deputy Secretary-General, Amina J. Mohammed, attended several events on Tuesday, highlighting the importance of â€œOur Shared Humanityâ€ and our global values, and the centrality of unlocking the potential of women and girls.â€œThe solidarity expressed in the United Nations Charterâ€™s opening words, 'we the people', is critical for our humanityâ€™s future. The values enshrined throughout the document must remain our benchmark and guide,â€ said Ms. Mohammed in her statement delivered at foreign affairs think-tank, Chatham House.Urging the world to move faster towards the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals, she noted that â€œwithout deep transformation, we risk catastrophic climate change; mass extinction of ecosystems and species; even higher levels of forced displacement; a major rollback of decades of development progress - and all of the political turmoil that accompanies social and economic disruption.â€In another event on tackling inequality, she stressed the importance of unlocking the power and potential of women and girls. â€œGender equality is one of the critical social, economic and political priorities of our time. This should not be such a struggle.Â  After all, the benefits of gender equality are many and proven.â€She urged countries to adopt â€œwell-designed and targeted policies that enhance the opportunities of women to participate in economic activities and in political and public lifeâ€ and added that â€œpublic spending on health, education and social protection should be increased to build the capacities that women and girls need to succeed in a technologically-driven 21st century.â€Listen to or download our audio News In Brief for 4 June on SoundCloud:

title: â€˜Bicycle Kingdomâ€™ makes a comeback, as China seeks solutions to tackle air pollution crisis
text: China was onceÂ considered to be the "Kingdom of the Bicycle,â€ with bikes dominating cityÂ streets across the country, but over the past four decades, Chinaâ€™s dramatic economic prosperityÂ and urbanizationÂ has seenÂ many people move to motor vehicles as their primary means of transport, contributing to a marked deterioration in air quality.Â In Hangzhou, a city in eastern China that wasÂ once described by the Italian explorer Marco PoloÂ as â€œthe finest and most splendid city in the world,â€ air pollution has had a devastating effect.Â According toÂ dataÂ backed byÂ theÂ World Health Organization (WHO),Â Hangzhouâ€™s air pollution isÂ well overÂ WHOâ€™s safe level.Â However, in a bid to improve public health and the environment, the Hangzhou authorities have put a fresh emphasis on cycling,Â which,Â allied with digital technology,Â is helping to cutÂ pollution:Â otherÂ cities are followingÂ their example.Â Over the past decade, theÂ local government hasÂ been improvingÂ bike-friendlyÂ infrastructure, such as lanes andÂ traffic signals created solely forÂ cyclists, andÂ hasÂ provided almost 86,000 public bikes. A smart card allows users to easily access all forms of public transport, from bikes to boats to buses.Â â€œAll together there have been 760 million rides, thatâ€™s almost half the population of China,â€ saysâ€¯TaoÂ Xuejun, general manager of the Hangzhou Public Bicycle Service.Â â€œSo far,Â more than 400 cities in China have adopted our project. Our dream is to promote our model across China and all over the world.â€Â As a result ofÂ these initiatives,Â according to Tao,Â cycling has become a popular choice for both local citizens and tourists,Â and the efforts of the Government-run company have been rewarded with international recognition,Â including the InternationalÂ AshdenÂ Award for Sustainable Travel in 2017.Â As well as leading the Chinese cycling resurgence, Hangzhou isÂ home toÂ an innovative way to encourage more sustainable lifestyles, with an app that is helping to stop desertification, cut air pollutionÂ and plant millions of new trees.Â Â The â€œAnt Forestâ€ mini-program, aÂ Hangzhou-basedÂ project from giant Chinese payments and lifestyle app Alipay,Â incitesÂ usersÂ toÂ makeÂ small, environmentally friendly decisions in their daily lives,Â such as cycling rather than driving to work, or recycling clothes. When usersÂ perform any carbon-reducing activities, they are rewardedÂ withÂ â€œgreen energyâ€ points.As they accumulate enough virtual points, a real tree is planted.Â According toÂ Ant Financial,Â more than 100 million trees have been planted,Â thanksÂ toÂ the low-carbon actionsÂ of 500Â million individuals, roughly 5% of the world's population.Internationally, one of the best-known examples of harmful air pollution affecting quality of life in a city, isÂ the Chinese capital, Beijing.Â Beijingâ€™s remarkable development over the last two decades saw a significant, and visible, rise in air pollution, due to a combination ofÂ factors,Â includingÂ coal-related pollutants; the growth of motor transport, especially logistics freight trucks; heavy industry; and dust from buildings andÂ roads, according to one of the main authors of aÂ UN led report,Â A review of 20 Yearsâ€™ Air Pollution Control in Beijing.Â Fine particulates â€“Â tiny, invisible airborne particlesÂ â€“ are largely responsible for deaths and illnesses from air pollution. The smallest, and deadliest, are called PM2.5 particles, whichÂ bypassÂ theÂ bodyâ€™s defences and lodge inÂ theÂ lungs, bloodstream and brain. Business, public buildings and households account for around half of PM2.5 emissions.Â Today, fine particulate pollution in Beijingâ€™s air is still 7.3 times the safe level the WHOâ€™s annual safe level, but the local and regional governmentsÂ have managed to improve the situation in recent years.Â ByÂ working together on a strategy to tackle the problem, by using the legal, economic and technological tools at its disposal, the concentration of fine particles in the air fell by one third, beating the target set by the State Council, Chinaâ€™s main administrative body.Â â€œBeijing has achieved impressive air quality improvements in a short amount of time,â€ saidÂ Dechenâ€¯Tsering, Director of UN Environmentâ€™s Asia Pacific Regional Office. â€œIt is a good example of how a large city in a developing country can balance environmental protection and economic growth,â€ she stressed.Â China is hosting the 2019 UNÂ World Environment DayÂ on JuneÂ 05, with air pollution as the theme,Â TheÂ main eventsÂ marking the day, will take place inÂ Hangzhou.

title: Pedal power makes â€˜positive impact on climateâ€™, urges UN on World Bicycle Day
text: Taking to two wheels fosters â€œsustainable consumption and productionâ€, and has a â€œpositive impact on climateâ€, according to the UN.Moreover, biking enhances access to education, health care and sport; and the synergy between the bicycle and the cyclist raises a more intimate and immediate awareness of the local environment.Happy #BicycleDay! I am very honored to be here today w/@UN family & inspiring cycling advocates to celebrate the contributions of this humble machine to human health, social & economic mobility, road safety and #ClimateAction! #BicyclesChangeLives #UN4ALL pic.twitter.com/59FluLLXsTAccording to the UN Environment Programme, even though the benefits of investing in pedestrians and cyclists can â€œsave lives, help protect the environment and support poverty reductionâ€, the mobility needs of people who walk and cycle, mostly urban dwellers, â€œcontinue to be overlookedâ€.â€œThe price paid for mobility is too high, especially because proven, low-cost and achievable solutions existâ€, underscores UNEPâ€™sÂ Share the Road Programme Annual Report 2018. â€œNo-one should die walking or cycling to work or schoolâ€.The Programme continues to advocate for action, working with countries around the world to prioritize the needs of pedestrians and cyclists â€“ a critical part of the mobility solution for helping cities break the link between population growth and increased emissions, and to improve air quality and road safety.According to the World Health OrganizationÂ (WHO), safe infrastructure for walking and cycling is also a pathway to greater health equity for the poorest urban dwellers, by providing transport â€œwhile reducing the risk of heart disease, stroke, certain cancers, diabetes, and even deathâ€.UN Headquarters in New York marked the day with a special outdoor event, which General Assembly President MarÃ­a Fernanda Espinosa observed comes â€œat a crucial timeâ€ as there are only 11 years left â€œto avoid the worst impacts of climate changeâ€.With 2030 marking the deadline for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), she encouraged support for new technologies, adding that â€œwe must also ensure we are harnessing existing tools, such as the bicycleâ€.â€œFrom reducing transport emissions and road deaths to tackling obesity and noncommunicable diseases, improving rural connectivity and empowering women and girls, bicycles can make a crucial contributionâ€, she stated.Noting that transport is the third-largest source of CO2, Ms. Espinosa cited studies showing that if just 10 per cent of city journeys were taken by bike, urban transport emissions would fall by 7 per cent.â€œIt would also contribute to reducing air pollution â€“ the theme for this yearâ€™s World Environment Day â€“ helping to save the lives of some 7 million people a yearâ€, she pointed out. â€œAnd I suspect there would be a significant boost â€“ to the economy and to more peaceful societies - if people were not gridlocked in traffic.â€â€œSo, we must do more to integrate bicycles into urban and rural planning, infrastructure and designâ€, she urged. â€œAnd we must invest in education to promote the multiple benefits of cyclingâ€.After speaking at the event, UN News caught up with Phil Southerland, CEO and co-founder of Team Novo Nordisk, an American global all-diabetes sports team of cyclists, triathletes and runners.At just seven months old, Mr. Southerland was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. Living in Tallahassee Florida, his parents were told that he would be dead or blind by age 25. Fortunately, at 12 years-old he discovered bicycling.While helping a friend in college to manage his own type 1 diabetes, Mr. Southerland realized the value of using the bike as a means to â€œshow the world that exercise is the billion-dollar drug that never gets prescribedâ€.The athlete is living proof that â€œyou can still chase your dreams with diabetesâ€.

title: With a premature death every five seconds, air pollution is violation of human rights, says UN expert
text: Ahead ofÂ the 2019Â World Environment DayÂ onÂ Wednesday,Â which has air pollution as its theme,Â David Boyd,Â theÂ UNâ€™sÂ Special Rapporteur on human rights and the environment,Â called onÂ states toÂ takeÂ urgent action to improve air qualityÂ in order toÂ fulfill their human rights obligations.Â Air pollution is aÂ deadly, man-made problem, responsible forÂ the early deaths ofÂ some seven millionÂ peopleÂ every year, around 600,000 ofÂ whom are children.Â It is estimated that 90 per cent of the worldâ€™s population breathe polluted air.Â Â Every five seconds, somebody around the world dies prematurely as a result.Â Â In a statement,Â Mr.Â Boyd said thatÂ uncontaminatedÂ airÂ isÂ a core component of the right to a healthy environment, together with clean water and adequate sanitation, healthy and sustainably produced food,Â aÂ non-toxic environment, healthy biodiversity and a safe climate.Â Â â€œThe right to a healthy environment is fundamental to human well-being and is legally recognized by over 150 States at the national and regional levels. It should be globally reaffirmed to ensure the enjoyment of this right by everyone, everywhere while upholding the human rights principles of universality and non-discrimination.â€Â Mr. BoydÂ describedÂ the efforts of China, host of this yearâ€™s World Environment Day, to tackle air pollution,Â asÂ a â€œsuccess story.â€Â Although the Chinese capital, Beijing, has become synonymous with dirty air over the past few decades,Â a concerted effort by local and regional authorities has seen an improved situation in recent years, with the concentration of fine particulatesÂ â€“ theÂ tiny, invisible airborne particlesÂ thatÂ are largely responsible for deaths and illnesses from air pollutionÂ â€“ falling by a third.Â The UN expert reiteratedÂ hisÂ recommendedÂ measuresÂ forÂ reducing air pollution, contained inÂ aÂ reportÂ presentedÂ to the UN Human Rights Council in March. These includeÂ monitoringÂ air quality and impacts on human health; assessingÂ sources of air pollution; establishingÂ air quality legislation;Â andÂ developingÂ air quality action plans.Â â€œIn celebration of World Environment Day, I urge States to take bold action to beat air pollution, improve health, address climate change,Â and fulfill their human rights obligations,â€ the expert said.Â World Environment Day,Â celebrated since 1974,Â is the United Nations day for encouraging worldwide awareness and action to protect the environment. It is organized around a theme that addresses a particularly pressing environmental concern.Â In aÂ video messageÂ released ahead ofÂ theÂ Day, UN Secretary-GeneralÂ AntÃ³nio Guterres said that, as well asÂ claiming millions of livesÂ every year, and damagingÂ childrenâ€™s development,Â many air pollutants areÂ also causing global warming. Mr. GuterresÂ called climate change an â€œexistentialÂ threat,â€Â and pressed the international community toÂ â€œtax pollution, not peopleâ€ and stop building coal plants.

title: From philanthropy to profit: how clean energy is kickstarting sustainable development in East Africa
text:
The United Nations human settlements programme, UN-Habitat, and Portuguese energy company EDP, are constructing a solar energy system to supply 12 classrooms â€“ which have been built to withstand 180 km per hour winds â€“ with clean, renewable energy.This will have a huge impact on the community because, as well as enabling some 1,300 students to study at night, people living in the area will, for a small fee, be able to charge their mobile phones, and access the internet.They will also stand a better chance of surviving, when the next cyclones and floods hit the country: Mozambique has developed an early-warning system, with SMS alerts sent out by the government, but this only works in communities with access to energy.â€œAs long as you can provide this service at a school, people will at least have access to communication with the outside world, which is the main handicap when an emergency strikes, recounts Juan Hurtato Martinez, UN-Habitat architect and manager of the project.Â  â€œSo, it ensures that, in an emergency, they can receive the alarms quickly."Although the impetus for the project comes from EDPs philanthropic arm, the company sees it as a sensible investment in Africa, in line with the UNâ€™s call for companies to play their part in the move to a â€œgreen economy,â€ that is not reliant on fossil fuels such as coal and gas."The African continent is surely the continent with more natural resources â€“ such as the sun, wind, water, biomass and others â€“ that allow the use of renewable energies,â€ says Guilherme Collares Pereira, Director of International Relations at EDP. â€œTherefore, it makes total sense to intervene in the market that has resources and that has the needs.â€
Renewable energies can enable universal energy access to be achieved Guilherme Collares Pereira, Director of International Relations, EDP
Some 600 million people in Africa are without access to electricity, Pereira points out, and it is â€œmore than proven that renewable energies can enable, in a cheaper, faster and more efficient way, universal energy access to be achieved.â€The project in the district of Namacurra is one of six, in Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique and Malawi, that will be receiving support from EDP. At the Kakuma Refugee Camp in Kenya, which hosts more than 186,000 people, a mini-grid will supply pay-as-you-go electricity to refugees according to their consumption needs. â€œIt is a very interesting approach that can be replicated throughout the camp,â€ says Pereira, â€œbut it can also be replicated in other refugee camps, not only in the Horn of Africa but all over the world.â€For EDP, the 2030 Agenda is an opportunity, says Pereira. â€œTen years ago, when we began involvement with these projects, we were guided more by our corporate responsibility policy, but nowadays it is more about business.â€In 2018 the company decided to invest â‚¬12 million in companies that are already working with renewable energy in East Africa. â€œAt the moment, they are not as profitable as traditional EDP businesses,â€ he notes, â€œbut this is a journey, and we are discovering how the process develops. So, in the next couple of years, when we are ready, we can invest in more companies and grow them in preparation for entry into other markets.â€â€œThe potential is enormous: renewable energy technology is getting better, more efficient and more resilient. There is also an abundance of mechanisms and even financing from countries and the international community to support these projects.Â  Everything is in place for its growth and it is imperative that the private sector enters this market."

title: Mozambique: UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Orlando Bloom meets the child cyclone survivors whoâ€™ve lost everything
text: During the week, the actor travelled to the coastal city of Beira, one of the areas worst-affected by Cyclone Idai, which killed over 600 people and destroyed nearly 240,000 homes when it made landfall in March.Sitting on the sandy floor of a tent at the Samora Machel site for internally displaced people, named after the countryâ€™s founding president, Mr. Bloom listened to children recount devastating stories of how they lost everything in the cyclone.PRESS RELEASE & MULTIMEDIA: @UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador #OrlandoBloom visits children displaced by #CycloneIdai in #Mozambique https://t.co/II5HGO1AiY pic.twitter.com/nMPvT9M17eThirteen-year-old Alzina Lopes described the moment Cyclone Idai made landfall, leaving her stranded in waist-deep floodwaters. Now she wants to go back to school, and dreams of becoming a traffic officer.â€œItâ€™s remarkable to see children, who have been through so much, gain a sense of normality in the safe spaces set up by UNICEF, where they are free to sing, dance, play and just be children,â€ said the Goodwill Ambassador.â€œThese are children and young people with dreams, they want to be in schoolâ€, he continued â€œbut almost everyone Iâ€™ve met here has lost their classrooms, their books and crucial identification documents due to the cyclonesâ€.Mr. Bloom said that it was â€œheartbreakingâ€ that without IDs â€œthey are unregistered, almost invisible and vulnerable to exploitationâ€.In the aftermath of tropical cyclones Idai and Kenneth, 1.1 million children remain in urgent need of humanitarian assistance.UNICEF is supporting families affected by the cyclones to either return home or relocate to safer places. It is also providing healthcare, nutrition, education, sanitation and protection services.In the days following the storm, UNICEF and its partners restored water supplies to thousands of people in Beira and procured and administered one million doses of the cholera vaccine, curbing a large outbreak.At the Mutua resettlement area in the city, currently home to around 1,500 cyclone-affected people - half of whom are youth - Mr. Bloom danced and sang with young children and spoke to them about their hopes and dreams.The actor also visited a primary school in Beira, which the students themselves repaired after the cyclone.Wrapping up his trip, Mr. Bloom spent an afternoon with young volunteers at an interfaith group on the beachfront â€“ a poignant venue, as the deadly storm barrelled in from the sea. They told him that the pain and suffering they saw after the cyclones, had strengthened their resolve to help others.â€œThousands of children and families in Mozambique have seen their lives upended by these devastating cyclones and itâ€™s going to be a long road back,â€ said UNICEF Mozambique Representative, Marcoluigi Corsi. â€œWeâ€™re working on the ground with our partners to help get children and their families back on their feet by providing support in healthcare, nutrition, education and protectionâ€.Mr. Corsi pointed out that as part of the recovery effort, â€œweâ€™re also trying to help affected communities become more resilient to future weather-related events that could happen more often because of climate changeâ€.UNICEF has launched an appeal for $122 million to support its humanitarian response for children and families devastated by the storm and its aftermath in Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Malawi.

title: Wednesdayâ€™s Daily Brief: #NoTobacco Day, Chinaâ€™s economy, family farming, #ClimateAction

Obviously Chinaâ€™s growth over the past 20 to 30 years has certainly been based on its performance as a factory of the world: thatâ€™s what itâ€™s used to kickstart its economy. Subsequent to that, thereâ€™s been a massive broadening of Chinaâ€™s goods and services offering, and itâ€™s important to see it as a multi-dimensional economy, not simply a manufacturing hub.â€Launching theÂ United Nations Decade of Family FarmingÂ in RomeÂ on Wednesday, two UN agencies have lauded family-run farms,Â whichÂ account forÂ over 90 per cent of theÂ sector,Â as â€œkey drivers of sustainable development,â€ that play a major role in ending hunger and malnutrition.Â Â The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD)Â also announced aÂ Global Action PlanÂ toÂ upgradeÂ support for familyÂ farmers, particularly those in developing countries, with detailed guidance for the international community.Â Â Although farmers produce most of our food, theyÂ are vulnerable toÂ poverty, especially in developing countries, and the plan highlights the need to increase access to social protection for farmers, as wellÂ as finance, training and opportunities to generate income.Â The havoc caused by cyclones Idai and Kenneth across Mozambique is â€œa wake-up callâ€ for vulnerable countries â€œto build resistance" against further high-impact tropical storms, coastal flooding and intense rainfall linked to climate change, according to the United Nations weather agency chief.A World Meteorological Organization (WMO) fact-finding mission to Mozambique recommended on Wednesday a package of disaster-risk-reduction priorities to strengthen the countryâ€™s early warning systems and reduce damage due to weather, climate and water-related hazards.Read our story here.Climate change and urbanization are combining to create an urgent global need for sustainable cities. title: â€˜Save Tuvalu; save the worldâ€™; UN chief echoes rallying cry from front lines of global climate emergency
text: If the world is to prevail against climate change, â€œthen we must find the political will to take transformative measures,â€ declared the UN chief.Â â€œLeaders must come to the UN summit in September armed with solutions as well as speechesâ€, he stressed, referring to the action-focused meeting he is convening in September to mobilize political ambition on climate change and push forward the goals of the Paris Agreement, which encompass greenhouse-gas-emissions mitigation, adaptation, and finance.Â On his recent Pacific tour to the frontlines of the global climate emergency, he heard the rallying cry â€œSave Tuvalu; save the world,â€ while visiting the tiny island archipelago that is battling sea level rise and coastal erosion as warming temperatures threaten the region. Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â â€œI was there to show solidarity with those suffering the worst impacts of climate change and to draw attention to the innovative climate action underway in the region,â€ explained the UN chief.Â Sea level rise in some Pacific countries is â€œfour times greater than the global averageâ€, he stated, saying that it poses â€œan existential threat to several island Statesâ€. Â â€œOceans are in serious trouble, from coral bleaching to biodiversity loss to plastic pollutionâ€, he warned. â€œExtreme weather events are on the rise, jeopardizing lives and livelihoodsâ€.Â Mr. Guterres spelled out: â€œNowhere have I seen the heartbreaking impacts of climate change more starkly than in Tuvalu, a remote coral atoll nation where the highest point is less than five metres above sea level.â€ Â He recounted a visit to the home of a family â€œwho live in a state of perpetual anxiety about inundation by the relentlessly rising seas just steps awayâ€.Â The UN chief was â€œdeeply moved by the warmth of the Tuvaluan people and their intense devotion to their land, way of life and cultural heritageâ€, he said, adding that while these communities have contributed almost nothing to climate change, because of big emitters, â€œthey are now fighting to preserve their countryâ€™s very existenceâ€.Â â€œMake no mistake: it is not just Tuvalu, or small islands, or the Pacific at stakeâ€, underscored the Secretary-General. â€œIt is the whole planetâ€. Â What is happening to these countries â€œis a sign of what is in store for the rest of usâ€, he warned. â€œPeople all over the world are starting to feel the impacts of the climate emergency â€“ and these will only worsenâ€.Â The UN chief recalled meeting young children who â€œare already fearful for their future and are relying on my generation to secure itâ€. Â â€œAs Secretary-General of the UN, I have many battlesâ€, he said. â€œBut as a grandfather, the struggle against climate change is the fight of my lifeâ€.Â Noting that â€œwe are not winningâ€, Mr. Guterres urged that political will must be fund â€œto take transformative measuresâ€. Â â€œWe must acknowledge the moral authority of the Pacific nations, frontrunners in the race against the climate emergencyâ€, he statedâ€œAnd we must find sustainable solutions, invest in renewable energies and increase resilience and adaptationâ€.Â The clearly laid-out goals of the scientific community to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 and limit global warming to 1.5C by the end of the century, are â€œessentialâ€, according to the UN chief.Â As the global community pursues those goals, he restated his message to Governments to â€œshift taxes from salaries to carbonâ€, saying â€œwe should tax pollution, not peopleâ€.Â He also urged them to â€œstop subsidizing fossil fuelsâ€ because â€œtaxpayersâ€™ money should not be used to boost hurricanes, spread drought and heat waves, and melt glaciersâ€.Â â€œStop building new coal plants by 2020â€, he continued. â€œWe need a green economy, not a grey oneâ€.Â He stressed that we have the tools to tackle the climate crisis, to â€œsave lives and property, breathe less polluted air, access cleaner water and protect biodiversityâ€. Â â€œClimate action could also yield a direct economic gain of $26 trillion, compared to business as usual, through to 2030, making it a cost-effective optionâ€ argued the UN chief.Â Turning to his climate action summit, Mr. Guterres flagged that he is asking world leaders to come â€œnot just with speechesâ€ but with â€œplans to transform energy, mobility, industry and agricultureâ€, and to implement their commitments to climate financing, â€œnot out of generosity but enlightened self-interestâ€.Â â€œUrgent climate action is a choice we can â€“ and must â€“ makeâ€, concluded the Secretary-General. â€œAs the people of Tuvalu know all too well: Saving them will save us allâ€.

title: Mozambique cyclones a â€˜wake-up callâ€™ to boost resistance: UN weather agency
text: Devastation caused by #Idai and #Kenneth is a wake-up call about more high-impact tropical cyclones, coastal flooding and intense rainfall linked to #climatechange, says WMO fact-finding report released for #Mozambique reconstruction donor conference https://t.co/Cn3TEuLujM pic.twitter.com/KTY9tKaY7oA World Meteorological Organization (WMO) fact-finding mission to Mozambique recommended on Wednesday a package of disaster-risk-reduction priorities to strengthen the countryâ€™s early warning systems and reduce damage due to weather, climate and water-related hazards.Â â€œMozambique needs to build resilienceâ€, WMO Secretary-General Petteri Taalas said in a message to an international pledging conference to secure support for reconstruction, on Saturday. â€œAlthough the number of tropical cyclones globally is expected to reduce in the future, the number of most intense tropical cyclones (category 4 and 5), associated with more rainfall, will increase in a warming climate,â€ he said.Â He asserted that future sea level rise â€œwill exacerbate the impact of storm surge on coastal regionsâ€ and raise flooding concerns, â€œparticularly for low-lying cities such as Beiraâ€, which was inundated by the cyclones in March and April. It also draws attention to Mozambiqueâ€™s vulnerability to floods from both rivers and sea. The fact-finding team said that a $27 million investment is needed to strengthen meteorological and water supply sectors.Â This includes reconstruction, rehabilitation and modernization of infrastructure and equipment, land surveys for flood-risk mapping and satellite rainfall estimation and forecast training.Â The team of meteorologists and hydrologists, headed by WMOâ€™s Filipe LÃºcio, will present a report to an international pledging conference for Mozambique, taking place on Friday and Saturday in Beira.Â On 14 March, months-worth of rain fell in a matter of hours around the coastal city as Idai provoked one of the worst disasters to ever hit the southern hemisphere.Â The cyclone and subsequent flooding killed more than 600 people, injured an estimated 1,600, affected more than 1.8 million and caused an estimated $773 million in damages to buildings, infrastructure and agriculture.Â â€œIn times of floods, Mozambicans seek safety on roofs of buildings. But the ferocity of Idaiâ€™s winds blew the roofs awayâ€, said Mr. Lucio. â€œIt is a salutary warning about the future scale of the combined challenges from urbanization and climate change-related sea level rise and extreme weatherâ€. Â The fact-finding teamâ€™s visit coincided with Cyclone Kenneth, the most intense tropical cyclone ever known to have hit the Cabo Delgado province, on 25 April.Â According to the report, WMO identified major weaknesses on preparedness, emergency coordination and response, including the lack of a back-up communication system for warning and emergency operations and an evacuation plan for cities, particularly in low-lying areas.Â Moreover, because Mozambique is downstream of nine major river basins, it is prone to devastating floods, but water use upstream can also exacerbated low flows during droughts.Â While climate change projections indicate a global decrease in numbers of tropical storms and cyclones, they signal possible increases in intensities and associated rainfall. And, assuming all other factors are equal, WMO predicts that sea-level rise will exacerbate the impact of storm surge on coastal regions.

title: Artificial intelligence summit focuses on fighting hunger, climate crisis and transition to â€˜smart sustainable citiesâ€™
text:
â€œThis summit is the leading United Nations platform for dialogue on artificial intelligenceâ€, explained the Secretary-General of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) on Tuesday, adding that it â€œalso raises complex questions about privacy and trust and poses other challenges, from job displacement and potential bias in algorithms, to autonomous weapons and social manipulationâ€.More than 2,000 participants from over 120 countries joined AI leaders and humanitarian actors to highlight its potential for advancing education, healthcare and wellbeing, social and economic equality and space research.17 ways #AI can help meet the #GlobalGoals for #SustainableDevelopment https://t.co/zANmkgJ21Z #AIforGood pic.twitter.com/syh7HueUv8Unable to attend in person,Â Secretary-General AntÃ³nioÂ Guterres sent a message lauding "the promise" of AI while also warning against its potential dangers."If we are to harness the benefits of artificial intelligence and address the risks, we must all work together â€“ Governments, industry, academia and civil society â€“ to develop the frameworks and systems that enable responsible innovation", he said. "These systems must be nimble and adaptable, capable of developing norms and self-regulation standards alongside legally binding laws and instruments when needed, as in the case of lethal autonomous weapons".Noting thatÂ the UN is "well placed" asÂ a forum on "how best to guide progress to better serve humanity," Mr. Guterres underscored thatÂ "we must seize the moment, in partnership, to deliver on the promise of technologicalÂ advances and harness them for theÂ common good".In his opening address, Petteri Taalas, Secretary-General of the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) spelled out that climate change is accentuating the need for tailored information to improve resilience to extreme weather events.â€œWMO deals with big data every day, running a 24/7 operational prediction system based on a huge amount of data gathered around the world,â€ he said, identifying AI as a potentially valuable tool to help meet this challenge.
Deliver on the promise of technologicalÂ advances and harness them for theÂ common goodÂ â€“UN chief Guterres
Guided by its inter-disciplinary audience, this yearâ€™s summit aims to generate 'AI for Good' projects and ensure that associated technologies will be developed safely, allowing equal access for all.Francis Gurry, Director General of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) said that 340,000 AI patent applications have been filed since the 1950s: â€œArtificial intelligence is one of the most important of the technologies that are currently transforming our economy and society.â€He acknowledged there were pressing economic, social and ethical questions surrounding AI, saying that â€œwe are at an extremely early stage, but the common characteristic is that the underlying technological activityâ€¦is occurring at a much more rapid speed than our capacity to formulateâ€ responses.Organized by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) - in partnership with theÂ XPRIZE Foundation, theÂ Association for Computing Machinery (ACM)Â and 37 UN entities - theÂ summit, which will run from 28-31 May, aims to identify practical applications of AI to accelerate the UN Sustainable Development Goals.â€œWe need to ignite a bigger conversation centered around how to use AI and data to help find scalable solutions to the biggest challenges facing humanity," XPRIZE CEO Anousheh Ansari said.It will also debate unintended consequences of the AI revolution, and propose actions for high-potential solutions in achieving global scale, along with a so-called â€œlearning dayâ€ to offer an audience with leading AI experts and educators.â€œBy bringing together AI technologists with leaders in government, industry, and humanitarian initiatives, new ways to apply AI to pressing world challenges are imagined and realized,â€ stressed Vicki L. Hanson, ACM CEO.What is clear to ITU chief Zhao is that â€œno one nation, no one organization, no one company and no one community can meet these challenges aloneâ€.â€œThe path to a transformative but also a safe, trusted and inclusive AI will require unprecedented collaboration between government, industry, academia and civil society", he concluded.

title: Tuesdayâ€™s Daily Brief: violence surges in Nigeria, anti-Semitism on the march, taxing pollution to tackle climate crisis, and more
text: An upsurge in violence in areas of north-west Nigeria beyond the reach of humanitarians, has forced thousands of people to flee to neighbouring Niger, UN refugee agency,Â UNHCR,Â said on Tuesday.Warning that some 20,000 people have been uprooted from their homes since April in Nigeriaâ€™s Sokoto and Zamfara states, the agencyâ€™s Babar Baloch told journalists in Geneva that UNHCR is working with authorities in Niger to help the new arrivals.Today, Niger hosts more than 380,000 refugees and asylum seekers from Mali and Nigeria, in addition to its own internally displaced population.The UN human rights office has condemnedÂ the rise in anti-Semitic incidents in Europe and the United States, and called on governments to â€œredouble their effortsâ€ to protect people from incitement to hatred and violence.The statement fromÂ OHCHRÂ follows â€œa significant increaseâ€ of anti-Semitism in Germany, where Jews in some areas have been advised not to wear traditional dress, to avoid drawing attention to their race and religion.In Austria, pictures of Holocaust survivors displayed in a street exhibition have also been vandalised â€œnot once, but three timesâ€, the human rights office said.Initially, swastikas were daubed on the survivorsâ€™ faces, before large sections of the prints were then cut out at the weekend.Most disturbing of all are acts of physical violence against Jews which have also increased in a number of countries in recent years, OHCHR said, noting a â€œparticularly sharpâ€ rise in Germany and France.But it warns that the worst incidents have been in the United States, where 11 people were killed during an attack on a synagogue in Pittsburgh last October, and where in April, a woman was killed and three others injured in another attack on a synagogue in California.Hereâ€™s our report from earlier this year on the steps being taken by the UN to address xenophobia. Â Â â€œWe need to tax pollution, not peopleâ€ and â€œend subsidies for fossil fuelsâ€, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres told the World Summit of the R20 Coalition on Tuesday, a UN-supported environmental organization, founded by former California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger.The idea that subsidizing fossil fuels is a way to improve peopleâ€™s lives could not be more wrong, said the UN chief in the Austrian capital, Vienna, because it means spending taxpayersâ€™ money to â€œboost hurricanes, to spread droughts, to melt glaciers, to bleach corals: to destroy the world.â€Mr. Guterres went on to call for the decarbonization of urban infrastructure, a halt to coal plants, and the promotion of sustainable consumption and production: â€œin short, we need a green economy, not a grey economy.â€Our full story is here.Audio of the UN Secretary-General at the R20 Austrian World Summit, below:Bribery is the main way people in North Korea get food, healthcare, shelter and work, a UN human rights office reportÂ saidÂ on Tuesday.Based on more than 200 first-hand accounts of escapees from the country, which is officially known as the Democratic Peopleâ€™s Republic of Korea (DPRK), the report says that the State-run public distribution system collapsed in the mid-1990s, forcing people to work in informal markets, where they have to bribe officials to avoid arrest.It also highlights â€œappallingâ€ levels of hunger that affects around 10.9 million people â€“ thatâ€™s more than 43 per cent of the population â€“ with north-eastern and rural provinces worst-affected. Our full story is here.Although the Ebola response in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to make headway thanks to the determination of health workers on the ground, insecurity is still hampering the response, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday. This has led the UN to establish a new coordination structure in the hopes that access to at-risk areas can be improved.Currently, the DRCâ€™s worst ever outbreak of the deadly virus has seen 1,920 Ebola cases overall, includingÂ 1,281 deaths. Despite the risks, the more than 700 workers deployed by WHO remain in the area working alongside other health teams providing care.Our full report is hereÂ and you can listen to an interview with the new emergency Ebola response chief in DRC here.Â Listen to, or download our audio News In Brief for 28 May, on SoundCloud:

title: End fossil fuel subsidies, and stop using taxpayersâ€™ money to destroy the world: Guterres
text:
The idea that subsidizing fossil fuels is a way to improve peopleâ€™s lives could not be more wrong, said the UN chief in the Austrian capital, Vienna, because it means spending taxpayersâ€™ money to â€œboost hurricanes, to spread droughts, to melt glaciers, to bleach corals: to destroy the world.â€Mr. Guterres went on to call for the decarbonization of urban infrastructure, a halt to coal plants, and the promotion of sustainable consumption and production: â€œin short, we need a green economy, not a grey economy.â€In the lead up to the UN Climate Summit this September, the Secretary-General has enlisted the President of France, the Prime Minister of Jamaica and the Emir of Qatar to mobilize international support to secure the $100 billion goal agreed by UN Member States at the Paris climate conference in 2015, necessary for advancing climate mitigation and adaptation in the developing world.Investors need to stop â€œfinancing pollutionâ€, scale up green ventures and increase lending for low-carbon solutionsâ€, he insisted, adding that the private sector and investment communities must support a â€œbold and ambitions climate agendaâ€, because climate action is not only good for people and the planet, it can also be good for business.Fossil fuel subsidies mean using taxpayers' money to boost hurricanes, spread droughts & melt glaciers. As taxpayers, I believe we would like to see our money back rather than see it used to destroy the world. My remarks at @R20_AWS: https://t.co/0BAWMuilXd #ClimateAction pic.twitter.com/dAB43HMF2mRecounting his recent trip to Tuvalu, a low-lying island state in the South Pacific that risks being inundated by rising sea levels, Mr. Guterres highlighted the fact that â€œrarely a day goes by,â€ without news of yet another disaster, such as floods, droughts, wildfires and extreme storms.However, there is a â€œsilver lining to the looming cloudâ€, because, although the current situation is extremely serious, the shift to a green economy would see profound benefits for societies around the world, with cleaner water and air, less pollution, more chemical-free agriculture and reduced biodiversity loss.The R20 Austrian World Summit is a long-term initiative to help regions, states and cities to implement the Sustainable Development Goals, and meet the global climate protection targets outlined in the Paris Agreement to limit climate change. R20 aims to develop the summit to become the most important European meeting place for climate action solutions.One of the other high-profile speakers at the opening session of the event was outspoken Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg, who initiated the school strike for climate movement in November 2018, at the age of 15.Ms. Thunberg said that millions of children have been gaining lots of attention for the climate emergency, but they, like scientists, are not leaders, unlike many of the politicians, CEOs and celebrities attending the Summit: â€œpeople listen to you, and are influenced by you. You have an enormous responsibility, a responsibility that most of you have failed to take.â€
Climate change is an emergency, the biggest crisis that humanity has ever faced Greta Thunberg, youth climate activist
Such influencers, she added, cannot rely on people to read between the lines or search for scientific information. They must explain repeatedly, no matter how uncomfortable or unprofitable that may be. Ms. Thunberg reminded the audience that, although climate change may be a chance for green growth, it is primarily â€œan emergency, the biggest crisis that humanity has ever faced.â€The work of Governor Schwarzenegger and the R20 coalition, in highlighting the importance of climate action at a â€œsub-nationalâ€ city and regional level, was praised by the UN chief, who described sub-national action as being â€œkey to addressing the climate crisisâ€, not only because regional and city governments are closer to the people, but because â€œregions and cities are the main engines of the world economy.â€

title: Social, cultural diversity â€˜an enormous richness, not a threatâ€™ Guterres declares calling on investment for a harmonious future
text:
He was speaking against the backdrop of European Parliamentary elections in recent days, which showed a surge in support away from political parties in theÂ centreÂ ground, towards those espousing more nationalist and anti-immigrant policy platforms.Â â€œThis is the world we want: a world in which contributions from everybody, everywhere matterâ€ - @antonioguterres at music workshop #WithRefugees and @YoYo_Ma in Vienna. https://t.co/4SqrNiCOrb pic.twitter.com/s3rHnvcqYDSecretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres told those gathered for the Day of Action that it was particularly important â€œin the present debate in Europeâ€ to adopt â€œa universal perspective for peace, for human dignity, for human rightsâ€ and the values enshrined in the UN Charter.Â â€œSocieties today are multi-ethnic, multi-religious, multi-cultural. And that is a richness, not a threatâ€. Like an orchestra featuring musicians from around the world, they need to practiceÂ to playÂ harmoniously: â€œIt is the sameÂ with societyâ€ he added.Â â€œDiversity requires investment. Social, cultural, political, religious; sometimes investment in social cohesion â€“ to make sure that in a diverse society, every community feels that their identity is being respected â€“ like the identity of the violinist needs to be respected, together with each instrumentalist.Â Hailing music as a fundamental tool to promote UN values, he said the Day of Action was fundamental to the future of the Organization â€œespecially when we are also discussing the dramatic situation of human mobilityâ€.Â Migration too, needs investment, instead of letting people smugglers andÂ traffickersÂ profit from it, and letting fear of migrants fester, â€œwe need to invest in international cooperation, we need to invest in adequate forms of migrationâ€, he said.Â Speaking after meeting Austrian President Alexander Van Der Bellen, Mr. Guterres praised the nation for its support for the UN Office at Vienna over the past 40 years, home to many key agencies and bodies.Â As one of the main UN headquarters, he said he was convinced the work done in Vienna would help preserve peace and security for the world, during trying times.Â He looked ahead to Tuesdayâ€™s Austrian World Summit on climate, saying that taking part was essential to him, having convened the Climate Action Summit this coming September.Â Fresh from a major fact-finding visit to the South Pacific, Mr. Guterres said that to rescue an island State such as Tuvalu â€“ parts of which are already sinking below the waves due to rising sea levels â€“ was â€œto rescue the planetâ€.Â â€œThe climate crisis is something that will have an impact on the lives of everybody everywhereâ€, said the UN chief. â€œAnd to reverse the present trend in which climate change is running faster than we are is an absolute must. And for that, we need in 2020, countries to assume engagements much stronger than the ones that were assumed in Paris.Â 
Â 
He said nations had to commit â€œto a much more ambitious set of measures in mitigation in adaptation, mitigation and in finance. And I must tell you that I consider absurd that we are taxing salaries, we are taxing income, and not taxing carbonâ€.

title: Preserving biodiversity vitalÂ toÂ reverse tide ofÂ climate change, UN stresses on International Day
text: Biodiversity inÂ plant and animal life in the worldÂ â€“ in terms ofÂ species, habitats and geneticsÂ â€“ leads toÂ ecosystems that are healthier, more productive and better able to adapt to challenges like climate change, says the UN, and human activity is threatening the fate of species around the world like never before, according toÂ an alarming new UN reportÂ earlier this month.Â The theme â€œOur Biodiversity, Our Food, Our Healthâ€Â aims to leverage knowledge and spread awareness of how much all life depends on biodiversity.Â Â InÂ his message to mark the day, celebrated every 22 May, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nioÂ Guterres,Â notes thatÂ â€œthe quality of the water we drink, the food we eat and the air we breatheÂ all dependÂ on keeping the natural world in good healthâ€, also underlining that biodiversity was essential to achieve theÂ 17Â Sustainable Development Goals and to address climate change.Â Â Healthy ecosystems canÂ â€œprovide 37 per cent of the mitigation needed to limit global temperature riseâ€, he said, warning that the â€œcurrent negative trends in biodiversity and ecosystems are projected to undermine progress towards 80 per cent of the targets for theÂ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). We cannot allow this to happen."Â What is #biodiversity? Itâ€™s the existence of many different types of plants and animals that makes the ğŸŒ a healthier and more productive place.We wouldnâ€™t be able to survive without it! Learn more ğŸ‘‰https://t.co/rr3tq8anVk#BiodiversityDay #IDB2019 #ZeroHunger pic.twitter.com/dDJvJ7AnL0â€œThe worldâ€™s current food system is increasingly broken.Â  Billions of people lack access to proper nutritionâ€, said the UN chief. â€œApproximately one third of what is produced is lost or wasted.Â  The ways in which we grow, process, transport, consume and waste food are leading causes of biodiversity loss, while also contributing to climate change.â€Â Addressing the issue ofÂ deforestation, Mr. GuterresÂ said it hadÂ caused the â€œloss of more than 290 million hectares of forests that help to absorb harmful carbon dioxide emissions from the atmosphereâ€.Â Â Mr.Â Guterres urged all governments, businesses and civil societyÂ toÂ â€œtake urgent action to protect and sustainably manage the fragile and vital web of life on our one and only planetâ€.Â Â Highlighting theÂ galvanizing effect of biodiversityÂ for human health and well-being, the Secretary-General stressed that â€œsolutions existâ€.Â Â â€œBy halting environmentally harmful practices, diversifying our food systems and promoting more sustainable production and consumption patterns, we can improve global health, increase food security and strengthen resilience to climate change", he concluded.Â Â By choosing to eat only seasonal and local produce, we can ensure that the demand for the right foods is high in the right season.Â Â According to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), more than 90 per cent ofÂ traditionalÂ crops have disappeared from farmersâ€™Â fields,Â whileÂ half of theÂ animals bred by humansÂ have been lost.Â All ofÂ the worldâ€™s 17 main fishing grounds areÂ being fished at or above their sustainable limits.Â FAOÂ alsoÂ underlinesÂ that agricultural biodiversity is fundamental for coping with a changing climate,Â and helping to remove carbon from the atmosphere,Â and securing the future ofÂ diverse sources of healthy and nutritiousÂ food.

title: FROM THE FIELD: Saving the tree kangaroos of Papua New Guinea
text: The tree kangaroo which is only found in the rainforests of Australia, West Papua, and PNG is threatened due to hunting and habitat destruction.But now the local and indigenous people of PNG, who typically hunted the marsupial, are acting as custodians of the ancient rainforests by promoting the sustainable use of the land and the management of what is now a conservation area.Ahead of International day for Biological Diversity marked on 22 May, read more here about how the tree kangaroo is being protected by the people.

title: UN chief calls for â€˜enlightened self-interestâ€™ from world leaders to save â€˜the whole planetâ€™ from climate change
text:
â€œOver the past week, I have witnessed first-hand the impacts of climate change in the Pacific Island Statesâ€, the UN chief said in a statement concluding his visit to the region. â€œThey contribute very little to the global climate emergency and yet, they are the ones that are being most affectedâ€. Â He did not mince words in saying that for some of them, â€œclimate change is now an existential threatâ€.Pointing out that entire villages are being relocated, livelihoods destroyed and people becoming sick from climate-related diseases, Mr. Guterres lamented: â€œThe risks are all too realâ€.Â He drew attention to his time in Tuvalu, where he saw â€œan entire country fighting to preserve its very existenceâ€. Â And yet, the UN chief found â€œremarkableâ€ that the countries facing these enormous challenges, have decided that â€œthey are not giving upâ€ but are instead â€œdetermined to find solutionsâ€.Â Not only have they developed ways to increase their resilience and adaptation, but according to Mr. Guterres, â€œthey are leading the way in reducing emissions and are an example that the rest of the world should followâ€. Â In Vanuatu, his final stop in the Pacific, the Secretary-General tweeted that the vulnerable island State was one of â€œthe most disaster-prone countries, made worse by the global climate emergencyâ€. However, he added that he â€œsaw first-hand how the Pacific island nation is facing threats with determined climate actionâ€.Â Reiterating the powerful message that he has continued to underscore throughout his visit to the South Pacific, the UN chief stressed that â€œclimate change cannot be stopped by the small island countries alone, it has to be stopped by the rest of the worldâ€ and that this requires the political will for â€œtransformational policies in energy, mobility, industry and agricultureâ€.Â Mr. Guterres echoed the â€œthree urgent messagesâ€ to world leaders that he had â€œconsistently conveyedâ€ throughout his visit to the Pacific, beginning with shifting taxes from salaries to carbon. â€œWe need to tax pollution, not people,â€ he reiterated.Â Second, he flagged that countries must stop subsidizing fossil fuels. Â â€œTaxpayer money should not be used to boost hurricanes, spread drought and heatwaves, melt glaciers and bleach coralsâ€, he asserted.Â 
And third, he argued against building new coal plants by 2020, saying â€œwe need a green economy not a grey economyâ€.Â Mr. Guterres said that solidarity or generosity is not being sought, â€œit is enlightened self-interest from all decision-makers around the worldâ€ that is needed â€œbecause itâ€™s not only of the Pacific that is at stake, itâ€™s the whole planetâ€. Â â€œTo save the Pacific is to save the whole planetâ€, concluded the Secretary-General.

title: Stop Tuvalu and â€˜the world from sinkingâ€™ UN chief tells island nation facing existential threat from rising seas
text: â€œWe must stop Tuvalu from sinking and the world from sinking with Tuvaluâ€, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said in a tweet posted during his on-going trip to the South Pacific.Pointing out that Tuvalu is â€œon the extreme frontlines of the global climate emergencyâ€, he noted that â€œrising seas threaten to drown this island nation â€“ a sign of whatâ€™s in store for us allâ€.The @UN chief @antonioguterresmet families in Tuvalu Friday "Whose homes & way of life are at risk because of relentless rising seas"#ClimateAction is essential."We must save Tuvalu - and save the world". pic.twitter.com/TRuzaryep2At a joint press conference with Tuvaluâ€™s Prime Minister, Enele Sosene Sopoaga, the UN chief told journalists: â€œYou are on the frontline of the war on climate change because climate change is striking in Tuvalu in a more dramatic way than anywhere else in the worldâ€.He professed his â€œenormous admirationâ€ that the island nation has â€œdecided to resistâ€ and is implementing â€œa programme of adaptation and resilience that is something that the whole world should admire and supportâ€.â€œButâ€ stressed Mr. Guterres â€œitâ€™s necessary that governments that are still causing the problems that affect Tuvalu, understand that they need to changeâ€.He made clear they must alter energy and transportation policies, Â along with the way they manage their cities and use fossil fuels â€œso that the impactÂ of climate change on Tuvalu can be stoppedâ€.â€œClimate change cannot be stopped in Tuvalu, it has to be stopped in the rest of the worldâ€, the UN chief spelled out, saying that he will host the 2019 Climate Action Summit in New York â€œto make sure that all countries accept the commitment that we need to be globally carbon neutral by 2050 to limit the increase in temperature to 1.5 degreesâ€.Â At the same time, Mr. Guterres expressed his â€œdeep solidarityâ€ and the UNâ€™s â€œtotal supportâ€ to the government and to the people of Tuvalu in their determined efforts to preserve their country â€“ â€œphysically, culturally, in the economic and social dimensions, as a rich component of the Pacific and the international communityâ€.â€œNowhere have I seen the heartbreaking impacts of the global climate emergency more starkly than in Tuvalu, where I met families whose homes are threatened by relentless rising seasâ€Â he detailed.â€œWe must take urgent #ClimateAction to save Tuvalu â€” and save the worldâ€, the Secretary-General tweeted.

title: â€˜Climate change is the battle of my lifeâ€™, UN chief tells students living on the frontline in Fiji
text: Mr. Guterres was greeted on board the Uto ni Yalo, a traditional emission-free ship built as part of aÂ naval fleet that combines the ancient craft of Pacific shipbuilding with modern materials and green technology.â€œAs Secretary-General, I have many battlesâ€, the UN chief tweeted. â€œAs a grandfather, the battle against climate change is the battle of my lifeâ€ adding â€œitâ€™s a battle weâ€™re not winningâ€.The ship, whose name means â€œHeart of the Spiritâ€, has circumnavigated the world twice, sailing over 80,000 nautical miles to countries in the Northern and Southern hemispheres to motivate community, corporate and policy commitments to protect the worldâ€™s islands and ocean spaces.Mr. Guterres held firmly to his belief that â€œwe need stronger political will and urgent climate action to save our planet and our futureâ€.He also participated in an interactive session with students at the University of the South Pacific on combating climate change, where he heard about their work and told them, â€œThe world needs your generation to keep my generation accountable.â€Â He assured them that the UN is committed to continue listening to their voices and opening pathways for meaningful participation in decisions that affect them.â€œYoung people around the world are driving transformative climate action and MUST keep up the pressure on their leadersâ€ he tweeted. â€œThe determination of the students I met in Fiji is key to living at peace with our climateâ€.For their part, the students in Fiji told the UN chief that they want the world to know they are calling for urgent climate action.Earlier in the day, Mr. Guterres laid a wreath at the National War Memorial for the fallen peacekeepers in the Pacific region, where he tweeted that â€œSince the 1970s, Fijian peacekeepers have served in UN peacekeeping missions, [where] some have made the ultimate sacrificeâ€. He thanked Fiji â€œfor its contribution to protecting the vulnerableâ€.As well as meeting Fiji's President Geogi Konrotti, where they planted a ceremonial coconut tree, the Secretary-General told a joint press conference with Prime Minister Josia Furek Benimarama that climate change was "a life battle for Fiji and the Pacific."

title: Thursdayâ€™s Daily Brief: Ebola in DR Congo, malnutrition in Laos, baby health, support for Sahel force, #ClimateAction
