title: UN chief lauds Fijians as â€˜natural global leadersâ€™ on climate, environment, hails â€˜symbiotic relationshipâ€™ with land and sea
text:
â€œFiji has taken on the sceptics and the deniersâ€ in a loud and clear voice, he said, â€œand the world is listeningâ€.The Secretary-General outlined that Fiji was the first small island State to preside over the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and in 2017, became the first emerging market to issue a sovereign â€œgreen bondâ€, dedicated to environmental conservation. It introduced an Environment and Climate Adaptation Levy; launched a rural electrification programme to reduce diesel emissions; and has relocated villages and established guidelines on how to support people displaced due to climate change..@UN chief @AntonioGuterres continues his journey in the Pacific islands to fight the "battle of his life" for #ClimateAction.His second day in Fiji: pic.twitter.com/M6VcfG1HGJâ€œOther countries in the region can learn from your exampleâ€, he congratulated.Mr. Guterres pointed to the Fijian legislature as another of the countryâ€™s important achievements calling it â€œa place of inclusiveness, equality, diversity and toleranceâ€.â€œWe need that spirit more than ever at this timeâ€, he said, noting rising anti-Semitism, anti-Muslim rhetoric, the persecution of Christians and other forms of xenophobia and racism.The UN chief stressed the importance of showing solidarity in response to a â€œdangerous upsurge in hatredâ€ and to combat the hate speech â€œcoarsening our public dialogue in many countries and regions of the worldâ€.Citing the 2030 AgendaÂ and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) as â€œour blueprint for a fair globalization built on prosperous, peaceful and resilient societies on a healthy planetâ€, he commended Fiji for being the first parliament in the world to undertake an SDG self-assessment.Noting that climate change is â€œthe defining issue of our timeâ€, Mr. Guterres acknowledged how Fijians have suffered cyclones, floods and droughts, or lost their homes, schools or crops to rising seas, saying â€œthe United Nations stands with you, I stand with youâ€.He flagged the importance of financing, underscoring that given the amount of climate change that has already occurred, investment in adaptation â€œis especially crucialâ€ in the Pacific region.Â â€œWe need developed countries to fulfill the pledges they have made
to support action in developing countries â€“ including by mobilizing the public and private sector to reach $100 billion per year to support mitigation and adaptationâ€, the UN chief said, adding that the â€œsuccessful replenishment of the Green Climate Fundâ€ is also vital.To help generate ambition, Mr. Guterres announced that he is convening a Climate Action Summit in September.â€œMy message to leaders is very clear: Donâ€™t come with a speech; come with a planâ€, he asserted. â€œI want leaders to showcase their plans to enhance Nationally Determined Contributions by 2020, and to cut emissions radically by 2025â€ by ending subsidies for fossil fuels and unsustainable agriculture and shifting towards renewable energy, electric vehicles and climate-smart practices.Carbon pricing must reflect the true cost of emissions, the UN chief said, â€œfrom climate risk to the health hazards of air pollutionâ€. That means not constructing any coal plants beyond 2020 and replacing jobs in fossil fuel industries with â€œcleaner, healthier alternatives, so the transformation is inclusive, profitable and justâ€.Noting â€œrampantâ€ overfishing and plastic pollution that is â€œpoisoning and depletingâ€ the oceans, he emphasized that â€œthe world must do moreâ€.â€œThe coming years will be a vital period to save the planet and to achieve sustainable, inclusive human development,â€ he said. â€œThe alarm bells keep ringingâ€.â€œWe must address this global emergency with ambition and urgencyâ€, the Secretary-General concluded, adding â€œevery country has a role to playâ€.

title: Wednesdayâ€™s Daily Brief: climate challenges for the Pacific, new global health tool, updates on Yemen, the Gulf and Somalia
text: Visiting Fiji for the first time as Secretary-General, AntÃ³nio Guterres outlined twoÂ â€œfundamental challengesâ€ facing leaders attending the Pacific Islands Forum on Tuesday, namely climate change and the worldâ€™s rising ocean, which threatens to submerge low-lying nations.â€œThe Pacific region is on the frontline of climate changeâ€, he said. â€œThat means you are also our important allies in the fight against itâ€. The UN chief said that he was there â€œto see the regionâ€™s climate pressures firsthand, and to learn about the work being undertaken by communities here in Fiji and elsewhere to bolster resilienceâ€.\Noting that the last four years were the hottest on record, Mr. Guterres highlighted recent ice losses in Greenland and Antarctica, saying that â€œsea levels will rise a full meter by 2100â€.Find more on this here.â€œFifteen million children in Yemen are asking you to save their lives,â€ the head of the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) told the 15 members of the Security Council on Wednesday, in an impassioned plea for action to end four years of fighting which has left at least 7,300 children killed or seriously injured.â€œThese are verified numbers. The actual numbers are no doubt higherâ€, said Henrietta Fore, who began her address with a quiet intensity, telling the horrifying but tragically now mundane story of how one classroom was shattered by shrapnel last month in the capital Sanaâ€™a: â€œImagine the pain endured by the families of the 14 children who never made it home...In any conflict, children suffer first. And worst.â€Read our full story here.In a bid to improve the treatment of neglected diseases and threats to global health, the UN health agency, WHO, launched an online resource on Wednesday, designed to guide research into new health products.The free-to-use Health Product Profile Directory, which the WHO describes as â€œan essential tool for realizing universal health coverage,â€ so far contains research information on 196 products, with a strong focus on infectious diseases.The Ebola outbreak that began in 2014 in West Africa, highlighted the importance of centralizing information in order to fight neglected diseases, antimicrobial resistance and diseases with the potential to spread pandemics, so that research and development is more effective, and better coordinated.A drought in Somalia described by the UN food and agriculture agency (FAO) as â€˜disastrousâ€™ could hit around 2.2 million people in the country: almost a fifth of the population. On Wednesday, FAO put out a special alert, warning that the number of hungry people in Somalia is likely to be 40 per cent higher than it was at the beginning of the year, and that there has been a sharp increase of acutely malnourished children being admitted to feeding centres.People in the country are more vulnerable this year because, on top of the drought itself, they are dealing with increasing conflict, and a reduction in humanitarian aid.In an effort to stave off the crisis, FAO is calling for urgent funds for critical livelihood support such as cash assistance, seeds and farming tools.Rising tensions in the Gulf this week â€“ including drone attacks on Saudi oil facilities and damage sustained by oil tankers off the coast of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) â€“ are being followed â€œwith growing concernâ€ by the UN Secretary-General. Briefing reporters at UN headquarters in New York, Spokesperson StÃ©phane Dujarric said that â€œhardening rhetoricâ€ in the region threatened to â€œfurther destabilize an already volatile situationâ€.In particular, he said Mr. Guterres condemned the attacks off the coast of UAE on Sunday, which the Government has referred to as acts of sabotage, and further investigation is needed â€œto determine the facts and hold accountable the perpetrators.â€â€œHe also condemns the drone attacks on oil facilities in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, for which the Houthis have claimed responsibilityâ€, said Mr. Dujarric. A Houthi spokesperson reportedly said on Tuesday that the multiple drone strikes on Saudi oil facilities were in response to the Kingdomâ€™s leading role in the pro-Yemeni Government military coalition.â€œThe Secretary-General calls upon all actors to exercise maximum restraint and prevent any escalation amid heightened tensionsâ€, he concluded.Speaking in the Security Council on Wednesday, UN Special Envoy for Yemen, Martin Griffiths, said he was also very concerned about the drone attacks. â€œEvents like this are a reminder that hard-won achievements can be wiped away very easilyâ€, referring to the step forward made by Houthi rebels in withdrawing from the key Yemeni port of Hudaydah.More than half the worldâ€™s countries now depend on exporting their raw materials to keep their economies ticking over, and itâ€™s a potentially massive brake on their development, UN analysts from UNCTAD said on Wednesday. Using trade data from 189 countries, UNCTADâ€™s State of Commodity Dependence Report 2019 finds that, in 102 States, more than 60 per cent of what they make from exports comes from selling raw products linked to industries such as farming and mining. Thatâ€™s 10 countries more than at the turn of the century.With recent average commodity prices â€œsubstantially belowâ€ peaks seen in 2008-2012, the UN economists say that this has contributed to an economic slowdown in 64 countries â€“ and several have gone into recession.â€œGiven that commodity dependence often negatively impacts a countryâ€™s economic development, it is important and urgent to reduce it to make faster progress towards meeting the Sustainable Development Goals,â€ said UNCTAD Secretary-General, Mukhisa Kituyi.The phenomenon almost exclusively affects poorer nations; in particular, 85 per cent of the most vulnerable â€œLeast Developed Countriesâ€, 81 per cent of landlocked developing countries and 57 per cent of small island states. In regional terms, sub-Saharan Africa countries are most dependent on commodity exports (89 per cent), followed by the Middle East and North Africa (65 per cent). In Latin America, the Caribbean, East Asia and the Pacific, meanwhile, half of the countries there are commodity-dependent.Â Listen to or download our audio Â News in Brief for 15Â May 2019 on SoundCloud:

title: UN chief outlines â€˜intertwined challengesâ€™ of climate change, ocean health facing Pacific nations on the â€˜frontlineâ€™
text: â€œThe Pacific region is on the frontline of climate changeâ€, he said. â€œThat means you are also our important allies in the fight against itâ€.The UN chief said that he was there â€œto see the regionâ€™s climate pressures firsthand, and to learn about the work being undertaken by communities here in Fiji and elsewhere to bolster resilienceâ€.Noting that the last four years were the hottest on record, Mr. Guterres highlighted recent ice losses in Greenland and Antarctica, saying that â€œsea levels will rise a full meter by 2100â€.In the Pacific specifically, he said that sea-levels are set to rise in some countries four times above the global average, posing â€œan existential threat to some island Statesâ€.Providing â€œample evidence of the regionâ€™s vulnerabilityâ€ the UN chief cited recent damage caused by Tropical Cyclones Gita, Josie and Keni as well as by volcanic eruptions and earthquakes and other extreme weather events in the region.â€œClimate change will further worsen the risksâ€, he spelled out, noting that the salinization of water and crops is endangering food security and escalating the impact on public health.He maintained that climate change also brings â€œclear dangersâ€ for international peace and security, pointing to the 2018 Boe Declaration, which reaffirms climate change as the single greatest threat to the wellbeing of the Pacific.Mr. Guterres said that he recently appointed a task force to coordinate UN initiatives to address these challenges.Â â€œMilitary strategists see clearly the possibility of climate impacts increasing tensions over resources and mass movements of peopleâ€, he continued. â€œAs coastal areas or degraded inland areas become uninhabitable, people will seek safety and better lives elsewhereâ€.Recalling that more than 24 million people in 118 countries and territories were displaced by natural disasters in 2016, he told Pacific leaders their islands and communities "are in the forefront of global climate negotiationsâ€.He vowed the UNâ€™s strong commitment â€œto supporting your response to climate change and reversing the negative trends that have put your cultures and very existence at riskâ€.There are 2 major challenges facing Pacific islands today:1 > climate change, which wreaks havoc through extreme weather2 > rising oceans, which threatens to submerge the islands.Here are the key takeaways from @UN chief @AntonioGuterres's visit to Fiji: pic.twitter.com/qX3mNO9Ic3Climate change also threatens the well-being of the worldâ€™s ocean and seas, which are critical to the economies and traditions of the Pacific.â€œOceans are warming and becoming more acidic, causing coral bleaching and reducing biodiversityâ€ the UN chief told the Forum, stating that global warming of 1.5 degrees Celsius would cause â€œsevere damage to tropical reefsâ€.Â Moreover, if warming reached two degrees Celsius or more, â€œit would be catastrophic for marine life and humans alikeâ€ he said. â€œFood security would decline. Economic growth would sufferâ€.But seas and marine lifeÂ are also under attack from other directions. Mr. Guterres painted a picture of overfishing; underwater deserts in effect, with no oxygen; seas filled with poison and trash, and species becoming extinct within decades.Â â€œEvery year, more than eight million tonnes of harmful plastic waste end up in the oceanâ€ he said. â€œAccording to one recent study, plastic could outweigh fish in our seas by 2050â€.While many countries are finally rejecting single-use plastic, the UN chief underscored that â€œwe must do even moreâ€ to address the unsustainable levels of stress on marine and coastal ecosystems.He commended Pacific countries for ensuring the adoption of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 14 to conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development, saying that his Special Envoy for the Ocean, Fijiâ€™s Peter Thomson, is promoting the SDGs and the outcomes of the UN OceanÂ Conference.Â â€œTo address the intertwined challenges of climate change and ocean health, we need smart and far-reaching stepsâ€ that require action aligned with the Paris Agreement and the 2030 Agenda, which makes full use of tools, such as the Convention on the Law of the Sea, according to the UN chief.â€œWe have the blueprints, frameworks and plansâ€ he stated. â€œWhat we need is urgency, will and ambitionâ€.Mr. Guterres spoke of his Climate Action Summit in September at UN Headquarters, as an opportunity â€œto scale upâ€ pledges to halt emission increases 2020, and â€œdramatically reduceâ€ them to net-zero emissions by mid-century.He also stressed the importance of gender diversity in decision making as climate change has impacts on women, citing as an example that food salinization affects the health of pregnant women and newborns.Come September, Mr. Guterres said that sustainable development will be centre-stage as SDG progress will be reviewed and finance mobilization discussed.He lauded Pacific countriesâ€™ commitment to promote their vision of a â€œBlue Continentâ€ and maintained that their voices â€œremain crucial in global negotiationsâ€.â€œThe Pacific has a unique moral authority to speak outâ€ he said. â€œIt is time for the world to listenâ€.â€˜A very illuminating meetingâ€™In his closing remarks, the UN chief reiterated that because Pacific Island States are â€œleading by exampleâ€, they have â€œthe moral authorityâ€ to tell the world that climate change needs to be reversed.While lauding some of the innovations mentioned over the last two day, Mr. Guterres warned that â€œwe are not yet winning the battle in relation to climate change and we are not yet winning the battle in relation to oceansâ€.Â â€œWe will not give up and we want the Summit that we are convening in September to be a reaffirmation of this objective and its feasibility and the request for the political will to be in place, especially from those countries that are contributing more to climate changeâ€ he underscored.Noting the linkages between climate change, oceans and development, the UN chief stressed that â€œwe must mobilize the whole multilateral systemâ€ and â€œthe international communityâ€ to address climate change â€œin the context of all the other problems that we are facing and all the other battles that we are not winningâ€.According to the UN chief, the Forumâ€™s final message is â€œto clearly say, we are determined to address the challenge of climate change but itâ€™s not only the Pacific that is at stake, itâ€™s the whole planet and even the most developed countries in the world will face dramatic impacts.â€Â â€œWhat we ask for is not solidarity, itâ€™s not generosity, it is enlightened self-interest from all decision-makers around the worldâ€, concluded the Secretary-General.

title: â€˜Disaster resilientâ€™ farming reduces agriculture risks, yields economic gains, says new UN agriculture agency report
text: According toÂ Disaster risk reduction at farm level: Multiple benefits, no regrets by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), poor farmers can obtain significant economic gains and other benefits by implementing modified farming practices aimed at boosting their ability to cope with disasters and natural shocks."The study makes clear that in most cases, disaster risk reduction (DRR) efforts on the farm make good economic sense: that investing in DDR early can save many dollars that would otherwise be spent on post-disaster rehabilitation," said Dominique Burgeon, Director of FAO Emergency and Resilience Division, in the foreword to the report.Affordable solutions, tangible benefits. Poor farmersğŸ‘©â€ğŸŒ¾ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸŒ¾ can obtain significant economic gains through easy-to-implement "disaster resilient" practices - new @FAO study.https://t.co/AMbs3qFsUe #ZeroHunger #WRC4 #GP2019Geneva pic.twitter.com/rWxkygds2WThrough multi-year trials on over 900 farms in 10 different countries, FAO stated that many of the low-cost farming innovations are within easy reach of poor farmers. And, they are much more than buffers against disasters.ExamplesÂ include planting mangrove to protect coastal areas from floods, and shifting to rooftop water collection and irrigation systems."Farm-level DRR good practices are often â€˜no-regretâ€™ measuresâ€™, Ms. Burgeon continued, explaining that â€œthey prove effective in providing added benefits even in the absence of hazards".FAO's study illustrates that good practices have considerable potential to reduce damages wrought on developing world agriculture by smaller-scale, lower-intensity disasters. While these garner less attention than large-scale hazards, like dry or cold spells, they represent a constant problem for the 2.5 billion people who rely on small-scale agriculture.On average, DRR practices have generated benefits 2.2 times higher than practices previously used by farmers, including in increased agricultural production and avoided hazard-associated risks.In hazard scenarios, for every dollar invested in DRR, the farmer achieved $3.7 in terms of avoided loss or return. And under non-hazard conditions, the return rose even further, to $4.5.These practices can benefit billions of people, preventing economic losses and delivering economic benefits at regional and national levels.Greater upfront investment in anticipatory measures is also more cost efficient than post-disaster spending on reconstruction and recovery, the report says.This can be done through farmer-to-farmer replication, or when local farmers begin to adopt new techniques after observing the benefits their neighbors gained when doing so. This method requires little investment or institutional support.Another avenue is through large-scale efforts that require government and private sector support to promote the practices at scale.Crucially, both pathways depend on good infrastructure, adequate investment and an enabling environment. Agricultural development policy, planning and extension work should treat disaster risk reduction as a priority, the report stressed.

title: Mondayâ€™s Daily Brief: #ClimateAction for the Pacific, Gaza blockade, attack in Burkina Faso
text: At a time when Muslims globally are observing the holy month of Ramadan, more than half the population in Gaza depends on the international community for food aid, the director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) said on Monday, citing a â€œnear ten-fold increaseâ€ in need.According to UNRWA, it must secure an additional $60 million by June to continue providing food to more than one million Palestine refugees in Gaza, including some 620,000 â€œabject poorâ€ who cannot cover their basic food needs and are surviving on $1.6 per day.>> Read our full coverage here.Listen to Matthias Schmale, UNRWA's Director of OperationsÂ in Gaza:SpeakingÂ to young MÄoris and people of the Pacific Islands in New Zealand on Monday, UNÂ Secretary-General AntÃ³nio GuterresÂ said â€œnature does not negotiateâ€ and emphasized four key measures that Governments should prioritize in order to reach carbon neutrality by 2050.For this, he called on nations worldwide to make four pivotal shifts: 1/ tax pollution, not people; 2/ stop subsidizing fossil fuels; 3/ stop building new coal plants; 4/ focus on a green economy.>> Find out more about his proposals here.In a related development, indigenous Australians are set to ask the UN Human Rights Committee to investigate its claim that the government is doing too little to limit climate change.According to reports, Torres Strait islanders in the north of the country say that global warming is a threat to their survival, thanks to rising seas, tidal surges and coastal erosion. They maintain that the lack of action by the authorities is a threat to their human rights.As part of their claim, the group is calling for the UN panel â€“ which is one of 10 human rights committees that meet regularly throughout the year in Geneva â€“ to call for Australia to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions.Senior UN officials, including Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres have voiced their outrage at a deadly attack on a Catholic church in the north of Burkina Faso on Sunday, during which six people were reportedly killed by gunmen.According to media reports, the attack took place in the town of Dablo, situated in a region that has seen a spike in violence in recent months. The church was burned to the ground, along with other buildings including a health centre.>> Find our full coverage here.Â Listen to or download our audioÂ  News in Brief for 13Â May 2019 on SoundCloud:

title: Climate action: 4 shifts the UN chief encourages Governments to make
text: #ClimateAction: The clock is ticking for Pacific islands. Here are 4 shifts @UN chief @AntonioGuterres wants us to focus on:1âƒ£Tax pollution, not people2âƒ£No subsidies for fossil fuels3âƒ£No new coal plants by 20204âƒ£Focus on a green economyMore info â¡ï¸ https://t.co/ECW3VnSnaq pic.twitter.com/visGINbUS0Acknowledging the role that youth needs to play in advancing climate action worldwide, he reminded the room of our common â€œcentral objective: not to have more than 1.5 degrees of increasing temperature at the end of the century. The international community, and especially the scientific community, has been very clear that to reach this goal we absolutely need to have carbon neutrality by 2050.â€For this, he called on nations worldwide to make four pivotal shifts:The UN chief called for an emphasis to be placed on taxes on carbon emissions, known as â€œcarbon pricing,â€ instead of being placed on salaries.He stressed that taxpayer money should not be used to increase the frequency of hurricanes, the spread of drought and heatwaves, the melting of glaciers and the bleaching of corals.Coal-based power is key according to UN-environmentâ€™s 2018 Emissions Gap Report: all plants currently in operation are committing the world to around 190 giga tonnes of CO2, and if all coal power plants currently under construction go into operation and run until the end of their technical lifetime, emissions will increase by another 150 giga tonnes, jeopardizing our ability to limit global warming by 2Â°C as agreed upon in the 2015 Paris Agreement.â€œIt is very important that around the world young people, civil society and those that in the business community have understood that the green economy is the economy of the future and the grey economy has no future,â€ said Mr. Guterres. â€œItâ€™s very important that you convince governments that they must act because thereâ€™s still a lot of resistance,â€ he told the youth gathered in the room.â€œGovernments are still afraid to move forward,â€ he deplored explaining that â€œthey feel the costs of climate action forgetting that the costs of inaction are much bigger than any costs of climate actionâ€.â€œNature does not negotiate,â€ he added. â€œItâ€™s very good to see youth in the frontline.â€On 23 September, the UN chief is convening a Climate Change Summit to galvanize increased ambition for decisive climate action.

title: UN chief praises New Zealand premierâ€™s â€˜admirableâ€™ response to Christchurch attacks
text: Mr. Guterres pointed out that he normally pays a â€œsolidarity visitâ€ to a Muslim country during Ramadan but, this year, he decided to visit the Muslim community in Christchurch, â€œto pay tribute to their courage, to their resilience, but also to pay tribute to the extraordinary unity and to the message of solidarity that was given by the people and the government of New Zealand.â€Â During visit to #Pacific Island States, @antonioguterres pays tribute to leading role #NewZealand legislation is playing in #GunControl and #climatechange More on the story here: https://t.co/Wlg0oDQ8Rx â€¦ pic.twitter.com/28tJqE5zHpThe UN chief also expressed his admiration for Ms. Ardernâ€™s rapid and decisive response to the mass shootings, which saw the Government immediately takeÂ measures to significantly strengthen gun control legislation, and her callÂ to prevent hate speech on social media and the Internet.Â Ms. Ardernâ€™s appeals and leadership, he added, were extremely important in the context of the UN initiatives to fight hate speech,Â and to better support countries in the protection of holy sites.Â The Secretary-General's visit to New Zealand is part of a tour of the Pacific Island States in which theÂ Â urgent issue of climate change figures strongly : in his remarks to the press,Â Â Mr Guterres thankedÂ NewÂ Zealand for its leading stance in combatting the â€œclimate emergency,â€ and the country's support for the Pacific Island States, which he described as being on the frontlineÂ of the dramatic impacts of climate change.â€œIâ€™ll be visiting Fiji, Tuvalu and Vanuatu and conveying a very strong message from the Pacific to the rest of the world:Â we absolutely must catch up, we absolutely must be able to stop this dramatic trend, to reverse this dramatic trend. We cannot allow runaway climate change. We need to protect the lives of all people and we need to protect our planet.â€Â The Secretary-General also noted New Zealandâ€™s introduction of legislation to achieve carbon neutrality before 2050,Â and keep global warming to 1.5 degrees by the end of the century,Â a goal reiterated by the scientific community in aÂ UN reportÂ released in October 2018, described at the time by Mr. Guterres as â€œanÂ ear-splitting wake-up call.â€Â However, he said that political will has been fading in other countries, even though they are conscious of the need to act, which is one of the reasons for launching a specialÂ UN Climate SummitÂ to be held at UN Headquarters in New York in September.

title: Ensuring the â€˜lungs of the planetâ€™ keep us alive: 5 things you need to know about forests and the UN
text: Arguably, protection and enhancing the worldâ€™s forests is one of the most cost-effective forms of climate action: forests act as carbon sinks, absorbing roughly 2 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide each year.Â  Sustainable forest management can build resilience and help mitigate and adapt to climate change.Speaking at the 2018 UN climate conference (COP24) in Katowice, Poland, Liu Zhemin, head of the UNâ€™s Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA), said that â€œforests are central in developing solutions both to mitigate and adapt to climate change, adding that â€œthese terrestrial ecosystems have already removed nearly one third of human-produced carbon dioxide emissions from the atmosphere. Through sustainable forest management, they could remove much more.â€At this weekâ€™s meeting session of the UNFF, it was noted that forest-based climate change mitigation and adaptation actions, if fully implemented, could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by around 15 gigatonnes of CO2 a year by 2050, which could potentially be enough to limit warming to well below 2Â°C (the target set by the international community in 2015). Today, fossil fuels emit 36 gigatonnes every year.In addition, as renewable sources increasingly replace fossil fuels, forests will become more and more important as sources of energy: already, forests supply about 40 per cent of global renewable energy in the form of wood fuel â€“ as much as solar, hydroelectric and wind power combined.Significant progress has been made in international forest protection over the past 25 years. The rate of net global deforestation has slowed by more than 50 per cent, a credit to global efforts to sustainably manage existing forests, while at the same time engaging in ambitious measures to restore degraded forests and land, and to plant more trees to meet the demand for forest products and services.Â The goal of zero net global deforestation is close to being reached, bringing the world one step closer to the UN Strategic Plan for Forestâ€™s target to expand global forest area by 3 per cent by 2030, an area of 120 million hectares, about the size of South Africa.Many people will be aware of the devastating effects that illegal and unsustainable logging has on forests, but the biggest global driver of deforestation is actually agriculture, because of the extent to which forests are converted to farmland and livestock grazing land: a key challenge is how to manage the ongoing increase in agricultural production, and improve food security, without reducing overall forest areas.A major UN report on biodiversity, released in May, made headlines around the world with its headline figure of one million species at risk of extinction, warned against the destruction of forests, noting that this â€œwill likely have negative impacts on biodiversity and can threaten food and water security as well as local livelihoods, including by intensifying social conflict.â€The first time forests came to the forefront of the international agenda was at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio, widely regarded as one of the landmark UN conferences. The Summit led to the adoption of Agenda 21, the first significant international action plan for achieving sustainable development, which noted the â€œmajor weaknesses in the policies, methods and mechanisms adopted to support and develop the multiple ecological, economic, social and cultural roles of trees, forests and forest lands.â€The Earth Summit also saw the adoption of the Forest Principles which, although non-legally binding, was the first global consensus reached on the sustainable management of forests. The Principles called for all countries to make efforts towards reforestation and forest conservation; enshrined the right of nations to develop forests in keeping with national sustainable development policies; and called for financial resources to be provided for targeted economic policies.To better co-ordinate international efforts to put the principles into practice, an inter-governmental panel and forum were set up in the 1990s, to be replaced in 2000 by the UN Forum on Forests (UNFF), which meets every year at UN Headquarters in New York to monitor progress on the implementation of the six Global Forest Goals.The Goals set targets for the sustainable management of forests, and reduction of deforestation and forest degradation, and were developed as part the forest communityâ€™s response to the 2030 agenda for Sustainable Development, the UNâ€™s overall blueprint for economic progress that protects the environment and humanity.One of the key take-aways from the 2019 session of the UN Forest Forum was that, too often, forests areÂ under-valued, because itâ€™s hard to put a clear monetary value on all of the positive contributions they make to the world.As a result, the true cost of deforestation and forest degradation is not taken into account when policy decisions are made on land use, such as decisions to clear forest land to use for commercial agriculture.Â The importance of financing was another important element of the session:Â  sufficient funding is an essential element in ensuring effective action to halt deforestation and forest degradation, promote greater sustainable forest management and increase the worldâ€™s forest area: despite the central role forests play in protecting the environment, only 2 per cent of funds available for climate change mitigation are available for efforts to reduce deforestation.

title: Paradise islands of Pacific increasingly vulnerable to climate change, as UN boosts resilience
text: Simona Marinescu is the UN Resident Coordinator for the 28 islands that make up Samoa, Cook Islands, Niue and Tokelau.Speaking to UN News ahead of the Secretary-Generalâ€™s visit, she described some of the issues facing the region, including how to get young people to gain more schooling and skills to get or start their own businesses on the islands â€“ and how to make the islands more enticing for businesses. Ms. Marinescu starts the interview by describing a trip to Tokelau, whose farthest island is 50 hours away by boat form Samoa.The greatest threat to the way of life in the Pacific is climate change. Ms. Marinescu said one of the main concerns for Governments in the region is keeping the balance between access to finance and tools for adapting to climate change, while also growing their economies. Many of the small island Pacific nations are developing, and once they â€œgraduateâ€ to middle-income, doors to financing mechanisms close.â€œThey are proud to graduate,â€ said Ms. Marinescu. â€œHowever, they still remain fragile. They remain exposed to climate change. So a big debate right now is how we can decouple graduation from access to major funding streams that help them build resilience.â€Samoa, for example, jumped from the Least Developed Country to Developing status in 2014. It also received $65 million; one of the largest country allocations from the Green Climate Fund, for a six-year project on flood management â€“ which means building seawalls and river walls to protect housing, and rethinking housing design.Mr. Guterres will begin his visit to the region starting in Auckland, New Zealand, on Sunday. Follow all the highlights on UN News.

title: Climate change: â€˜A moral, ethical and economic imperativeâ€™ to slow global warming say UN leaders, calling for more action
text:
Calling on Member States to take â€œurgent action to limit global temperature rise to 1.5Â°C above pre-industrial levelsâ€, the leaders of more than 30 UN agencies and entities, issued a formal, joint appeal for governments everywhere to â€œstep up ambition and take concrete actionâ€ ahead of the landmark Climate Action Summit, which has been convened by UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres this September.The appeal noted that to keep rising temperatures down, countries had to strive to "fulfil their obligations on human rights, including the right to health, the right to food security, the right to development, the rights of indigenous peoples, local communities, migrants, children, persons with disabilities and people in vulnerable situations, as well as gender equality, empowerment of women, intergenerational equity, and decent work and a just transition for all, as stated in the Paris Agreement.â€
We call upon Member States to come to New York in September with concrete, realistic plans to enhance their nationally determined contributions by 2020 - UN leadership appeal
Â As set out by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Special Report on Global Warming, limiting global warming to 1.5Â°C â€œis necessary to prevent irreversible changes.Â Achieving this goal will require changes on an unprecedented scale at all levels, but it is still possible if we act nowâ€, said the UN system-wide appeal.â€œWith great urgency we call upon Member States to come to New York in September with concrete, realistic plans to enhance their nationally determined contributions by 2020 and in support to the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals.â€The communique issued after consultations during a meeting of the UN Chief Executives Board for Coordination, called on countries to ensure that appropriate â€œadaptation measuresâ€ are taken to protect people, jobs and ecosystems, â€œparticularly people in those regions most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change including those at risk through forced displacement and migration.â€Climate change is a race we can win, but we must step up ambition now. Today, the @UN is committing to concrete steps and calling on countries for ambitious commitments ahead of our #ClimateAction Summit in September. https://t.co/Z2sewrUbAGOn the crucial issue of paying for the ambitious measures which need to be taken, the appeal described climate finance as "critical to deliver action on the necessary scale to address climate changeâ€¦developed countries must deliver on the goal of mobilizing governments and the private sector to achieve the goal of $100 billion per year by 2020, to support climate action in developing countries and further enhance their efforts on scaling-up financial resources.â€And in the race to innovate, the appeal calls for greater ambition, noting that â€œthe Fourth Industrial Revolution offers tremendous potential for a paradigm shift to low-emission, climate-resilient development pathways.â€The UN system is supporting â€œthe enhancement of capacity of Member States to develop and utilize relevant data and technological innovations, to find solutions for climate and sustainable development challenges and disaster risk reduction and management, including the use of new and emerging technologies, including information and communication technologies, data and tools.And the UN is going to practice what it is preaching from the Secretariat and beyond. â€œWe will present our system-wide efforts towards reaching climate neutrality in our internal operations by 2020 and enhancing environmental and social sustainability in all UN activitiesâ€, says the joint appeal.

title: FROM THE FIELD: â€˜Race is onâ€™ to halt biodiversity loss in Indonesia

title: New SDG Advocates sign up for â€˜peace, prosperity, peopleâ€™ and planet, on the road to 2030
text: â€œWe have the tools to answer the questions posed by climate change, environmental pressure, poverty and inequalityâ€, said UN Secretary-General, AntÃ³nio Guterres. â€œThey lie in the great agreements of 2015 â€“ the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Paris Agreement on climate change.â€â€œBut tools are no use if you donâ€™t use them. So, today, and every day, my appeal is clear and simple. We need action, ambition and political will. More action, more ambition and more political will,â€ said the UN chief.2019 @SDGAdvocates announced Thurs to advance #SDGs. @almmura tells us why she's a @UN Advocate: â€œI believe in gender equality, reducing inequalities, I fundamentally believe in inclusive security, and that the only way we can get ahead, is if we go togetherâ€. pic.twitter.com/9uAdXnJJQ5They are joining and overall group of 17, who are all committed to raising awareness, inspiring greater ambition, and pushing for faster action on the SDGs, which include the end of extreme hunger, poverty, and quality healthcare for all.The Advocates represent the universal character of the SDGs themselves, hailing from Governments, entertainment, academia, sport, business and activist organizations around the world.â€œBy joining forces to achieve our goals, we can turn hope into reality â€“ leaving no one behind,â€ said Co-Chair of the SDG Advocates group, Prime Minister Erna Solberg of Norway.â€œThis is a time of great hope for the world. If we work smartly together and stay on course, we can raise millions out of poverty and significantly expand basic social services for many more by the 2030 end date of the SDGs,â€ added Co-Chair of the SDG Advocates and President of Ghana, Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo.Â  Â Mr. Guterres has appointed some members of the previous group of SDG Advocates as SDG Advocate Alumni and said on Thursday he was looking forward to their ongoing support and engagement.

title: UN and African Union in â€˜common battleâ€™ for development and climate change financing
text: Mr. Guterres declared that the Organizationâ€™s work to promote peace and security, human rights, development and climate action, can only progress in Africa if the UN works hand in hand with the AU.The UN chief emphasised the â€œalignmentâ€ between the UNâ€™s and African Unionâ€™s respective plans to ramp up inclusive and environmentally responsible economic development: the UNâ€™s 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, and the African Unionâ€™s Agenda 2063.The common battle they face, he continued, is to secure the necessary financing for development, particularly for Africa. Mr. Guterres said that development there is a â€œfundamental preconditionâ€ for a more peaceful world, and for well-managed migration, and, therefore, that improved funding is â€œin the interests of the whole international community.â€With regard to climate change, the Secretary-General warned that more ambition is needed, because â€œwe are not winning the battle,â€ and Africa is disproportionately affected: â€œthe African continent practically does not contribute to climate change, but the African continent is one of the areas of the world where the impact of climate change is more dramatic and devastating.â€A joint communiquÃ© released on Monday by the UN and African Union welcomed the â€œstrong cooperation and collaboration between the two organizationsâ€, and committed to continue to work closely together in addressing peace and security issues, and achieving sustainable development issues in Africa.The communiquÃ© described the UN Climate Action Summit, which will take place in September, as â€œcritical to mobilize the needed partnerships, resourcesâ€ necessary to achieve international climate action goals, and noted the agreement of the leaders of both organizations to further strengthen their cooperation on adaptation for climate change ahead of the Summit and beyond.

title: Mondayâ€™s Daily Brief: biodiversity and forests, labour and road safety, womenâ€™s rights, and fallen UN staff remembered
text: A hard-hitting report into the impact of humans on nature shows that nearly one million species risk becoming extinct within decades, while current efforts to conserve the earthâ€™s resources will likely fail without radical action, UN biodiversity experts said on Monday.Speaking in Paris at the launch of the Global Assessment study â€“ the first such report since 2005 â€“ UNESCO Director-General Audrey Azoulay said that its findings put the world â€œon noticeâ€.Find our full story here.The global community gathered at UN Headquarters in New York on Monday, to take action on behalf of the worldâ€™s forests.With an estimated 1.6 billion people â€“ or one quarter of the overall population â€“ dependent on forests for subsistence, livelihood, jobs and income, they are essential for human well-being, and play a vital role in promoting economic growth. They are also increasingly important to combat climate change.The 14th session of UN Forum on Forests runs until Friday and will take stock of progress in implementing the UN Strategic Plan for Forests, which provides a blueprint for including them in the 2030 Agenda and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).The Strategic plan and its associated targets provide a global framework for sustainably managing all types of forests and trees, halting and reversing deforestation and forest degradation, and increasing forest area by 2030.A UN study based on 1.2 billion people has found stark differences in the number of hours that many of us spend earning a living.According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), one-sixth of workers in the European Union (EU) toil away for more than 48 hours per week, but more than half of all employees in Chile, the Republic of Korea and Turkey, put in the same long hours.Jobs involving tight deadlines and stress, apply to one in three people in the EU, rising to one in two in the United States, Turkey, El Salvador and Uruguay.Physical risks are also â€œfrequentâ€, the report finds, with more than half of workers exposed to repetitive hand and arm movements, and about one-in-four, to high temperatures.Among the studyâ€™s other findings are that while 70 per cent of workers were positive about their managers, up to 12 per cent said they faced abuse, including bullying, unwanted sexual attention and harassment. And while up to 84 per cent of staff in the EU, Uruguay and the US said they learn new things while theyâ€™re working, only 30 per cent of workers agreed with this in the Republic of Korea, and just 55 per cent in China.Regardless of the country, least-educated workers are less likely to develop their skills, the report says, highlighting also that good working conditions â€œcontribute to the well-being of workers and the success of enterprisesâ€.Finally, across all 41 countries covered in the joint ILO-Eurofound report, women were found to earn significantly less than men â€“ and they are also â€œover-representedâ€ at the lowest end of the salary scale.Despite progress, road traffic deaths continue to rise, with an annual 1.35 million fatalities. Road traffic injuries are now the leading killer of children and young people aged 5-29 years. The warning comes from the World Health Organization (WHO), in the context of the Fifth UN Global Road Safety Week which started on Monday.During the week, thousands of safety advocates from around the world are expected to highlight the need for more effective leadership for road safety, through the #SpeakUp campaign.Calling for a â€œworld free from road traffic deaths and injuriesâ€, WHOâ€™s Director-General, Tedros Ghebreyesus, described a world in which all people benefit from universal health coverage, rehabilitation and psychological support.Pedestrians and cyclists account for 26 per cent of all road deaths, while motorcycle riders and passengers account for 28 per cent.WHOâ€™s Director, Dr. Etienne Krug, called on governments and their partners to â€œaccelerate action to save lives by implementing solutions that workâ€.To mark the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, considered the blueprint on womenâ€™s rights and empowerment, gender agency UN Women announced on Monday a new multigenerational campaign, titled â€œGeneration Equality: Realizing womenâ€™s rights for an equal futureâ€.Â In 2020, it will be 25 years since 189 Governments committed to taking bold actions in 12 critical areas of concern regarding gender equality: poverty, education and training, health, violence, armed conflict, economy, power and decision-making, institutional mechanisms, human rights, media, environment, and the girl child.â€œToday, the reality is that not a single country can claim to have achieved gender equality. Despite some progress, real change has been too slow for most women and girls in the world, and we see significant pushback in many places against their leadership and agency,â€ said UN Women Executive Director, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka.The Generation Equality campaign will bring together several generations of womenâ€™s rights activists to galvanize attention and action on key issues including equal pay, equal sharing of unpaid care and domestic work, an end to sexual harassment and all forms of violence against women and girls, health-care services that respond to their needs, and their equal participation in economic and political life and decision-making in all areas of life.The lives of 115 colleagues who lost their lives between the beginning of last year and the end of March, serving the United Nations, were honoured on Monday at the annual Memorial Service for Fallen Staff, in New York.UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said that it was a â€œsad reminder of the often-perilous nature of our workâ€ but also â€œtestament to the commitment of the thousands of women and men from around the globe who are prepared to risk all to promote peace and provide assistance to some of the worldâ€™s most vulnerable and needy people.â€Read our full coverage of the ceremony here.Listen to or download our audio 3-minute News in Brief for 6Â May 2019 on SoundCloud:

title: World is â€˜on noticeâ€™ as major UN report shows one million species face extinction
text: Speaking in Paris at the launch of the Global Assessment study â€“ the first such report since 2005 â€“ UNESCO Director-General Audrey Azoulay said that its findings put the world â€œon noticeâ€.At 1pm (CET) on Monday 6 May, the key findings of the @IPBES #GlobalAssessment - the definitive global synthesis of the state of #biodiversity, ecosystems and #nature's contributions to people - will be launched via live webcast. ğŸ“¹: Watch here: https://t.co/bONK3WLXYx #IPBES7 pic.twitter.com/0Frfph9Ec1â€œFollowing the adoption of this historic report, no one will be able to claim that they did not know,â€ the head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said. â€œWe can no longer continue to destroy the diversity of life. This is our responsibility towards future generations.â€Highlighting the universal importance of biodiversity â€“ the diversity within species, between species and of ecosystems â€“ Ms. Azoulay said that protecting it â€œis as vital as fighting climate changeâ€.Presented to more than 130 government delegations for their approval at UNESCO headquarters, the report features the work of 400 experts from at least 50 countries, coordinated by the Bonn-based Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES).In addition to providing exhaustive insights on the state of nature, ecosystems and how nature underpins all human activity, the study also discusses progress on key international goals, such as the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Aichi Biodiversity Targets and the Paris Agreement on climate change.The report also examines five main drivers of â€œunprecedentedâ€ biodiversity and ecosystem change over the past 50 years, identifying them as: changes in land and sea use; direct exploitation of organisms; climate change, pollution, and invasion of alien species.On at-risk fauna and flora, the study asserts that human activities â€œthreaten more species now than ever beforeâ€ â€“ a finding based on the fact that around 25 per cent of species in plant and animal groups are vulnerable.This suggests that around one million species â€œalready face extinction, many within decades, unless action is taken to reduce the intensity of drivers of biodiversity lossâ€.Without such measures there will be a â€œfurther accelerationâ€ in the global rate of species extinction, which is already â€œat least tens to hundreds of times higher, than it has averaged over the past 10 million yearsâ€, the report states.It notes that despite many local efforts, including by indigenous peoples and local communities, by 2016, 559 of the 6,190 domesticated breeds of mammals used for food and agriculture were extinct â€“ around nine per cent of the total - and at least 1,000 more are threatened.In addition, many crop wild relatives that are needed for long-term food security â€œlack effective protectionâ€, the report insists, while the status of wild relatives of domesticated mammals and birds â€œis worseningâ€.At the same time, reductions in the diversity of cultivated crops, crop wild relatives and domesticated breeds mean that farming will likely be less resilient against future climate change, pests and pathogens.â€œWhile more food, energy and materials than ever before are now being supplied to people in most places, this is increasingly at the expense of natureâ€™s ability to provide such contributions in the future,â€ the report states, before adding that â€œthe biosphere, upon which humanity as a whole dependsâ€¦is declining faster than at any time in human historyâ€.On the issue of pollution, although global trends are mixed, air, water and soil pollution have continued to increase in some areas, the report insists. â€œMarine plastic pollution in particular has increased tenfold since 1980, affecting at least 267 speciesâ€, it says, including 86 per cent of marine turtles, 44 per cent of seabirds and 43 per cent of marine mammals.The 2019 Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services is also the first of its kind to examine and include indigenous and local knowledge, issues and priorities, IPBES said in a statement, noting that its mission is to strengthen policy-making for the sustainable use of biodiversity, long-term human well-being and sustainable development.â€œThe loss of species, ecosystems and genetic diversity is already a global and generational threat to human well-being,â€ insisted Sir Robert Watson, IPBES Chair. â€œProtecting the invaluable contributions of nature to people will be the defining challenge of decades to come. Policies, efforts and actions - at every level - will only succeed, however, when based on the best knowledge and evidence.â€

title: FROM THE FIELD: New sensors protect vulnerable Malawians against deadly lightning

title: FROM THE FIELD: Hardy seeds bear fruit to protect Colombiaâ€™s environment
text: The Antioquia region, a key agricultural area, has experienced steadily rising temperatures and now dry seasons are lasting longer. title: UN aid teams scramble to reach â€˜most remote placesâ€™ cut off by Cyclone Kenneth in Mozambique
text: Humanitarian affairs coordination office, OCHA, reported that heavy rains had paused in the morning around the coastalÂ city of Pemba, with aid workers going flat out to prepare relief flights â€“ including medical supplies â€“ to the island of Matemo, one of the worst-hit by the cyclone.â€œCertainly the impacts of #CycloneKenneth, just as the impacts of Cyclone Idai, are intensified because of #climatechange and because of sea-level rise.â€@UNOCHA, @Refugees, @WFP, @WHO and @WMO provide the latest updates on the situation in northern #Mozambique. pic.twitter.com/D01S4kckTjâ€œEmergency staff will also do further damage and needs assessments while they can, as more rain is expected in the coming days, turning the response into a start-stop operationâ€, said OCHA Spokesperson, Jens Laerke, briefing reporters in Geneva.The Government of Mozambique is reporting that at least 38 people died during the second massive cyclone to hit southern Africa in six weeks, following on from the devastating impact of Cyclone Idai. Kenneth partially or fully destroyed nearly 35,000 houses,Â close toÂ 200 classrooms; and at least 14 health facilities have been hit, OCHA reported.Around 21,000 people are now sheltering in accommodation centres, after their villages were wiped out, said Mr. Laerke, adding that some staff who had made an aerial survey, said that â€œsome villages looked like they had been bulldozed.â€ For the initial response, $10 million has been released for Mozambique by the head of OCHA, together with $3 million for the hard-hit Comoros Islands.Spokesperson for the UN refugee agency (UNHCR), Charlie Yaxley, said that â€œaccess to the most remote places remains difficultâ€, with reports that some remain â€œcompletely isolated and in need of rescueâ€. Although the northern areas hit by Kenneth are less populated than other parts of the country, the damage and flooding had been â€œextensiveâ€.Drawing on eye witness accounts from UNHCR teams on the ground in Pemba since the weekend, he said parts of the city had been completely flooded. â€œIn the most deprived areas, houses had collapsed, and flash floods left mud and trash all over the streetsâ€¦Communities are organizing themselves to clean up streets and remove the sand and muck brought by the storms. Despair is evident.â€In the worst affected areas â€œpeople have lost everythingâ€ said Herve Verhoosel, Spokeperson for the World Food Programme (WFP), noting that thanks to early positioning of supplies, the agency has already reached 11,500 beneficiaries, beginning on Saturday morning.â€œThe ravages caused by the cyclone are compounded by the impact it has on agriculture, livelihoods and the food and nutrition security situationâ€. With preliminary Government assessments showing 31,300 hectares of crops lost, hitting at the peak of the harvest season, â€œthe short/mid/longterm availability of food is worrisomeâ€, added Mr. Verhoosel.He said the agency had already been providing food distributions and nutrition support in some affected districts since last year. â€œWFP is already working in Mozambique to increase resilience to climatic shocksâ€¦This focus becomes even more crucial, and additional funding in that regard after the emergency, will be essential to ensure we can help the country recoverâ€, he added.

title: Work to make the world a better place: 5 things you need to know about â€˜green jobsâ€™
text: For the UN, these â€œgreen jobs,â€ play an important role in realising the vision of the future that practically all countries signed up to when they adopted the landmarkÂ Paris AgreementÂ in December 2015, an international commitment to combat climate change, and significantly reduce human activity contributing to global warming.Â In the build-up to Septemberâ€™sÂ UN Climate Summit, which will aim to inject momentum into the fight against climate change, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres hasÂ called on world leadersÂ to come with concrete proposals for decent green jobs, declaring â€œdonâ€™t come with a speech, come with a plan.â€Â Â UN News got in touch withÂ MoustaphaÂ KamalÂ Gueye, coordinator of theÂ Green Jobs ProgrammeÂ at the International Labour Organization (ILO) â€“ the UN agency dedicated to promoting decent work â€“ to find out more.Â Â The ILO defines a green job as being one which contributes to preserving or restoring the environment. This can involve anything from improving energy efficiency, to actively de-carbonizing the economy and bringing down emissions of harmful gasses in the atmosphere.Â Â The ILO says thatÂ green jobs contribute to the transformation of economies, workplaces, enterprises and labour markets into a sustainable economy that protects the planet and provides decent employment opportunities for all. Whilst some sectors lend themselves more easily to green jobs, Ultimately, â€œall jobs could be greened,â€ says Mr.Â Gueye, â€œin the sense that the way the work is done reduces the environmental footprint of the company.â€Â For the UN, green jobs must also be â€œdecent jobs.â€ This means that they are productive, deliver a fair wage, social protectionÂ â€“ which includes policiesÂ to reduce poverty and vulnerability,Â such asÂ sickness, unemployment and disability benefits â€“Â and equality of opportunity for men and women. ThisÂ refers backÂ to theÂ 2030 Agenda, the UNâ€™s plan of action for people, planet and prosperity: one of the goals of the Agenda,Â Goal 8, calls for â€œfull and productive employment and decent work,â€ an aim whichÂ supportsÂ many other of the goals that make up the UNâ€™s vision forÂ an economy that benefits all, and causes less harm to the environment.Â Around the world many countries are trying to shift towards a cleaner economy, moving away from a reliance on energy produced by fossil fuels, such as coal and gas, towards a more sustainable supply by ramping up renewable energy sources, such as solar plants and windÂ farms.Â Â This is an important example of the ways that countries can transition to a â€œgreen economy.â€Â Â Whilst there is not a universally agreed definition of theÂ term, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP),Â describesÂ a green economy asÂ beingÂ one which isÂ â€œlow carbon, resource efficient and socially inclusive.â€Â At the UNâ€™sÂ Rio+20Â conference on sustainable development in 2012, one of the milestone conferencesÂ on the road to the adoption of the Paris Agreement,Â the outcome documentÂ declared that a green economyÂ is â€œone of the important tools available for achieving sustainable development,â€Â which should createÂ â€œopportunities for employment and decent work for all, while maintaining the healthy functioning of the Earthâ€™s ecosystems.â€Â TheÂ shiftÂ to a green economyÂ opens upÂ a â€œmassive opportunity for job creation,â€Â says Mr.Â Gueye. An obvious example is the energy industry, where the shift to renewable energiesÂ is creating new jobs inÂ companies catering to solar plants, wind farms and other clean energy sources.Â ButÂ the opportunities stretch farÂ beyond the energy industry,Â in both developed and developing countries,Â to includeÂ areas such asÂ constructionÂ and manufacturing, where a host ofÂ innovativeÂ new techniques, often driven by digital technology,Â are designed toÂ reduce waste and improveÂ efficiency.Â In developing countries, the ILO Green Jobs Programme actively helps communities to adopt and implement sustainable practices, increasing their chances of securing an income. In ruralÂ Zambia, for example, the Programme has trained women to build homes using sustainable techniques, and how to assemble and install solar panels, in a country suffering from an energy crisis, and where many people have never had access to electricity. The skills they have learned have had positive, life-changing benefits for the community and, by reducing waste and pollution, have reduced the impact on the environment.Â The UN, including the ILO,Â is very bullish onÂ theÂ benefitsÂ to the job market ofÂ a green economy,Â and says that most scenarios suggest that the net effect will be positive.Â In its 2018Â World Employment and Social OutlookÂ report, the ILOÂ says that, by 2030,Â 18Â million new jobs will result from taking the steps necessary to keepÂ the increase inÂ global temperatures to below 2 degrees Celsius.Â On top of this figure,Â a furtherÂ sixÂ millionÂ jobsÂ are expected toÂ result from the growth of the so-called â€œcircular economy,â€Â in which, rather than products being used over a short period and thrown away,Â there is more emphasis onÂ repairing, re-using and recycling.Â The UN doesnâ€™t shy away from the fact thatÂ the shift to a green economy willÂ that someÂ sixÂ million jobs â€“particularly inÂ industries that areÂ contributingÂ to the emission of harmful gases, and other drivers of global warming â€“ are expected to disappear.Â This is whyÂ theÂ ILOâ€™sÂ concept of a â€œJust Transitionâ€ is so important.Â Workers and communities across the worldÂ are already being impacted by theÂ changing economy,Â and this is only expected toÂ continue.Â A Just Transition accepts thatÂ some will face hardships as certain industries and occupationsÂ decline, butÂ putsÂ in placeÂ initiativesÂ toÂ addressÂ theÂ challenges. TheseÂ can includeÂ income support, retraining opportunities and relocation assistance.Â Â For the Just Transition to function effectively,Â a range of actors need to work together, from trade unions,Â toÂ national and local government, sustainability-conscious businesses and community-based organizations.Â And the prize couldnâ€™t be bigger: a world in which all peopleÂ work in decent, productive jobs,Â contributingÂ to a global economy thatÂ protects the environment, for theÂ benefitÂ of all.

title: Mondayâ€™s Daily Brief: Earth Day, looking for a solution to Libya crisis, focus on indigenous issues, Security Council on Sri Lanka, a high-level visit to Bangladesh
text: MarkingÂ International Mother Earth Day, the UN on Monday debated how best to build â€œan equitable and sustainable futureâ€ for all, through enhanced education andÂ climate action, on the road to a key international summit on the issue due to take place in September.Billed officially as an Interactive Dialogue on Harmony with Nature, the UNÂ General AssemblyÂ session involved Member States and top officials discussing the need to take urgent action against the pace of global warming, in line with the 2015Â Paris Agreement, to keep carbon dioxide emissions to well-belowÂ two degrees Celsius.The whole story here.TheÂ UNÂ Special Representative for Libya and Head of theÂ UN Mission in the country, UNSMIL, GhassanÂ SalamÃ©, is continuing his efforts toÂ try and de-escalate military action in and around the capital, Tripoli.Â Â TheÂ commanderÂ of the self-styled Libyan NationalÂ Army began an offensive to try and take the Libyan capital from forces backing the UN-recognized Government,Â more than two weeks ago.Â Â Hereâ€™s UN Spokesperson,Â StÃ©phane Dujarric, briefingÂ correspondentsÂ in New York on MondayÂ on Mr.Â Salameâ€™sÂ progress.Â â€œEarlier today, he met with Tunisian Foreign Minister KhamisÂ JhinaouiÂ in Tunis, with whom he discussed developments related to the clashes in southern Tripoli. Both asserted that the UN-facilitated political process is the ideal and only way to solve the Libyan crisis.â€Â According to theÂ UN office coordinating humanitarian affairsÂ (OCHA), thousands of civilians, refugees and migrants remain trapped in conflict-affected areas, unable to flee either because of fighting or detention.Â Â InÂ aÂ statement released on Monday, OCHA said that medical teamsÂ wereÂ working relentlessly to evacuate and care for people wounded in the conflict.Â Â Through the Tripoli flash appeal, the humanitarian communityÂ hasÂ urgently called for US$10.2 millionÂ to continueÂ providing life-saving relief, adding that â€œhumanitarian needs in Libya are rapidly increasing, while funding levels remain lowâ€.Â Traditional knowledge is at the core of indigenous identity, culture and heritage around the world, the chair of theÂ United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous IssuesÂ said at the annualÂ eventâ€™s opening day on Monday, stressing that it â€œmust be protectedâ€.Anne Nuorgam, who is a member of Finlandâ€™s Saami Parliament and head of the Saami Councilâ€™s Human Rights Unit, described the Forum as an opportunity to share innovations and practices, developed in indigenous communities â€œover centuries and millenniaâ€.Indigenous peoples make up less than six per cent of the worldâ€™s population, but account for 15 per cent of the poorest on earth, according to the Forum. They live in some 90 countries, represent 5,000 different cultures and speak the overwhelming majority of the worldâ€™s estimated 6,700 languages.Find the whole story here.The members of the UN Security Council condemned â€œin the strongest terms the series of heinous and cowardly terrorist attacksâ€ that took place in several churches and hotels in Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday, which resulted in nearly 300 killed and hundreds more wounded.They expressed their â€œdeepest sympathy and condolences to the families of the victims and to the Government of Sri Lankaâ€ and wished â€œa speedy and full recovery to those who were injuredâ€.Reaffirming that terrorism in all its forms and manifestations constitutes â€œone of the most serious threats to international peace and security,â€ they underlined the need to hold perpetrators, organizers, financiers and sponsors of these reprehensible acts of terrorism accountable and bring them to justice.The Security Council urged all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law and relevant Security Council resolutions, to cooperate actively with the Government of Sri Lanka and all other relevant authorities in this regard.The members of the Security Council reiterated that any acts of terrorism are criminal and unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, wherever, whenever and by whomsoever committed.Â  They reaffirmed the need for all States to combat by all means, in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and other obligations under international law, including international human rights law, international refugee law and international humanitarian law, threats to international peace and security caused by terrorist acts.Three top United Nations officials will visit BangladeshÂ later this week,Â to highlight the need for supporting the humanitarian needs ofÂ almost a millionÂ Rohingya refugeesÂ now living in the country.Â Â TheÂ UN announced the visit ofÂ High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), FilippoÂ Grandi; the Director General of theÂ migration agency,Â IOM, AntÃ³nio Vitorino; and the UNÂ relief chief, MarkÂ Lowcock,Â head of OCHA,Â in a statementÂ released on Monday.Â Â InÂ the capitalÂ Dhaka, the delegation will hold talks with senior government officials,Â and then travelÂ to Coxâ€™s Bazar to meet with refugees, assess preparations underway ahead of the monsoon season and visitÂ UNÂ support projects.Â The aim of the visit is to highlight the need to continue strong international support,Â while solutionsÂ can be found for the safe, dignified return of Rohingyas to Myanmar.

title: â€˜Do everything in your power to tackle climate changeâ€™ UN chief urges on Mother Earth Day
text: Billed officially as an Interactive Dialogue on Harmony with Nature, the UN General Assembly session involved Member States and top officials discussing the need to take urgent action against the pace of global warming, in line with the 2015 Paris Agreement, to keep carbon dioxide emissions to well-belowÂ two degrees Celsius.This video is a poignant reminder of the urgent need to protect the planet. On #EarthDay & every day, take #ClimateAction in every way you can. https://t.co/bGs5wt1RGM pic.twitter.com/lWzVmVtjWHIn a tweet to mark Earth Day, UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres said it was vital â€œevery dayâ€ to â€œcommit to taking better care of our planet. Please do everything in your power to tackle climate change â€“ the defining issue of our timeâ€, he said. â€œClimate change is one of the largest threats to sustainable development globally,â€ said the concept note prepared for the General Assembly meeting, â€œand is just one of many imbalances caused by the unsustainable actions of humankind, with direct implications for future generations.â€President of the General Assembly, Maria Fernanda Espinosa, said that taking care of nature was, in essence, â€œtaking care of peopleâ€. She also noted the importance of respecting life-cycles of the natural world, and contributing to biological diversity so that the world can â€œcontinue and prosperâ€.â€œWe are the last generation that can prevent irreparable damage to the planet and to its inhabitantsâ€ she tweeted. â€œWe are at a crossroads; this is the moment in which we decide the path we wish to take, to avoid reaching a point of no return in global warming. We already know the results of inaction.â€The international day recognizes a collective responsibility, as called for in the 1992 Rio Declaration, to promote harmony with nature and the Earth to achieve a just balance among the economic, social and environmental needs of present and future generations of humanity.It also provides an opportunity to raise public awareness around the world to the challenges regarding the well-being of the planet and all the life it supports.To boost ambition and accelerate actions to implement the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, the UN Secretary-General will host the 2019 Climate Action Summit on 23 September, to meet the climate challenge.

title: 5 world-changing ideas: our top picks for World Creativity and Innovation Day
text: Theyâ€™re small, self-sustaining â€“ and they could revolutionize the way we think about housing around the world, as building materials become scarcer.Measuring just about 22-square-meters, or some 200-square-feet, a â€œtiny houseâ€ comprised of one room with a loft or pull-out bed, hidden storage, a kitchen and a bathroom, was presented last September to get people thinking about decent, affordable housing that limits the overuse of natural resources and helps the battle against destructive climate change.The design was created by the UN environment agency and the Center for Ecosystems in Architecture at Yale University in the United States, in collaboration with UN-Habitat.Â Â After completing a historic 500 km journey from the Kenyan island of Lamu to the Tanzanian island of Zanzibar, the worldâ€™s first ever traditional â€œdhowâ€ sailing boat made entirely from recycled plastic, known as theÂ Flipflopi, was created toÂ raiseÂ awareness of the need to overcome one of the worldâ€™s biggest environmental challenges: plastic pollution.The Flipflopi Project was co-founded by Kenyan tour operator Ben Morison in 2016, and the ground-breaking dhow was built by master craftsman Ali Skanda, and a team of volunteers, using 10 tonnes of recycled plastic.The boat gets its name from the 30,000 recycled flip-flops used to decorate its multi-coloured hull.Â Â It takes around 7,500 litres of waterÂ to make a single pair of jeans,Â  equivalent to the amount of water the average person drinks over a period of seven years. Thatâ€™s just one of the many startling facts to emerge from recent environmental research, which show that the cost of staying fashionableÂ is a lot more than just the price tag.Despite the grim statistics, producers and consumers of fashion are increasingly waking up to the idea that the industry needs to change. A number of companies, including large volume retailers, are integrating sustainability principles into their business strategies. Examples include the global clothing chain H&M, which has a garment collection scheme; jeans manufacturer Guess, which is involved in a wardrobe recycling programme; and outdoor clothing company Patagonia, which produces jackets using polyester from recycled bottles.Â Â On a small island in the remote South Pacific, a one-month-old baby was the worldâ€™s first child to be given a vaccine delivered by a drone.The state-of-the-art craft which transported the vaccine, travelled nearly 40 kilometres over rugged mountain terrain, flying from Dillonâ€™s Bay in western Vanuatu to remote Cookâ€™s Bay â€“ a scattered community accessible only on foot or by small boats â€“ where 13 children and 5 pregnant women were inoculated by a nurse.Henrietta H. Fore, the Executive Director of UNICEF said the tiny aircraftâ€™s flight â€œis a big leap for global health.""With the world still struggling to immunize the hardest-to-reach children, drone technologies can be a game changer for bridging that last mile to reach every child,â€ she explained.Â Â Satellite-based tracking to chart how land is being used on the Earthâ€™s surface got much easier and more accessible, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO), thanks to the launch of a new online portal, developed in collaboration with the United States Space Agency, NASA.The system â€“ known as Collect Earth Online â€“ is web-based, free of charge, and open to all platforms. It allows users to â€œsystematically inspectâ€ any location on the planet, from glaciers to rainforests, with satellite data.â€œThis innovation allows the collection of up-to-date data about our environment and its changes in a more efficient and participatory manner, using the local experts that know the landscape and the underlying ecologyâ€, explained Mette Wilki, the head of Policy and Resources at FAOâ€™s Forestry Division.

title: â€˜The clock is tickingâ€™ on meeting the Sustainable Development Goals, says UN deputy chief
text:
â€œClimate change is ravaging the planetâ€¦ staggering numbers of children and youth â€“ especially girls and young women â€“ still lack access to basic education and healthcare services, [and] people in many countries are starved of economic opportunities, decent work and social protection measuresâ€, she told the Â 2019 ECOSOC Partnership Forum, where governments, business representatives and other influencers met to discuss how partnerships can best advance and the 17 (SDGs).During today's ECOSOC Partnership Forum, we explore how partnerships can drive inclusive implementation of the SDGs. Join us live: https://t.co/re8QqoTipx @UNDESA @AminaJMohammed #Partnerships2030 pic.twitter.com/gtOeEEIEkjUnder the theme, â€œPartnerships Driving Inclusive Implementation of the SDGsâ€, the Forum will capture key policy messages to inform the High-level Political Forum (HLPF) in in September.â€œOur task is immense, but many of the pathways to change are in plain sightâ€, she asserted, adding that while â€œsuccess is still possibleâ€, it requires difficult conversations around â€œthe need to fill partnership skillset gaps, tackle financing shortfalls, and address data deficienciesâ€.The economic, social and environmental dimensions of sustainable development call for â€œa fully integrated approachâ€ that engages everyone.â€œPartnerships are critical for achieving progress across the full agendaâ€ stressed Ms. Mohammed, calling SDG 17 on partnerships, â€œthe â€˜connective tissueâ€™ which will ensure an integrated and holistic approach to sustainable developmentâ€.The deputy UN chief shared four points for discussion, beginning with a commitment between the UN, governments, private sector and civil society to work together in a more coordinated and integrated way.Â â€œThe transformation we need requires us to acknowledge that everyone is a development actor,â€ she argued. â€œGovernments alone cannot achieve the SDGsâ€.Â Secondly, she pointed to the need to prioritize investments in platforms and coalitions that engage a larger ecosystem of partners.Â â€œInvestments in cross-cutting, high-return priorities have strong potential to unlock progress across multiple SDGsâ€, she stated, flaggin a range of areas, from quality education and health services to zero-carbon energy and environmental conservation.Ms. Mohammadâ€™s third point focused on leadership, innovation and strategic collaborations â€œat the local levelâ€.Â â€œWe must draw on the knowledge and experience of local communities and actors on the ground to ensure that we replicate and scale up the most promising modelsâ€, she emphasized.Â Ensuring that the process to socialize the SDGs and strengthen ownership is â€œinclusive, transparent and accountableâ€, was her final point.â€œAll stakeholders, big or small should find a place to play their role and make their contributionâ€, she maintained.Â 
The transformation we need requires us to acknowledge that everyone is a development actorÂ â€“ Deputy Secretary-General
